title: Privacy and Your Connected Car
subTitle: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.
promoTeaserSmall: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.
promoTeaser: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.
metaTitle: Privacy and Your Connected Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute
metaDescription: Privacy and Your Connected Car: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.  Read my report on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We, as modern drivers, are sitting right on the very edge of a whole new world. If you’ve driven a car with “smart” cruise control, lane-keeping assist, and other active safety features, you’ve sampled it. Connectivity has given us more convenience and more safety, and sooner than you think, all of our rides will be communicating seamlessly with other cars and the infrastructure of roads and signage around them.

In fact, right here in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the world's largest test bed for connected vehicles is taking shape. The University of Michigan's Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI) coordinates the academic/government/industry effort called the Michigan Mobility Transformation Center, where the real-world use of vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure communication is being perfected, complete with a test track.
There is so much new technology in our cars! It's all so fun! Who wants to think about the coding that's underneath it, and whether it respects us? Probably not you.

Yet, we have to think about it, for no other reason than that our own sense of the car as a private, personal space may be at risk. In fact, it seems nearly certain that we have already handed over at least some sense of being alone in the car. In exchange, we are getting a lot more guidance in terms of navigation, active safety, and Internet connectivity. The payoff could be a drastic reduction in the kinds of accidents caused by driver error, which is to say, most of them.

I walked in to the Global Symposium on Connected Vehicles and Infrastructure, well aware of my lack of deep technical understanding, but determined to figure out what's up with security and privacy in these fast-developing connected automobiles. You will be as glad as I was to know that these highly educated, deeply qualified scientists all over the world are all over this issue, with plans that are starting to bear fruit.

In the AP Calc reunion that was the session on "V2X Policy: Next Steps, Security and Privacy," I listened, fascinated, as five actively engaged experts dove into the subject of taking on what one called a "Wild West" environment and making it both protective of our privacy and resilient against hackers.

Andrew Smart of SAE International mused, "We all know that the first space shuttle had 420,000 lines of code. Now, today's auto industry has 40 million lines of code as of a couple of years ago. In five years' time, that should go up to 100 million plus." Faced with this complexity, the challenge, he said, is to ensure that it's as error-free and hacker-resistant as possible.
Once upon a time, it was man and machine in harmony. Now, with vehicle to Internet, it's one upon many. Engineers need to deal with the increased complexity.
As Smart put it: "Once upon a time, it was man and machine in harmony. Now, with vehicle to Internet, it's one upon many. Engineers need to deal with the increased complexity."

André Weimerskirch of UMTRI, an internationally known expert in automotive cybersecurity, has given this issue a lot of thought. In a marvel of understatement, he told the group: “It’s fairly simple to imagine that once you have electronics in the car that control your car and can accelerate, de-accererate, and steer, if someone can hack into the car, that is not good for us.”

He outlined three "hot spots" for cybersecurity research into cars. The first is misbehavior handling: "to be prepared and know what to do if someone successfully hacks into the car." Researchers are creating a comprehensive "misbehavior authority" that would include protection against attacks by design and also have a "plan B" in place if the security is breached. The second is creating and implementing standards for every level of automated vehicle, with testing solutions. And the third is privacy in the vehicle-to-vehicle domain, which he said was "highly desired and was included by design." Privacy protection for new applications, as they are invented, will have to be carefully considered, he said.

The quantum change, as Weimerskirch pointed out, is that vehicles are connected over a wireless interface—but “the models we know from the PC world” can’t just be carried over in a safety-critical environment like a car.

It’s too late to ask whether we want this level of connectivity: it's here. But, based on what I saw at this session, it’s reassuring that bright minds are working on compartmentalizing the interiors of our cars so that we get the connectivity we need and at least some level of privacy and protection from hackers. The nightmare scenario of some James Bond villain making your brakes go out on a lonely road by the click of a mouse? Not so much. As A2 Technology Management's Tom Schaffnit quipped, “I don’t think anybody in their right mind would be running their brake system on Android. There’s going to be compartmentalization in terms of what operating systems are used. Most critical systems are embedded and don’t run on Google or other platforms.”

Schaffnit said the five tasks on order are privacy by design (and policy), nationwide interoperability, integrated support for vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-Internet operations, safety, mobility, and environmental applications, and support for commercial and proprietary applications.

Walt Fehr of the Department of Transportation commented, “There may need to be a fundamentally different way a vehicle connects to the Internet now that we have the possibility of mandated communication-based technology.”
That's encouraging.
Always go for privacy by design. Store only data that is necessary and, more important, have technical limitations to access the data in the first place.

Weimerskirch went on: “You want to be in control of the data that your vehicle stores, but there are many other applications of privacy. People talk about Big Data where diagnostic data of your car is stored in the cloud or in a server. Insurance discounts are offered today where you plug in something to collect data.” If you think about it, there isn’t much that your car will not tell about you and your life, he said.

His watchword, and that of others, which I heard over and over at the session: "Always go for privacy by design. Store only data that is necessary and, more important, have technical limitations to access the data in the first place."

It’s all starting to finally come to fruition, as the DOT’s Walt Fehr said.  This summer, they are completing the fundamentals of the connected vehicle and will be demonstrating how the “elegant solutions” already at use in crash avoidance technology are being extended to overall connected vehicle technology.

“Whatever we come up with here, he said, “any of these processes have to be deployable in a continent-wide scale. That’s why we’re inviting everyone we can think of to collaborate with us as we build out one of the first complete working connected transportation systems using all of these communication media.”
Stay tuned, because this is just starting to get really interesting.

title: New York Auto Show: The Europeans
subTitle: A close look at a close relationship: European automakers and the city that never sleeps.
promoTitle: New York Auto Show: The Europeans
promoTeaserSmall: A close look at a close relationship: European automakers and the city that never sleeps.
promoTeaser: A close look at a close relationship: European automakers and the city that never sleeps.
keywords: New York Auto Show: The Europeans
metaTitle: New York Auto Show: The Europeans - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: New York Auto Show: The Europeans - . See my video tour on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

homepage.subTitle: ny-show-final-homepagel
homepage.title: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: The first auto show in America was staged in New York City in 1900. To this day, it is one of the most heavily attended, which is most surprising because a paltry 23 percent of the population in Manhattan actually own a car.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/9oegDRCdqmY?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Jeff Curry, head of Jaguar marketing, told me, "New York is the center of culture in the U.S. It sets the tone in business and drives the consumer business. So as far as we are concerned, those 23 percent are influencers. It's definitely the center for high-end car buyers."

It's no surprise that those high-end buyers are buying European cars, and it's also no surprise that the New York show is the showplace for the European and British carmakers. They are, after all, just across the pond; New York is their closest port of entry.
Jaguar has had a showroom in New York since 1948 and debuted the classic E-Type to the U.S at the 1961 NY Show.

While New York is Jaguar's second largest U.S. market behind California, it is sister company Land Rover's biggest U.S. market. The first Land Rover dealership in the U.S. was opened in 1987, in New York City. You have to admit, any Land Rover is the perfect choice to handle Manhattan’s potholes on the way to the Met.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: Not one to shy away from a big New York party, Land Rover chose the deck of the legendary Intrepid aircraft carrier—which is now an air, sea, and space museum—to announce both its first global partner, Virgin Galactic, and its futuristic Discovery Vision Concept. It was a stunning juxtaposition to see the Virgin Galactic SpaceShipTwo alongside the futuristic Discovery Vision Concept on the deck of the Intrepid.

At the very least, it was the wildest new-car reveal I’ve ever seen. When I mentioned that to chief designer Gerry McGovern, he said: “Did you see my event at the Battersea Power Station? It was equally amazing. In that one, I literally walked on water!” He smiled at the very idea. Here’s a man with no confidence dilemma.

There were a few whispered comments about the Vision’s front end looking like a Ford Explorer, but the interior was jammed with whimsical future tech suggestions: technology that lets you see the rocks under the car and the depth of water you’re about to ford. It has seven highly configurable seats with backs that can be used as tables. The one-piece tailgate flips up, and a platform flips down, revealing rear-facing "social seating" and a stand-up platform. Armrests double as wheeled luggage, and a panoramic sunroof can change with a hand gesture from a view of the gloomy sky to an augmented-reality sky of your choosing. In fact, all of the Vision's glass is interactive and referred to as “Smart Glass,” a name a little too close to the disconnected Google-Glass-wearing zombies at the party for my taste.
Land Rover made it clear that the Discovery Vision Concept is not a replacement for the current Discovery, but its vision for a future Discovery family.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: I hit the Jag stand to present an Automobile Magazine All-Star trophy to the top dog at Jaguar, Joe Eberhard, for the F-Type roadster. Is there any car more beautiful than that Ian Callum-designed F-Type? Okay, maybe it’s his F-coupe. It looked particularly stunning in red.
Rounding out the Brit brands in New York: Rolls-Royce showed the turbo-6.6-liter V-12, two-tone Ghost II. Not so stunning.
Bentley wowed with a Continental GT Speed convertible, the fastest four-seat convertible ever, with a top speed of 203 mph. That’ll rip your rug off.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: And then there were the Euro exotics: The most anticipated was the Alfa Romeo 4C, signaling that venerable company’s return to America after a very, very long absence. The first Alfa 4C will hit our shores in June in the form of a special Launch Edition. There will only be 500, and most of them are already spoken for.

Tucked behind Maserati (which was celebrating its 100th anniversary with the new Ghibli), and across from the Aston Martin V8 Vantage GT (fresh from its Geneva Motor Show debut), you could find New York’s traditional smattering of supercars.

In quick succession, you could tick off a $2 million Bugatti Veyron Grand Sport Vitesse, a Lotus Evora, a $400,000 Lamborghini Aventador Roadster, and a very rare 273-mph Koenigsegg Agera R from Sweden, of all places.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: Last but certainly far from least, five German car companies are always heavily represented in New York. Mercedes-Benz rolled out its high-roller 577-hp 2015 S63 AMG Coupe.
VW wowed all present with the hot little Golf Sportwagen TDI Motion Concept. That one looked for all the world like it was ready for immediate production. Just add four-wheel drive. Please.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: I also handed out an Automobile Magazine All-Star to the mighty BMW 3 Series, its eighteenth, while gawking at the new 425-horsepower 4 Series convertible.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text:
Porsche also got All-Star statuary for the Boxster and Cayman, and I got champagne. So that was a jolly stand.
 
As we left, Audi, which received its All-Star for the A7, our 2012 Automobile of the Year, was in the midst of tearing apart its press-day display to create an entirely new look for the public, scheduled to mob the place over spring holiday.

The East Coast appreciates the European carmakers as much as they love that show, and I always love to go to New York. With Automobile Magazine awarding four out of its ten All-Stars to European cars this year, it just made it an extra happy place for me to be.
All that's left to do is pick up the chocolate Easter Bunnies from Vosges Chocolate on Spring Street and head for home.

images.caption: Scene from the 2014 New York Auto Show.
Champagne with Porsche's Detlev von Platen as I hand out  Automobile Magazine All-Star awards for the Boxster and Cayman.
With Ludwig Willisch, BMW's U.S. chief. Automobile Magazine All-Star award goes to BMW's 3 Series (again).

pageElements.text: April is Car Care Month, and as part of that, you get to see my mug on the dirt-encrusted window of a car. You're welcome!

Yes, it has come to this: famous "dirty windshield" artist Scott Wade was asked by Sears Auto to immortalize Automobile Magazine, Jean Knows Cars, and me in dirt. ("Immortalize"? Let me get a hose...)

This is a man who grew up in central Texas on a long dirt road. Every car around him was perennially covered by a thin layer of limestone and clay, and he started drawing on the windows because, why not? First with a fingernail, then with a Popsicle stick, then with brushes, and it all leads straight downhill to my face. Thank you, Scott. Thank you very much. My mother will relate to this, I promise you.
You can see some of Scott Wade's other dirt-works on his website, Dirty Car Art, and a quick time-lapse of the work in progress below.

pageElements.embedCode: <object classid='clsid:D27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000' id='ooyalaPlayer' width='0' height='0'codebase='http://fpdownload.macromedia.com/get/flashplayer/current/swflash.cab'><param name='movie' value='https://www.ooyala.com/player.swf' /><param name='bgcolor' value='#000000' /><param name='wmode' value='Transparent'/><param name='allowScriptAccess' value='always' /><param name='allowFullScreen' value='true' /><param name='flashvars' value='embedCode=xub3JobTr4d7rsOkMK9SldQwQudqsc-U&autoplay=0&loop=0&browserPlacement=4&width=0&height=0&wmode=Transparent' /><embed src='https://www.ooyala.com/player.swf' bgcolor='#000000' width='0' height='0' name='ooyalaPlayer' wmode='Transparent' align='middle' play='0' loop='0' allowscriptaccess='always' type='application/x-shockwave-flash' allowfullscreen='true' flashvars='embedCode=xub3JobTr4d7rsOkMK9SldQwQudqsc-U&autoplay=0&loop=0&browserPlacement=4&width=0&height=0&wmode=Transparent' pluginspage='http://www.adobe.com/go/getflashplayer'> </embed></object>

pageElements.text: In case you want to try this at home, Scott suggests using very fine dirt, or, alternatively, whole wheat flour. Cover your car window with a light coat of cooking oil, then use a blow dryer to blow handfuls of dust onto the glass. "With a little finesse, the result is very similar to the real deal," he says. Or drive down a lot of dirt roads until it happens naturally.

Related story:

Your Wiper Blade 5-Point Plan, in honor of Car Care Month

title: BMW Art Car Art Book
subTitle: You've been admiring BMW's Art Cars for years. Now you can put the full set on your coffee table.
promoTeaserSmall: You've been admiring BMW's Art Cars for years. Now you can put the full set on your coffee table.

metaTitle: BMW Art Car Art Book - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: You've been admiring BMW's Art Cars for years. Now you can put the full set on your coffee table. Read about the new book on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: The radiant interior perspective of the fourteenth BMW Art Car struck a persuasive note on the Paramount Pictures studio lot, where image and imagination function in a parallel universe. BMW’s display was part of the second edition of the Paris Photo Show in Los Angeles, an art fair that celebrates the still and moving image.

The car, a 1995 BMW 850CSi, designed by David Hockney, a British native who has spent much of his life in Los Angeles, explores the interior of the automobile. It’s a work that’s about exploration, exposition, and exposure, rather than power and speed. Hockney (shown here) even included imagery of dachshund in the back seat.

The display of the Hockney Art Car (pictured) set the tone for BMW’s ongoing involvement with the Paris Photo Show’s Los Angeles outpost. The fantastical California art fair also served the introduction for the first complete publication to explore the BMW Art Car Series, published by Hatje Cantz, which goes on sale in the U.S. in June.

The acclaimed product designer Carl Gustav Magnusson authored the essay about Hockney’s art car and also attended Paris Photo. “The car is the focus of the story, the content and the canvas,” he writes. “The imagery, flat and Matisse-like, narrates the emotional connection and singular bond between the driver and the vehicle.” Hockney’s work, which often explores travel, seemed like an inviting way to tackle the journey.

The book is encased in a cover designed by Jeff Koons, the most recent artist commissioned to imagine an art car, and features 200 pages that explore the evolution of art and design within the seventeen cars that make up the collection. The book includes an interview with Hervé Poulain, the French racing driver who commissioned Alexander Calder to make the first car, which he went on to drive at the 1975 edition of the 24 Hours of Le Mans.
“I wanted art—reflecting and learning about, the act of losing myself in it—and motorsport to be the purpose of my life,” Poulain says.

Along with stunning photography of the Art Cars, scholars and journalists reflect on the relationship between the automobile and the artists, who include Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol, Jenny Holzer, and Roy Lichtenstein.

“What will continue to maintain the significance of this series in the future is the constantly changing perception of the interplay between design and art,” writes Thomas Girst, who heads up BMW Group Culture Engagement.

“At the time, Calder’s BMW 3.0 CSL [pictured] was the latest thing in innovative engineering technology, but almost forty years later, the sports car seems like an antiquated time traveler from the 1970s.”
To order the book: Go to Amazon.com, where preorders are being taken here prior to the June 30 U.S. release date. Price: $37.21.
To look at the Art Cars online: Go to BMW's Museum website, where you can see images and video here.
Images courtesy of Hatje Cantz and BMW AG

The Koons BMW Art Car February 12, 2014

Warhol's BMW M1 Art Car Visits L.A. May 8, 2013

title: Google, Where's My Car?
subTitle: Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice!
promoTeaserSmall: Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice!
promoTeaser: Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice!
metaDescription: Google, Where's My Car? Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice! Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Hey, Android users! All the fun is not reserved for iPhone types. As of its latest update out this week, Google Now, an Android app, can find your car for you.

If you've ever forgotten quite where you left the car—say you parked in haste to get to a concert or an urban ballpark, and you realize after the event that you hadn't been attentive enough to your surroundings—this will be a very welcome assist.

Basically, Google uses your smartphone's sensors to recognize that you were inside a moving vehicle and now you aren't. So, as Google explains, "you may see parking location cards even if you didn't park your car," for example when you get out of a taxi or someone else's car, or when you get off a bus or train. But no big deal, since what counts is that you will see the location cards when you did park your car.

Google Now will display an indicator that shows approximately where your car is parked. History of your previous parks can be found by touching Previous Locations. In answer to your next question, nobody else can see this location information but you, on your own phone, Google assures us.
Just set your main mode of transportation to driving in Google Now, and watch the magic happen.

Another Cool Thing It Can Do: Commute Communication

You can turn on a Commute Sharing feature in Google Now that will update people you choose about your progress to and from work via Google +.

Just enable location sharing, include those people, and they'll be notified when you have left work and when you get home. Oddly, I would love to know this about other people, like my kids, but I would be less excited about having them know it about me. Character flaw? But I appreciate the security aspect of it.
Top photo: JaysonPhotography/iStock/Thinkstock

pageElements.text: The ascension of Mark Fields to president and CEO of Ford should be a surprise to no one. He has been so successful, is so qualified to do this job, and has the chops to do it.

Mark Fields is the youngest son of Elinor and the late Jerry Fields. The Fields didn’t suffer fools gladly. Their sons were hardworking college graduates and achievers, Mark probably being the biggest achiever of all because he was the youngest. He followed closely in the footsteps of his older brothers. They all worked at the same clothing store in high school and he followed them to Rutgers. But he took a sharp westward turn toward Detroit after his Harvard MBA.

At Ford, he moved very quickly through the ranks. He was identified early as a mover and shaker. At a brash age of thirty-seven in 1998, he was dispatched to Japan to get Mazda back on track, and once he accomplished that, he was sent to Europe in 2002 to get the Premier Automotive Group in order.

His time in Europe was an education in the highly toxic Ford executive culture of the time, which I’ve always called The Medicis Meet the Machiavellis. You had to watch your back if you were running anything at Ford. The family was always meddling (it being their company and all), and the executive ranks were full of snakes in the grass. When Bill Ford took over, the knives-to-knives corporate culture is undoubtedly one of the things that drove him to the outside to find Alan Mulally at Boeing and bring him to Dearborn to straighten things out.

By then, Mark was back at the mother ship and in the midst of a personal PR crisis. He had been named President of the Americas and, as part of his contract, he was given travel home to his family in Miami on weekends. A local Detroit investigative reporter tracked him getting on the corporate plane and flying to Miami and did a series of exposes about how he was wasting Ford’s money. Ford’s PR didn’t handle it very well. Instead of just nipping it in the bud, it got worse and worse and put his name on the map in a bad way.
So, when Mulally (who was once described by a top exec as having "great steely balls" behind his gosh shucks sunny smile) showed up and started to clean up, nobody expected Fields to live long.

The typical executive behavior pre-Mulally was to pick away at each other and see who could out-bully whom. Word came back from an early corporate meeting that Mulally had laid down the law and told everyone how it was gonna be: all for one and one for all, and nothing but the Way Forward and the blue oval and One Ford, and he would absolutely tolerate none of the bad behavior that had been going on.

A high-level executive vice-president who was at the table told me about an important moment in the Mulally/Fields relationship. It was an early roundtable meeting with the top execs where chief financial officer Don LeClair and Fields were going at it. Mulally, with a very smiley face, said, “Hey, guys, remember how we all agreed that we could disagree without being nasty to each other, we’d all get along? Well, if you guys can’t do that” (and his voice went icy), “I’ll find two guys that can.” Shortly thereafter, Don Leclair was gone with a thank you for his years of faithful service, and Mark Fields got religion in a big way.

Mulally had set up a weekly meeting in which every person in the room was in charge of one part of the business, and all the plans and goals were on a big chart. The progress of each part of the goal was identified with green dots, yellow dots, or red dots, and during the Thursday meeting each person would stand up and give a report about all the pieces of their part of the business, and if there was a yellow or red dot, they would ask people in the room for help. For a while, it was nothing but green dots, green dots, green dots, which made Mulally crazy because he knew it wasn’t real.

Mark Fields was the first executive to bring a chart to the meeting with a red dot on it. To tell the roomful of your fiercely competitive peers that you’re having a hard time, you’re behind, and part of your project is in danger of failing—to ask for help—was an act of bravery that made a huge impression on Mulally.

From then to now, I have never seen Fields fail or put a foot wrong. I have seen his cockiness tempered, replaced by a more admirable self-confidence. He is honest, self-effacing, and even self-deprecating. He has shown a great sense of humor, even in the wake of the entire press corps making fun of his clearly mullet-style haircut.

The real turning point for me was in 2008, when he invited me to meet his mom before the New York Auto Show, where I watched him shed probably five years for every hour we were with his mother. By the time we left he was about sixteen years old.

Related story:

Mark Fields's Mom and Me May 5, 2014, from the October 2008 issue of Automobile Magazine

An interesting side note is that he is the first Jewish CEO at Ford, a company founded by a notorious anti-Semite. If there’s any question about the relevance of this milestone, look no further than the fact that there are people in the year 2014 who still refuse to consider a Ford because of the founder’s anti-Semitism 100 years ago.

The success of Mark Fields depends on all the usual factors—good product with smooth roll-outs, a strengthened presence in Europe, a reasoned and successful expansion into Asia, in addition to being able to make the Lincoln brand a success.  It also has two other important factors: whether the Ford family continues to keep the drama down (they’ve been exceptionally well behaved for the past decade) and whether he’ll able to channel Mulally’s energy and keep the egos in check. At some level, all the old conflicts are probably still simmering. Can he maintain the fragile peace among the traditional warring factions at the top of the Ford food chain? And when the doodoo hits the fan, as it always does, can he keep the Way Forward plan going forward?

title: Miata's Proud Parents
subTitle: A chat with the fathers of the Mazda Miata.
promoTeaserSmall: A chat with the fathers of the Mazda Miata.
promoTeaser: A chat with the fathers of the Mazda Miata.
metaDescription: The Fathers of the Mazda MX-5 Miata: Interviews with three men who are integral to the car's history. See them on JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Miata and I go all the way back to the late Eighties, when I was invited by Mazda chairman Kenichi Yamamoto to have the very first journalist test drive of a pre-production prototype at the Miyoshi Proving Ground. This was not a press trip. We had bonded in the early Eighties over our love of baseball: me the Detroit Tigers, him the Hiroshima Carp, for which Mazda was the major sponsor. In fact, in 1984, the year the Tigers won the World Series, the Carp won the Japan Series. I just happened to be in Hiroshima that night, and all the clubs and bars were giving away free sake. There were a lot of salarymen in three-piece suits lying drunk in the gutters of Hiroshima that night.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/U8Vpd4Leia4?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
But I digress.

Mr. Yamamoto wanted to know what I thought of this new roadster from Mazda, a completely new kind of car for them. It was outstanding. It was unbelievable. The simplest way to describe it was a Lotus Elan that didn't break and had a high-tech suspension. It was absolutely perfect in concept for the time, and I didn't want to get out of it; I drove around and around, I drove engineers around, and when I was done driving, I was taken into a room at the track, and all the engineers for the various components filed in and began to ask me questions about it. Eventually I had to beg them to stop. "There's nothing left in my brain," I said.
When the first cars came to the States, I wrote the story for Automobile Magazine. It was so fantastic that it inspired us to name it our first Automobile of the Year.

When the first cars came to the States, I wrote the story for Automobile Magazine. It was such a fantastic car, it inspired us to name it our first Automobile of the Year, despite the fact that Motor Trend's Car of the Year was such a strong franchise that we had resisted doing this for the first four years of the magazine.

image.altText: Jean Jennings in Mazda MX 5 Miata

pageElements.text: In 2004, my husband gave me a very special Mazdaspeed Miata for my birthday. If it hadn't been this turbocharged Miata, I would have called him a crazy man for buying the editor of a car magazine a car, but the Miata is so magic, of all the hundreds upon hundreds of cars I have driven, that's one car I wanted to own.

So here it is the twenty-fifth anniversary of that very special car, and we are on the verge of seeing the first brand-new Miata from the ground up since that car came into existence in 1989. Mazda threw a little champagne celebration at the New York Auto Show, gathering there the three original 1989 Chicago Auto Show cars: the red, white, and blue cars you see here and in this video, and every special one-off Miata model they could get their hands on. It was a perfect chance to talk to the "fathers" of the Miata: the brilliant Bob Hall, who had the original idea and convinced Mazda to build it, and its first designer, Tom Matano, who came from BMW to the Miata project at Mazda and sketched the first car. Mazda's current head of design, Derek Jenkins, was also there and had a few things to say about what it was like to be the guy in charge of redesigning the icon.

To see the full interviews, click here:

Bob Hall

Tom Matano

Derek Jenkins

title: Land Speed Record Girl
subTitle: Kaylin Stewart is 15 going on 220. Her dream comes true at the Bonneville Salt Flats in August.
promoTeaserSmall: Kaylin Stewart is 15 going on 220. Her dream comes true at the Bonneville Salt Flats in August.
promoTeaser: Kaylin Stewart is 15 going on 220. Her dream comes true at the Bonneville Salt Flats in August.
metaKeywords: Dry Lakes Racing Hall of Fame
metaDescription: Kaylin Stewart is 15 going on 220. Her dream comes true at the Bonneville Salt Flats in August. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: When she was four years old, Kaylin Stewart watched her father, Tom, set a land speed record at the Bonneville Salt Flats, in Utah, and resolved to race on the salt as well.

A few weeks from now, upon celebrating her sixteenth birthday, Kaylin will begin her quest to become the youngest driver ever to join the 200 MPH Club. Last year, just two weeks after turning sixteen, Madeline Carlson raced a roadster 147.365 mph on Bonneville’s three-mile short course, becoming the youngest to set a class record. Bill Lattin was seventeen years old in 1987 when he bettered a class record at 212.040 mph, and he remains the youngest to have joined the club.
When Bonneville Speed Week begins on August 9, she will attempt to better the existing mark of 219.509 mph in the B-Blown Modified Pickup class.
Kaylin’s project is more ambitious; just breaking the 200-mph barrier won’t be enough.

To gain membership in the "2 Club" and unseat Lattin, she must eclipse a class record above 200 mph. So when Bonneville Speed Week begins on August 9, she will attempt to better the existing mark of 219.509 mph in the B-Blown Modified Pickup class.
At the moment, Kaylin doesn’t even have a driver’s license.

Never mind that. Not only is she set to attempt the feat that has been achieved by 750 land speed racers over the decades, with just twenty-four women among them, but she is also making a documentary film about it. She has already interviewed several of the “salt sisters”—those women in the 2 Club—on camera. With co-producer Harry Pallenberg now aboard, footage of her own record attempt will be mixed with those interviews for a documentary, Chasing 200, which is planned for release in the summer of 2015.

“After I found out I couldn’t be a cat when I grew up, that’s when I decided I wanted to be a producer-director,” says the high school sophomore from Arroyo Grande, California. She plans to study film production at Chapman University in the Los Angeles area.

Kaylin, who is five feet nine inches tall, has already been fitted for her racing seat in the Jesel Land Speed Team’s 2005 Dodge Ram 1500 crew cab pickup, which holds seven class records and has achieved 262.118 mph on the salt. Under the Ram’s hood, a fearsome twin-turbocharged 385-cubic-inch V-8 produces 2,100 horsepower. This engine is matched with a five-speed manual transmission. Gears are shifted by pressing a button on the steering wheel, releasing a blast of pressurized air that stimulates electromechanical actuation within the gearbox.

Team owner Wayne Jesel, whose family business manufactures valvetrain components for high-performance engines, is an acquaintance of the Stewarts. At the Dry Lakes Racing Hall of Fame banquet in January 2013, Kaylin told him about her dream of being the youngest member of the 2 Club. She mentioned that the truck’s picture hung in her room at home.
“Well, why don’t you just drive the truck at Speed Week next year, when you turn sixteen?” she remembers Jesel saying.
“I don’t think I stopped smiling for a week,” Kaylin says. She helped out on Jesel’s team last August.

Before she can drive during Speed Week, she must obtain a regular driver’s license and then a competition license. The process starts on her birthday, July 10, when she goes to the Department of Motor Vehicles for the state’s test. After passing, she will immediately head for Bonneville, where the Utah Salt Flats Racing Association holds a “test and tune” meet from July 11 to 13. Kaylin will strap herself in a converted Chevrolet stock car, offered by a friend of Jesel’s, for a series of progressively faster runs. (Motorcycle racer Valerie Thompson will also do license qualifying in the car.) These sessions will ultimately result in Kaylin’s receiving a “B” license for 200-mph-plus racing.
She told me it’s “incredible” to have people show this much confidence in her. “It’s terrifying, but it’s incredible.”

In August, she will return to Bonneville for Speed Week. Record attempts are staged over six miles of the salt-covered ancient lake bed. The first two miles are the acceleration zone. Three timed one-mile sections follow. Then the driver releases the parachute that helps her slow over the sixth mile before turning off the course. One of the biggest challenges during the run is to keep the driven wheels from spinning when powering across the salt. It isn’t enough to surpass the established record just once. A second run must be made on the following day, and the average of the two top speeds is used for scoring.

Last Saturday, I caught up with the Stewarts at El Mirage dry lake near Victorville, California. The Southern California Timing Association, which sanctions land speed racing here and at Bonneville, was holding its season-opening meet. With Kaylin’s eleven-year-old brother, Riley, they had driven their pickup about five hours after school on Friday in order to help out Robbie Cohn with his F-Classic Gas coupe. Cohn’s car is the near twin of the 1978 Chevrolet Monza that Tom raced to 214.160 mph in 2002.

After arriving at El Mirage, Riley and Kaylin slept in back of the truck while Tom, a machinist at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant on California’s coast, climbed into a tent on a platform. Cohn’s car had already made one run when I caught up with them.

Marveling at the scene, with various characters and some of the most bizarre and beautiful cars and motorcycles on the planet, I asked if Kaylin’s fellow students at Central Coast New Technical High School have any concept of what she is doing. She fixed her blue eyes on me and gestured often with her hands when saying the boys think her racing is “cool because of the cars” but girls are more skeptical, asking why she would “want to spend a week getting dirty and sweaty.”

El Mirage is an off-highway vehicle area administered by the federal Bureau of Land Management. For $15, you can enter the lakebed and do your thing. Kaylin, who has a driver’s permit, has already driven here. In January, while helping some friends test a land-speed car, Tom coned off a course, and Kaylin, behind the wheel of their Hyundai Sonata, made a dozen or so runs over the smooth dirt at speeds between 80 and 100 mph. “It was just to get the feeling of running down the course with cones and making safety turn-outs,” Tom says.

Meanwhile, as Kaylin continues explaining about her desire to race and how she decided to make the movie, her polished deadpan wit is often in evidence. For example, she says her mother has imposed a strict rule against her going over 275 mph until she’s eighteen.
“But I can always say, ‘I didn’t know how fast I was going. There’s no speedometer!’”

Much of her poise comes from extensive acting experience. She says she has “gone on a hundred auditions and been in a million plays, and I get nervous every time I’m about to go onstage or into the audition room.” But there is also the barrel racing. “When I race a horse, before I make a run, I visualize everything I’m going to do.” http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1801553/

Tom thinks the latter experience will pay dividends on the salt. “It helps a lot,” he says. “I can see the focus and the nerves. She has to control the horse and be timely. When it’s your turn to go, you have to be the show and turn it on.” The loud music in the arena, the yelling of her coach--she doesn’t remember any of that afterward, he says.
Kaylin's polished deadpan wit is often in evidence. For example, she says her mother has imposed a strict rule against her going over 275 mph until she’s eighteen.

Later I call up Kaylin's mother, Jessica, who has stayed behind on the family’s ten-acre ranch to manage the opening of the movie’s Indiegogo fundraising campaign. (It’s off to a slow start.) She is prepared for the obvious question. “We have people tell us we’re crazy all the time,” she says. “We’re driven by that mama bear instinct. Your gut reaction is, ‘How can you let her do something like that?’”

Like Tom, she expresses confidence in the Jesel team’s attention to detail and emphasis on safety. She considers the upside. Kaylin, she says, will be better prepared for life than 90 percent of her classmates.

And even without taking the philosophical view, Jessica allows there’s a certain inevitable quality to it all, especially when considering Kaylin’s precocity. “She was talking in full sentences when she was a year old. She’s never had a fear in her life. She rode in the push truck when she was an infant. She’s talked about it since she was six. She was going to drive like Daddy.”
In August, Kaylin might drive faster than Daddy.
Chasing 200 Trailer from Sunny & Mild Media on Vimeo.

title: Scout Navigation App
subTitle: Looking for a navigation solution that's easy and socially interactive? Our review of the free app.
promoTeaserSmall: Looking for a navigation solution that's easy and socially interactive? Our review of the free app.
promoTeaser: Looking for a navigation solution that's easy and socially interactive? Our review of the free app.
metaDescription: Looking for a navigation solution? Here's a free app you should check out. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Have you jumped on the GPS bandwagon? If you don't have an in-car navigation system yet and are relying on your smartphone, or if you haven't yet found a nav solution that you're happy with, the Scout app provides a painless way to move into and through the twenty-first century.

The free application was created by Telenav, the first company to bring GPS to phones (way back in the Nextel days) and is so easy to use that even a novice like myself found I could just pick it up and start navigating. The clear, bright orange and gray graphics, bold lettering, and well-placed features immediately trumped the interface of the map features that come with my iPhone.

Scout’s improvements recognize we are creatures of habit, as well as social animals, so the app helps you keep track of your favorite haunts with Likes or find yesterday’s locations in Recents. A super convenient feature is the ability to quickly share your ETA, taking real-time traffic into account, right from the map, so you can let your spouse know via text message what route you're taking and when to expect you for dinner. Or select an eatery from the interactive dashboard and easily send a link via text, email, Facebook, or Twitter that provides a map to that location so your friends know exactly where to meet up.

For searches, I preferred using the voice command feature as opposed to typing in my destination. Scout seems to understand my Midwestern English a lot better than Siri.  To activate it, you just say, “Hey Scout,” and then ask it to find whatever destination you are looking for. The list of matching choices that appears is very readable.  Because this is a free app, your list of search results starts with a “relevant ad,” but that’s easy to ignore.  Then you tap the car icon alongside your choice, and a map pops up with three different route choices and their associated mileage. Tap your choice, tap Go, and you are on your way.

Sooner Heath of Telenav told me that the app was designed to reduce the number of taps you need to execute a task. “Users were zooming out an average of four times and zooming in four times to get from the turn-by-turn view to the whole-route view.” So they created a shortcut that toggles between those two views in two taps.

Other time savers appear when you tap the Explore icon to find the most commonly searched for destinations like Coffee, Restaurants, Gas, or ATMs. Because Scout displays search results with not only proximity but popularity in mind, sometimes the closest option is not what you’ll see first. For instance, when I searched generally for “grocery stores,” the first thing to appear was a megastore over a mile away, while the closest store, a Whole Foods, didn’t even show up. When I asked Scout to find Whole Foods, both local locations did appear. So, if you know exactly what you want, make your search request specific.

Telenav predicts some of us will soon see an automotive-grade version of Scout, called Scout for Cars, built into our cars’ infotainment systems and able to connect seamlessly with Scout on our smartphones. Telenav technology is already present in many Ford vehicles. For the future, Telenav says, the look of Scout for Cars will likely be customized to the specifications of carmakers that adopt Scout technology. Those systems should still retain Scout’s signature simple interface and expand on personalized features to include predictive routing and search results that take your historical preferences into account.

To Get the App

Scout app for iOS

Scout app for Windows Phone

title: Indianapolis 500: 10 Fun Facts
subTitle: 10 things you'll love to find out about the greatest spectacle in racing.
promoTeaserSmall: 10 things you'll love to find out about the greatest spectacle in racing.
promoTeaser: 10 things you'll love to find out about the greatest spectacle in racing.
metaDescription: 10 things you'll love to find out about the greatest spectacle in racing. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

image.altText: Jeff Gordon Indy Pace Car Corvette

pageElements.text: Have you ever been to the Indy 500? That's OK; watching it on TV is good, even if not quite the same as being in the middle of the action. The 99th running of the legendary race happens on Sunday, May 24, on ABC. The green flag goes down at 12:00 noon Eastern time, and NASCAR stock-car racing star Jeff Gordon heads out to kick off the action in the pace car, a Chevrolet Corvette Z06. While you wait, here are ten things you may not have known, but ought to.

1. This year is the first Indy 500 in thirty-seven years without Jim Nabors (of Andy Griffith Show and Gomer Pyle fame) singing "Back Home Again in Indiana" just before the race. (You can watch his final rendition from 2014 on YouTube.) It took ten people to replace him: the a cappella group Straight No Chaser, alumni of Indiana University, will do the honors this year.

2. Nine women have competed in the Indianapolis 500. A full list of their accomplishments is on the Indianapolis Motor Speedway website. This year, Pippa Mann will compete in her fourth Indy. She's racing on behalf, not only of women, but of the Susan G. Komen anti-breast-cancer organization. Go to her Indiegogo page and pledge a donation in exchange for Pippa-related souvenirs. Also in the starting lineup: Simona de Silvestro in the #29 Dale Coyne Racing Honda, in her fifth Indianapolis 500 start.

3. There are 29 bars dedicated specifically to margaritas and bloody Marys at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Let it not be said that Indy fans drink only that, however. They also consume 145,000 gallons of beer and 24,000 gallons of Coca-Cola products, and they put 475 gallons of ketchup on the 8,000 pounds of pork fritters and ten tons of Track Fries, among other products served during the event.

4. The first Indy 500 champion drove something known as a Marmon Wasp. The bright-yellow, wasp-tailed racer won at an average speed of 74.6 mph. The driver was Ray Harroun, and the year was 1911. The luminous yellow car made it onto a commemorative U.S. Postal Service stamp in 2011 for the centennial. (This year is only the 99th running because the action stopped during both World War I and World War II.)

5. It’s harder than you think to understand how much Indy drivers get paid. The Indianapolis Star noted this week that it’s nothing like other major-league sports. With no driver’s union, no collective bargaining agreements, and no minimum salaries—or salary caps—every driver pretty much gets a different deal from every other driver. Some of the top drivers have guaranteed salaries, while others get percentages. Three-time Indy 500 winner (and Dancing with the Stars champion) Helio Castroneves was revealed, because of a court case, to have been paid $6 million from 2000-02 by the Penske racing group, but that, apparently, is far more than most earn. The paper suggests $1.5 million a year is the top end, while many others make low to middle six figures.

6. An INDYCAR Series car could run upside down. It generates 5,000 pounds of downforce when going 220 mph. Since the cars weigh only 1,575 pounds, this amount of downforce would, in fact, allow the car to run upside down if that speed is maintained, according to the INDYCAR people. Let's see that!

image.altText: Janes Addiction Carb Day Credit Karl Zemlin
image.caption: photo: Karl Zemlin

pageElements.text: 7. There are no more Carbs, but there's still a Carburetion Day; the racing cars have been fuel injected, not carbureted, since the Sixties. Held the Friday before the race, which is May 22 this year, Carb Day is the last day of on-track practice. There are festivities, too: Jane’s Addiction is among the bands performing that night.

8. What do they do with all that unused real estate on the back stretch? Solar power, that’s what. Last July, the largest solar farm at any sporting facility in the world opened for business. It makes solar energy for Indianapolis Power and Light, stretching over 68 acres and generating enough power for up to 2,700 homes.

9. The Indy 500 might be the most tradition-laden event in racing. Among those traditions is the annual parade on the Saturday before the big day. (You can watch it on the NBC Sports network.) This year’s grand marshal is 2008 Olympic gymnastics gold medalist Nastia Liukin, for some reason. Among other unexpected Grand Marshals in the parade’s fifty-eight-year history: Shirley MacLaine (1958); Jimmy Stewart (1965); the ambassadors of Peru, Bolivia, and Ecuador (1968); Anderson Cooper (2011); and Mickey Mouse (1974, 1985, and, with Minnie, 1992).

10. The speedway is the world’s largest spectator sports venue, with 250,000 permanent seats. The Roman Colosseum, Yankee Stadium, the White House, Vatican City, the Taj Mahal, the Rose Bowl, and Churchill Downs fit inside the oval with room to spare. Room for you, perhaps.

title: 2015 Audi A3 2.0T Quattro S Tronic
subTitle: As much a great driver's car as the Audi Coupe GT I once had. All that, plus 4G LTE connectivity.
promoTeaserSmall: As much a great driver's car as the Audi Coupe GT I once had. All that, plus 4G LTE connectivity.
promoTeaser: As much a great driver's car as the Audi Coupe GT I once had. All that, plus 4G LTE connectivity.
metaTitle: 2015 Audi A3 2.0T Quattro S Tronic - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: As much a great driver's car as the Audi Coupe GT I once had. All that, plus 4G LTE connectivity.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Y5OCMyDbUvg?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Vital Stats

Base price: $33,795 (includes destination charge)
This car's price: $36,645 (includes destination charge)
EPA fuel economy: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 220 horsepower, 228 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed S tronic dual-clutch automatic with Audi quattro all-wheel drive
Safety features: Eight airbags, including driver and front passenger knee bags; not yet tested by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; named a Top Safety Pick + by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. This award applies to the 2015 Audi A3 with the optional Advanced Technology package ($1,400), not on the model we tested, which includes active lane assist, Audi pre sense front crash protection, and adaptive cruise control
Tech features: Quattro all-wheel drive; Audi MMI Navigation Plus ($1,900) includes CD/DVD player, navigation system with voice control, Audi MMI Touch, and color driver information display; Cold Weather package ($500) includes heated front seats and exterior mirrors and heated windshield washer nozzles; Aluminum Style package ($450) includes aluminum interior trim and window surrounds; Audi music interface with iPod cable ($350)
Chief competitors: 2014 Acura ILX (base price $27,885), 2014 BMW 320i (base price $33,675), 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA250 (base price $30,825); all prices include destination charges

Key Points:

• There's a huge rivalry between the 2015 Audi A3 and the 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA250. the tussle is over bringing in younger buyers to the brand, which both Audi and Mercedes consider essential.
• Impressive standard features on the A3 include a panoramic sunroof, Bluetooth, LED daytime running lights, leather seats and leather-wrapped steering wheel, and bi-xenon headlights.
• The line will be beefed up even further in the coming months with models including the A3 TDI clean diesel and the Audi A3 Sportback e-tron plug-in hybrid.

• The A3 is a safety leader, offering several advanced tech features that are new to the entry-luxury segment, including the standard pre sense basic system that detects when an emergency maneuver is being made and prepares the car and its occupant restraint systems in advance of a possible crash.

• The 2015 A3 is the first Audi model to earn a Top Safety Pick or Top Safety Pick + award and the first to earn a Good or Acceptable rating in the small overlap front crash test by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
• Connectivity is a major theme, especially as cars evolve into data centers on wheels. The A3 leads the pack.

• The A3 gets 4G LTE high-speed wireless connectivity through Audi Connect. Simply put, when passengers connect their mobile devices to the hot spot integrated into the A3, they can surf the Web independently of each other. For example, one can participate in a video conference while another watches a video. Audi Connect is standard on the top-end Prestige model, which costs $8,450 more than the base Premium. The midrange Premium Plus gets Audi Connect as part of a $2,600 MM Navigation plus package.
• Another feature found in the MMI Navigation plus package is a handwriting recognition system. The driver can trace letters on top of the controller knob (MMI) for navigation and music searches.
• Facebook and Twitter are “vehicle friendly,” with a text-to-speech function.
• Audi and AT&T have hooked up on two data plan options: $99 for six months and 5 GB, or $499 for thirty months and 30 GB. That works out to about $16.50 a month after a free six-month trial period.

pageElements.text:
2015 Hyundai Genesis RWD 3.8

Base price: $38,950, inc. $950 destination charge
Price as tested: $38,950, including $950 destination charge. This is the base model with no options. Mid-level 2015 Hyundai Genesis 3.8 AWD starts at $41,450, including shipping. The top-of-the-line 2015 Hyundai Genesis 5.0 RWD starts at $52,450, including shipping. Note the jump to over $50K for the top-of-the-line model.
Genesis prices are creeping up. The base 2014 Hyundai Genesis starts at $36,120, inc. $920 destination charge. The top-of-the-line 2014 Hyundai Genesis R-Spec starts at $48,320, inc. shipping.
Fuel economy: 18 city/29 highway (311-hp 3.8-liter V6 engine; eight-speed automatic transmission)
Note: Worse fuel economy with new AWD model. 16 city/25 highway, according to EPA.
Safety: Not yet rated by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; major coup in testing by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The redesigned Genesis earned the Top Safety Pick+ award, scoring Good ratings in all IIHS crash tests and a Superior rating for front crash protection
The Genesis is one of only three large luxury cars to earn this award for 2014. The other two vehicles are the 2014 Acura RLX with the optional front crash prevention system and the 2014 Volvo S80
The IIHS said the Genesis earned the superior rating because of the automatic braking capabilities (previews autonomous driving) on the optional front crash prevention system. The system is being offered for the first time on the 2015 model.
Automatic Emergency Braking is part of a $3,500 3.8L Technology Package. The AEB system will initiate braking if it senses a car approaching at an unsafe speed.
Standard safety features on 2015 Genesis include nine airbags, inc. driver’s knee airbag, electronic stability control and anti-whiplash head restraints.
Chief competitors: 2014 Mercedes-Benz E-Class (base price $53,125, inc. $925 destination charge); 2014 BMW 528i (base price $50,425, inc. $925 destination charge); 2014 Cadillac CTS (base price $46,025, inc. $925 destination charge)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Theqt_rwsMM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points:

This is a major redesign of the Genesis, replacing the first version that bowed in 2009. Is this a true luxury contender? Now features a “statement” grille, contours patterned after the Audi A7 and BMW 5 Series.
It's roughly the same size as outgoing model, but many upgrades, including the first use of an AWD system in a Hyundai sedan. Where were you when we had two feet of snow on the ground?

Plus, lots of stuff you don’t see on the competition:
1)	Automatic trunk opening system that will pop the trunk if you stand next to the car for three seconds with the key in your pocket. Competitors have leg kick system. Hyundai allows you to keep both feet on ground with its system.

2)	Smartphone app that can remind you to get service or start the car remotely if it’s cold. Temperature outside vehicle is determined via Zip code prior to estimated departure time. User will receive phone notification is temp is above or below default level.
3) There is also an app that will interface with Google Glass if you use the wearable computer. Functions include remote vehicle start, remote Find My Car, call roadside assistance.

title: 2016 Cadillac ATS-V: L.A. Auto Show
subTitle: Sweet to look at, to sit in, to drive. Or it will be, when it comes out in the spring.
promoTeaserSmall: Sweet to look at, to sit in, to drive. Or it will be, when it comes out in the spring.
promoTeaser: Sweet to look at, to sit in, to drive. Or it will be, when it comes out in the spring.
metaDescription: Sweet to look at, to sit in, to drive. Or it will be, when it comes out in the spring.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: The Cadillac ATS is sweet to look at, to sit in, and to drive.
But more power wouldn’t hurt.

At the Los Angeles Auto Show, Cadillac gave us the ATS-V coupe and sedan, which are packing new heft under the hood. Or rather, generating 455 horsepower makes this twin-turbocharged V-6 the stoutest six-cylinder engine in any small sedan.

As Cadillac’s new president, Johan de Nysschen, said, it’s aimed at aficionados. They will have their choice between an eight-speed automatic transmission or an advanced six-speed manual gearbox that features no-lift shifting when the car is shrieking from 0 to 60 mph in just 3.9 seconds.

You know it’s the ATS-V when you see the 18-inch forged alloy wheels, which are lightweight but strong. (The Michelin Pilot tires were exclusively developed for the V.) You’ll also note vented bodywork, which de Nysschen assured is “functionally developed.” Third-generation Magnetic Ride Control intelligently modulates ride and handling responses, and killer Brembo brakes stop the car from its 189-mph top speed.
For those special track days, the ATS-V records high-definition video, then overlays lap times and other data for playback. How cool is that?

The midsize CTS-V has developed a big following over the years, and it’s easy to foresee the same happening with the ATS-V after it arrives in showrooms next spring. We can hardly wait to test it, and when they’re handing out the keys, we’re grabbing one for a coupe.

More to Read:

Jean's Driveway: 2015 Cadillac ATS Coupe, a designer walkaround with Bob Boniface (video)

title: Mercedes-Maybach S600
subTitle: The most fabulous new member of the S-Class family brings back the Maybach name.
promoTeaserSmall: The most fabulous new member of the S-Class family brings back the Maybach name.
promoTeaser: The most fabulous new member of the S-Class family brings back the Maybach name.
metaDescription: The most fabulous new member of the S-Class family brings back the Maybach name.
