pageElements.text: Seek huge and pillowy, and you’re usually led to the back of the home goods store, just beyond oversized bedding. But at the Los Angeles Auto Show, we wafted over to the presentation of the 2016 Mercedes-Maybach S600, which goes on sale in April. This is, Mercedes assures, "the world's quietest production sedan" and the most ultraluxurious member of the S-Class family.

There’s less Benz in this Mercedes and more cushion—as found in the executive rear seating area. The Maybach name invokes the marque that created limousines before World War II. In recent years, Mercedes’s parent company, Daimler-Benz, failed with a separate Maybach brand, but in typically stubborn German fashion, it is bringing back the glory in this new way. Mercedes-Maybach will be a sub-brand selling ultra-exclusive luxury cars "for customers for whom status is important."

Based on the Mercedes-Benz S-Class sedan, the Mercedes-Maybach S600 is powered by a twin-turbocharged 6.0-liter V-12 engine making 523 horsepower. Its force is so great, it could pull any of L.A.’s Art Deco buildings through a black hole into the postmodern era.

How large is it? At 214.6 inches, it’s shorter than a dual-cab Chevrolet pickup but longer than two Smart cars put end to end. The extra 8.1 inches it has over the mundane S-Class sedan (actually, one of the world’s greatest cars) goes into the back seat, where the Chinese ruling class and lucky kids from Beverly Hills do much of their business.

The woody, leathery cabin will be infused with its own exclusive Agarwood fragrance and cluttered with bubbles from the two silver-plated champagne flutes. This car doesn’t live behind a garage door. It sweeps from behind Door Number Three on Let’s Make a Deal and delivers you to your fantastic domain, whether it’s in Napa Valley or comes from cyberspace.

images.caption: Interior of Mercedes-Maybach S600 offers over-the-top but still understated luxury.
Mercedes-Maybach S600's executive seating is ultra-adjustable, with energizing massage based on hot stone principles.
Mercedes-Maybach S600 will go on sale in the U.S. and China at the same time, April 2015.

title: Lexus LF-C2 Concept: L.A. Auto Show
subTitle: The future is this bright at Lexus; concept previews a future RC convertible.
promoTitle: Lexus LF-C2 Concept: L.A. Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: The future is this bright at Lexus as concept previews a future RC convertible.
promoTeaser: The future is this bright at Lexus as concept previews a future RC convertible.
keywords: Lexus LF-C2 Concept: L.A. Auto Show
metaTitle: Lexus LF-C2 Concept: L.A. Auto Show
metaDescription: The future is this bright at Lexus as concept previews a future RC convertible.

pageElements.text: With the Lexus LF-C2 Concept, unveiled at the Los Angeles Auto Show this week, the upscale Toyota brand proved it's in touch with the reason it exists: to provide us with an ethereal level of indulgence. This concept roadster is not likely to be the favorite of the sports-car purist, but l applaud Lexus's ambition to differentiate itself from the more mainstream-looking cars they make at Toyota.

That assertiveness is captured in the LF-C2 Concept, which gleamed in a multi-layer yellow paint treatment on the show floor. The color is polarizing in more ways than one, but I think it's just right for a show car, the better to show off the LF-C2's cool white-and-gray leather interior. There's no roof on this concept, giving a clear view of the interior with its central video monitor, remote touchpad on the center console, and old-school analog clock.
The LF-C2 concept previews what's expected to be a convertible version of the Lexus RC coupe.

Close your eyes and go to your happy place. You know, the one with a gleaming yellow sun presiding over a tree-lined, winding road in the southern French countryside. You're in a 2+2 roadster, and you don't know which part of that you enjoy most: the bursts of speed your roadster handles with aplomb, or the looks you get from envious passers-by when they get a glimpse of you in that luxurious leather interior when you stop. Love or hate the intensity of this concept with its massive grille and 20-inch tires, isn't it good to live in a world where these exist?

Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: “Zoom-zoom.”
“Always the soul of a sports car.”

You would be embarrassed by Mazda’s goofy taglines if they weren’t such utterly perfect declarations of engineering intent. Pure and honest. Mazda designers have their own special declarations of intent. In 2010, Mazda adopted Kodo—soul of motion—to describe and inspire its design language.

Kodo is not sweet and smiley; it’s a powerful blend of aggressive and smooth forms and surfaces. When Derek Jenkins, Mazda’s soft-spoken North American director of design, approached the difficult task of infusing zoom-zoom into a smaller version of the popular CX-5 sport-utility vehicle, he studiously applied a little Kodo, and a star was born.
<iframe width="853" height="480" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/dUof-CaEsYQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

More to read:

2016 Mazda CX-3 at the L.A. Auto Show (November 19, 2014)

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Base price: $27,615 for base Camry Hybrid LE (includes destination charge)
This car: $32,987 for Camry Hybrid SE (includes destination charge)
Top starting price: 2015 Camry Hybrid XLE starts at $30,805 (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter V-6, 156 horsepower, with electric motor and nickel-metal hydride battery for combined 200 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Safety features: Standard: stability control, traction control, rearview camera, brake assist; optional Advanced Technology package on XLE adds pre-collision system, adaptive cruise control, lane departure alert with auto high beam and blind spot monitor with rear cross-traffic alert
Safety ratings: 5/5 stars for overall safety from National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; named Top Safety Pick + from Insurance Institute for Highway Safety
Tech features: 6.1-inch touchscreen display, Bluetooth connectivity
Options on this model: Entune premium audio with navigation ($1,300), power moonroof ($915), remote start ($499) br> Fuel economy: 40 mpg city/38 mpg highway
Chief competitors: 2015 Ford Fusion Hybrid ($26,910), 2015 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid ($26,810), 2015 Honda Accord Hybrid ($30,125); all prices include destination charges
Comparative fuel economy: Ford Fusion Hybrid, with a lithium-ion battery, gets better fuel economy than the Camry Hybrid at 44 mpg city/41 mpg highway; Honda Accord Hybrid also has a lithium-ion battery and gets 50 mpg city/45 mpg highway; Hyundai Sonata Hybrid has a lithium-polymer battery and gets 35 mpg city/40 mpg highway
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sBJDqqnPGX4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The Toyota Camry has been the bestselling car in the U.S. for eleven of the past twelve years
• However, it has been described as “vanilla” by some
• For 2015, the Camry and Camry Hybrid get a thorough overhaul with significant changes, including exterior redesign, improved handling, and a revised interior with more equipment and better materials
• At all three trim levels (value-oriented LE, sporty SE, and premium XLE), the car is equipped with more standard equipment than ever before
• Among the standard features on the base LE are an eight-way power driver’s seat including power lumbar support and a 4.2-inch multi-information display
• Upgrade to the Camry Hybrid SE, and you get better front-seat upholstery, a leather-trimmed tilting and telescoping three-spoke steering wheel with Bluetooth hands-free phone, and silver interior trim
• The Camry's body structure and suspension tuning have been tweaked for better response
• It's interesting that Toyota is still using the older nickel-metal hydride battery instead of a newer lithium-ion battery; nickel-metal hydride is larger and heavier than lithium-ion, although it has a proven track record of safe use in hybrids
• The Camry Hybrid merits strong consideration from shoppers looking for a comfortable, fuel-efficient family car

pageElements.text: I have a huge collection of Christmas music, but here are my favorite CDs. May your days be merry and bright. May you go forth and prosper. And be nice to everyone.
Love, Jean

#1

Vince Guaraldi: A Charlie Brown Christmas Original Soundtrack (Fantasy)
I kick off the season with this classic to get immediately in the spirit. Like Snoopy.
Best Track: Christmas Time Is Here
Incongruous: Nothing

#2

Annie Lennox: A Christmas Cornucopia (Universal Island Records)
An angel’s voice and an inspired playlist.
Best Track: Lullay Lullay
Incongruous: Nothing

#3

Quadriga Consort: On a Cold Winter’s Day (Carpe Diem)
A couple hundred years before Downton Abbey, but same neighborhood.
Best Track: Taladh ar Slanaighear (Our Saviour’s Lullaby)
Incongruous: Nothing

#4

Daryl Hall and John Oates: Home For Christmas (dke Records)
Blue-eyed soul kind of Christmas perfection.
Best Track: Home for Christmas
Incongruous: Nothing

#5

Leon Redbone: Christmas Island (August Records)
Nice banjo.
Best Track: Christmas Ball Blues
Incongruous: Nothing

#6

Crooner Lounge: Swingin’ Christmas (Village Square Music)
The best of the best crooners ever, singing my faves.
Best Track: Shake Hands with Santa Claus by Louis Prima
Incongruous: Nothing

#7

Jolly Old Soul (Rhino)
One of those great compilations you buy at Starbucks while you’re waiting.
Best Track: Every Day Will Be Like a Holiday by William Bell
Incongruous: Nothing

#8

Sleigh Ride Side by Side (EMI Music)
A mix of old classics with a few modern (and unusual) artists.
Best Track: What Are You Doing New Year’s Eve? Lena Horne
Incongruous: Thanks for Christmas, sung by XTC

#9

James Brown: Funky Christmas (Sony Music)
Every song a James Brown original. It’s all about the Flames.
Best Track: Don’t Forget the Poor at Christmas
Incongruous: Clean for Christmas

#10

Il Divo: The Christmas Collection (SYCO Music/Columbia Records)
Best Track: Panis Angelicus
Incongruous: Somewhere over the Rainbow

title: BMW's Car That Won't Crash
subTitle: A day testing the latest in collision prevention on the BMW i3.
promoTeaserSmall: A day testing the latest in collision prevention on the BMW i3.
promoTeaser: A day testing the latest in collision prevention on the BMW i3.
metaTitle: BMW's Car That Won't Crash - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A day testing the latest in collision prevention on the BMW i3.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: I like the idea of a car that drives itself. I know the rest of the world is not 100 percent with me on that. But I’ve watched a lot of science fiction movies. In those, if you engage autopilot, you get to do fun things in your bunk instead of keeping your hands at ten and two. I want that. Every year at the Consumer Electronics Show, the self-driving car gets a little closer. This year it got within striking distance.

There is a lot of technology to work out still, and even more legal implications to argue. But a car that can take over the helm is coming at us fast. In fact, it’s coming at us in increments, hoping we won’t notice. One thing that’s not as difficult to solve as a car that can drive itself is a car that can stop itself before slamming into something. It doesn’t have to identify what it’s about to hit. It doesn’t have to take decisions away from the driver. It already knows you don’t want to smack anything. (Because of that, a few 2015 cars will stop, or nearly stop, when they see that a head-on collision is imminent.)

So while the world sorts out the technical and legal issues around sentient cars, great strides are being made in not-so-smart cars that don’t smash into things. I drove a BMW i3 outfitted with technology—still in the research stage—that could stop itself before I dinged any of its adorable exterior, no matter how bad I was at close-quarters driving. I couldn’t back into anything, sideswipe anything, or ram anything head on, even when I was trying.

BMW had a course set up on the roof of the SLS Las Vegas Hotel. Someone handed me the keys to that sweet ride and dared me to try and hit something with it. I wasn’t allowed to go faster than 15 miles per hour, because that is the point where this technology engages. But other than that? “Go ahead,” the researcher guarding the technology said. “Try to hit something.”
He was confident that the 360-degree laser cameras that protected the car would engage the auto-stop function without incident.
“Go ahead,” the researcher guarding the technology said. “Try to hit something.”
And try, I did.

I tried backing into a wall, which is more difficult than it sounds. I had to practice stopping myself from stopping the car first. But I quickly arrived at the perfect technique: close my eyes and floor it. The car kicked in, braking hard at the last minute and completely stopping before impact. I tried a sideswipe (just look away to accomplish this one): nope. The car came to a complete stop to protect its own side mirrors. Forward impact? Complete stop within kissing distance of the obstacle.
It was fun. I tried my best to be the worst driver in the world. But the car covered my gaffe every time.

This may not be quite as good as kicking back and watching a movie while the car drives I-5 for me, but I want it.  I certainly want it in any car my teenagers drive. And I suspect the insurance savings would go at least partway to justifying the purchase of a BMW.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Volt
subTitle: Electrifying news: an all-new Volt, plus a long-range Bolt crossover concept.
promoTeaserSmall: Electrifying news: an all-new Volt, plus a long-range Bolt crossover concept.
promoTeaser: Electrifying news: an all-new Volt, plus a long-range Bolt crossover concept.
metaDescription: Electrifying news: an all-new Volt, plus a long-range Bolt crossover concept.

pageElements.text: The introduction of the all-new 2016 Chevrolet Volt is big news for General Motors. The company is rolling out its second-generation Volt at the Detroit auto show this morning. But the hybrid's debut is being overshadowed by reports that a larger crossover concept, the Chevrolet Bolt, will be there, and it’s claiming 200 miles of range on electric power only.

The Volt will go on sale later this year, delivering up to 50 miles between charges, which is 30 percent greater range on electric power only than the current model. Between its new four-cylinder gas engine and its battery power, drivers can expect to go about 1,000 miles between trips to the gas station, Chevrolet says. A thousand miles, they say? Low gas prices or not, that’s enticing.

The Chevrolet Volt was big news when it came out in 2010, but how has the mid-$30,000 sedan actually done in the market? Well enough to make it the biggest-selling plug-in on the U.S. market, according to GM, although it has certainly received nowhere near the adulation you’ll see for Tesla’s electric cars.

As for the upcoming crossover, sure, the long-range Bolt will make heads turn. But as a consumer, if you’re looking for alternative energy here and now, you’ll want to look at the Volt, which goes on sale in the second half of 2015 looking a lot more like the Impala and a lot less like a quirky EV. That’s by design, Chevrolet says.

We got an early look at it at the Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant last week, and Chevrolet design chief John Cafaro was right when he said it’s just that little bit more aggressive and sexy than the outgoing model. “It doesn’t look like a jellybean” is how he put it.

The new Volt gets LED daylight running lights, a pair of eight-inch touchscreens, GM’s 4G LTE with Wi-Fi, and a redesigned back seat that now has three sets of seatbelts, although there’s absolutely no leg space for the center passenger. Like the outgoing model, headroom in the back seat is marginal.

But back to the range issue. You can drive more miles on electric only, now up to 50 miles from the previous 38. Fuel economy is 41 mpg combined or 102 MPGe using a combination of electric power and the new 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine, the first North American use of GM’s new small engine family. It makes 101 horsepower and runs on regular unleaded fuel.

The unleaded gas, the fifth seat, and a move toward a smoother and quieter driving experience are part of Chevrolet’s response to its close study of Volt owners’ feedback. Executive chief engineer Pam Fletcher called it “about the most customer-inspired car you’re going to see launched” because owners were exhaustively polled.
Those owners wanted “mainstream,” according to Volt chief engineer Andrew Farah. The roofline is lower and a bit sleeker with a handsome shark-fin antenna on top,  the hood and liftgate are aluminum.

New for the 2016 model are a set of Michelin energy saver tires specifically designed for the Volt, and an upcoming infotainment system that will be shared with several GM vehicles, to be described in detail in the spring at the New York Auto Show.

Chevrolet’s moment in the spotlight as the Detroit auto show media days open on Monday morning will make it clear that the brand intends to plug in for the long haul. Pricing on the Volt, and official details on the Bolt, will be announced shortly.

More to Read:

2014 Chevrolet Volt: Should You Buy It?

title: 2016 Cadillac CTS-V
subTitle: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.
promoTeaserSmall: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.
promoTeaser: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.
metaDescription: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.

pageElements.text:
So you say you have a need for speed? Cadillac addressed that by introducing its 2016 CTS-V super sedan at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit on Tuesday. Let’s just cut to the chase: it's a rear-wheel-drive, five-passenger luxury sedan that is capable of 200 mph in standard trim.

That puts the third generation of the CTS-V in some pretty rarefied company, especially among sedans. Particularly among American sedans, where this car's only rival will be the Dodge Charger with the 707-horsepower Hellcat V-8.

The new Cadillac, compared with the Hellcat, gets to 200 mph with a mere 640 horsepower (and 630 pound-feet of torque), huffed up by a version of the new Corvette Z06 6.2-liter supercharged V-8. That’s a serious gain versus the second generation, which was rated for 556 horsepower.

The supercharged eight sends power to the Caddy’s electronic limited-slip rear differential via a new eight-speed automatic transmission, which can be operated in manual mode with paddle shifters. Its use of a torque converter distinguishes it from the dual-clutch manumatics dominating the high-performance market, but Cadillac claims its up- and downshifts will match the best of the Euro competition.
As proof, Cadillac offers an impressive 0-to-60 mph claim: 3.7 seconds. Pretty brisk for a luxury sedan weighing more than two tons (4,145 pounds).

To get that much mass stopped from high speed, there's a robust new Brembo brake system, although there's no carbon-ceramic rotor option. Cadillac says extensive bracing has improved rigidity by 25 percent, suspension components are stiffer, the ZF variable-ratio electric power steering has been tweaked for better feel, and the latest generation of Cadillac's magnetic ride control continuously adjusts the suspension according to road conditions and driving style.

Visually, the V is distinguished from tamer members of the CTS clan by dedicated front and rear fascias, aero splitters fore and aft, a higher carbon fiber hoodline (to accommodate the supercharger) and an air extractor to mitigate underhood heat; and wider fender flares to accommodate those meaty Michelins.
There’s also an aero package option that adds downforce, at the expense of that 200-mph top speed.

While this and more add up to a formidable sport sedan package, Cadillac hasn’t neglected the luxury element. Division boss Johan de Nysschen claims the new super sedan will be as quiet and docile for everyday driving as any of its stablemates.

The bottom line: This is the most powerful Cadillac in the division’s 102-year history, as well as the most capable sedan. Like you, we’ll be looking forward to becoming better acquainted. However, that may be some time coming. The new CTS-V won’t be in showrooms until 2016.

title: 5 Reasons to Want LED on Your Next Car
subTitle: Here's why they do more than just give a car a pretty face (and rear view).
promoTitle: 5 Reasons to Want LED on Your Next Car
promoTeaserSmall: Here's why they do more than just give a car a pretty face (and rear view).
promoTeaser: Here's why they do more than just give a car a pretty face (and rear view).
keywords: 5 Reasons to Want LED on Your Next Car
metaTitle: 5 Reasons to Want LED Lights on Your Next Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Your next car will be better off to have them, and here are five reasons why. Read about LED lights on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Like many features you’d now consider indispensable, LED lighting is a bit of technology that was seen first on luxury-level cars. But that’s not going to be true for long; it will eventually become something you’ll see on cars and trucks at a wide variety of price points. In fact, there are already affordable vehicles that sport these eye-catching lights in front, in back, and even inside.
Other than looking pretty as a design element, and sparkly and brilliant to a passer-by on a dark night, what is the point of LED lighting, and is it worth trying to get on your next car?
Here are five things to know.

1.

You can see better with them. Light-emitting diodes, or LEDs, are much brighter than traditional halogen or incandescent lights, yet they’re closer to the experience of seeing natural light, so they’re not as hard on the eyes. They’re also more capable of precision: In the Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class, for example, there are 24 individual LEDs inside each headlamp, so light distribution can be precisely controlled.

2.

People can see your car better. Audi claims LED head- and taillights activate as much as 10 times faster than incandescent lights, letting other drivers spot your brake lights sooner. Many vehicles that haven't gone full LED for the headlights do have LED daytime running lights, making your car more visible during daylight hours as well: this 2015 Dodge Charger, for instance.

3.

They are good-looking and, because individual LED lights can be laid out in various shapes, can become an important style element. On the Acura MDX, for example, there are five LEDs in each headlamp, laid out in a row in what the company calls a “jewel eye” design.

4.

They’re more energy efficient. LED lights don’t have a filament like traditional headlamps, so they’re more durable. They’re also less of a power drain, and they can last much longer before they burn out. For example, Ford lighting expert John Teodecki says the LED headlamps in the 2015 F-150 pickup use 63 percent less energy than halogen bulbs and are expected to last five times longer.

5.

Going LED is becoming more affordable as popular models adopt the technology. For example, even the base model of the 2015 Toyota Corolla has LED low-beam headlights with halogen high beams and LED daytime running lights.

title: The Magnetic Ice Shield vs. Winter
subTitle: Would you spend $25 to avoid scraping your windshield all winter? Sure you would!
promoTitle: The Magnetic Ice Shield vs. Winter
promoTeaserSmall: Would you spend $25 to avoid scraping your windshield all winter? Sure you would!
promoTeaser: Would you spend $25 to avoid scraping your windshield all winter? Sure you would!
keywords: The Magnetic Ice Shield vs. Winter
metaTitle: The Magnetic Ice Shield vs. Winter
metaDescription: Would you spend $25 to avoid scraping your windshield all winter? Sure you would!Check out our test on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Quality of life can be massively improved by the smallest things. Here in the Ice Belt, where Jean Knows Cars does business, our quality of life currently involves dealing with winter weather. We have just tested something that, for the price of a nice lunch, can make your whole winter experience better if you’re a street or driveway parker.

The iceScreen Magnetic Ice Shield covers the windshield of your vehicle, stays on with no drama, pulls off with no hassle or struggle, and gives you a perfectly clear view with absolutely no shoveling or scraping. It’s sold online for $29.95 to $40 (depending on whether you get the standard model we bought or the deluxe version that has a reflective sunshade on the reverse side). There’s even a large-format Ice Shield for trucks ($29.95).

There’s still lots of winter yet, but the iceScreen people are currently selling these for 50 percent off on their website. Such a deal even at the list price.
How to use it:

On: Put the Ice Shield on the windshield. It takes seconds, and with the aid of several strong magnets, it’s foolproof. Side flaps get closed in the front doors to keep the shield from flying away in a high wind--or being stolen. Hint: Tuck in the flaps iafter you’ve completed installing the shield; it’s an exercise in futility to try to slam them in the doors while the shield is loose.
Off: Don't remove the Ice Shield until you remove snow from the rest of the car, so you don't undo the work the magic screen did for you.
The company also makes "Mirror Mitz" to cover your side mirrors. Now that's a luxury. They're $10 a pair.

images.caption: Flaps protect against thieves and high winds.
Ice Shield works like a charm.

pageElements.text: The nice people at iceScreen are helping us give away five Ice Shields and five sets of Mirror Mitz. Visit our Facebook page or comment below to be one of those entered to get one. We want to hear about your worst ice-scraping experience (or your best).

title: Moving Backward
subTitle: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.
promoTeaserSmall: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.
promoTeaser: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.
metaDescription: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.

pageElements.text:
This story was written by my father, Automotive News editor Robert Lienert, in 1980.—Jean

My parents were products of their time and place, and when they were married early in 1906, the automotive age had not yet reached Nebraska.
My father farmed with horses and gave them up reluctantly when tractors took over, much later.

As a bride, my mother had her own horse. It was a "buggy" horse. That is, it was not so big and awkward and cumbersome as a draft horse. When she wanted to visit a neighbor or go to town, she'd whistle for her horse and he'd come to the barn.
She could harness him and hitch him to the buggy and be on her way. As a result, she was more independent than were many farm wives.
My parents were married about fifteen years before they bought their first automobile. For my mother, the car did not lead to freedom or open the way to a mobile society.

As the family acquired cars and the "modern" age burst upon her, the private "buggy" horse was displaced. And my mother never learned to drive a car. I never asked why. But I recall that riding in a car made her nervous, and it would have been in character for my father to feel that only men drove cars.

My mother thus had to depend on someone else to take her when she wanted to go anywhere. And since my father often didn't wish to go places, my mother spent a lot more time at home in her mature years.
The automobile, rather than freeing her, confined her more than ever.

title: 2016 Honda Pilot
subTitle: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.
promoTeaserSmall: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.
promoTeaser: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.
metaDescription: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.

pageElements.text: The 2016 Honda Pilot will bring something to showrooms this summer that the current Pilot lacks: style. It made its debut at the Chicago Auto Show, where it did something surprising for this previously staid product: It threatened to steal the spotlight from all other new-model introductions.

On the threshold of its third generation, the 2016 Pilot discards the trucky, two-box design of generation two for a more rounded profile, with a roofline that slopes away slightly at the rear, a strong character line below the windows, and LED running lights accenting LED headlamps.
The new sheetmetal surrounds new architecture, shared with the Odyssey minivan and the next-generation Honda Ridgeline pickup that's coming for 2017.
Honda’s Chicago show presentation was thin on specifications, but this much emerged: the 2016 Pilot is 3.5 inches longer, yielding more interior room.

At the same time, Honda says the Pilot will weigh up to 300 pounds less. The engineers say there's a greater percentage of high strength steel in the structure, as well as more aluminum and other lightweight materials. The high-strength steel also accounts for increased structural rigidity, according to Honda, although percentages of increase weren’t revealed.

The 2016 Pilot gets a new engine, a 3.5-liter V-6 with direct fuel injection, cylinder deactivation, and a start/stop feature. This V-6 is new to the Pilot, but not to Honda; it’s adapted from the 278-horsepower version in the Accord sedan. The current Pilot has a 250-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6.

Honda refrained from releasing power numbers for the V-6 in Pilot tune, as well as EPA fuel economy projections. But with a more efficient engine, those projections will be an improvement over the current Pilot’s 18 mpg city/25 highway (17/24 with all-wheel drive).
A new nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters is offered in higher trim levels.

Like previous generations, the 2016 Honda Pilot is front-wheel drive, with the option of all-wheel drive. However, the 2016 AWD option is a new system, a six-speed automatic transmission replaces the previous five-speed, and a new nine-speed automatic, with paddle shifters, is offered in higher trim levels.

Interior design and materials move up a notch, and there are a number of new upscale options: a heated steering wheel; perforated leather front seats, heated and ventilated; heated leather second row seats; a panoramic power moonroof; second-row captain’s chairs; and LED map lights. There are also numerous new electronic features—five USB ports, four of them capable of recharging iPads and/or smartphones, as well as audio player jacks, an HDMI video game port, two 12-volt outlets, and a 115-volt power outlet.

There’s a new eight-inch touchscreen option, home for a new satellite navigation system with graphics that render images in 3D. And of course there’s enhanced connectivity, via the HondaLink infotainment system.

The current Pilot earned top safety ratings from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, and Honda expects the 2016 Pilot will duplicate that achievement, with a host of driver assistance features, including a new road departure mitigation system, and enhanced crashworthiness.
Pricing remains to be revealed. Current Pilot pricing starts at $30,750 for the basic front-wheel-drive LX, climbing to $42,500 for the top-of-the-line Touring model.

title: 2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata
subTitle: The fourth-generation Miata is sexier and more desirable than ever.
promoTeaserSmall: The fourth-generation Miata is sexier and more desirable than ever.
promoTeaser: The fourth-generation Miata is sexier and more desirable than ever.
metaDescription: The fourth-generation Miata is sexier and more desirable than ever.

pageElements.text: An all-new Mazda MX-5 Miata. Did you say so what? It’s not an unreasonable question. The original Miata was a clever blend of brilliant concept and common sense—a captivating and affordable update on the dear old British roadsters that added practicality, comfort, and reliability to the sports car tradition.Two successive generations added more improvements and amenities, including a brilliantly engineered folding hardtop.
So how could Mazda improve a car that seemed almost beyond reproach?
The fourth generation is the stuff of oohs and aahs—all new, sexier than any of its predecessors, and beautifully engineered.
Read This! The First Mazda Miata: The Car That Reset My Brain, by Jean Jennings / February 20, 2015

Here’s how. Appearing at the Chicago show, where the original made its world debut twenty-six years ago, the fourth generation is the stuff of oohs and aahs—all new, sexier than any of its predecessors, and beautifully engineered.
Pending a test drive, we’ll assume the dynamics will measure up to the new packaging. In the meantime, here’s the hardware story.

At 154.1 inches, the 2016 MX-5 Miata is 3.2 inches shorter than the third generation, on a wheelbase (91.1 inches) that’s shrunk by just over a half-inch. The new car is almost a half-inch wider (68.1 inches), and the only exterior spec that doesn’t change is height: 49.0 inches.

The sum of all these dimensions, plus static ride height that’s down by about a half-inch, is a tidier, more aggressive look, thanks to a wider stance and reduced overhangs—less Miata extending beyond the (seventeen inch) front and rear wheels.

There’s also less Miata at the scales. Reduced dimensions and extensive use of aluminum add up to a roadster that will weigh in some 150 pounds lighter, according to Mazda—about 2,330 pounds in base trim. Lower weight plus revised suspension, a slightly lower center of gravity, and improved weight distribution—Mazda makes it 50/50 front/rear versus 52/48, thanks to a slight rearward relocation of the engine—should result in a roadster that’s exceptionally quick on its feet.

Whether it will be quick when the light turns green remains to be seen. The new engine is Mazda’s Skyactiv 2.0-liter four-cylinder, making 155 horsepower. Nourished by direct fuel injection, it’s more efficient than the 2.0-liter four it replaces, with a slight edge in torque (148 pound-feet versus 140), and should achieve better EPA fuel economy projections (the 2.0 is rated 22 mpg city/28 highway). Ratings for the new Miata have not been announced.

But at 155 horsepower, it gives away 12 ponies to the current engine. That’s not much, but it works out to a less favorable power-to-weight ratio for the new car—15.5 pounds per hp for 2016, 14.9 for the current Miata.
Like the 2015 Miata, the fourth generation will offer a choice of manual or automatic transmissions, both six-speeds.

Despite its reduced dimensions, the cockpit of the new Miata will provide a little more room, a little more seatback adjustability, a slightly lower seating position, and improved forward sight lines, thanks to a lower hoodline.

Although the new Miata won’t be in showrooms until summer, Mazda is ready with an array of custom accessories, introduced at Chicago. The collection includes an aero kit (front air dam, rocker panel extensions, rear bumper skirt, and rear deck-lid lip spoiler); a Brembo brake package with snazzy red calipers; BBS wheels, seventeen inches like the standard  wheel but with increased offset; and a luggage rack.
With summer still some way off—Chicago in February makes summer seem to be a myth—Mazda wasn’t ready to announce pricing for the new MX-5. The current price model starts at a little under $25,000.
It’s a safe bet that pricing for the new car will start a little higher. It’s also a safe bet that it will still be by far the best sports car buy going.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Equinox
subTitle: A tasteful update to Chevy's compact-crossover contender.
promoTeaserSmall: A tasteful update to Chevy's compact-crossover contender.
promoTeaser: A tasteful update to Chevy's compact-crossover contender.
metaDescription: A tasteful update to Chevy's compact-crossover contender.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower(L and LS models); 3.6-liter V-6, 301 horsepower (LT and LTZ)
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/32 mpg highway (FWD); 20/29 mpg (AWD)
Most interesting option: 4G LTE Wi-Fi hot spot

The first thing to know about the Chevrolet Equinox is that it’s hugely popular. It’s Chevrolet’s second-best-selling vehicle, after the Silverado pickup. Chevrolet’s U.S. vice-president, Brian Sweeney, said there are more than a million on the road today, and you probably wouldn't argue that point, so frequent are Equinox sightings in mall parking lots and suburban streetscapes.
It's true; in the increasingly popular category of family-friendly SUVs, the Equinox plays a strong role.

So it's logical that the 2016 Equinox, making its world debut at the Chicago Auto Show this week, didn't mess with the winning formula too much. The changes involved a modest update to its looks, both front and rear.

There are now LED daytime running lights, plus new headlights and fog lamps; upper trim levels get LED headlamps, too. In the rear, Sweeney said the dual-element taillamps were “inspired by Corvette and Camaro,” but nobody will mistake this family-friendly vehicle for either of those.
The grille has been updated, but appropriately, resisting the current mania for enormous grilles, Chevrolet has kept the toothiness to a minimum on the 2016 Equinox.

More interesting to the crossover shopper are the numerous safety and technology features you can now get on the Equinox.  Rear cross-traffic and side blind zone alert are now options, and a rearview camera is standard on all trim levels. A seven-inch infotainment screen with Chevrolet’s MyLink is standard as well.

The Equinox has only been on the market since 2010, and this is the first update it has received. It faces off against tough competitors including the Honda CR-V,  Ford Escape, and Toyota RAV4. Chevrolet is determined to hold onto the number-four sales slot, planning for an all-new Equinox that's due in late 2017.

title: 2016 Hyundai Elantra GT
subTitle: The moderately hot, under-$20,000 hatchback is refreshed, just in time for spring.
promoTeaserSmall: The moderately hot, under-$20,000 hatchback is refreshed, just in time for spring.
promoTeaser: The moderately hot, under-$20,000 hatchback is refreshed, just in time for spring.
metaDescription: The moderately hot, under-$20,000 hatchback is refreshed, just in time for spring.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive hatchback
Price: $19,625 (including destination charge)
On-sale date: March 2015
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 173 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual (standard); six-speed automatic (optional)
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway
Most interesting option: Driver-selectable steering with Comfort, Normal, and Sport modes
Grand Touring—GT—is a badge that suggests a higher level of driving fun than other members of a vehicle lineup, and that’s the mission of the 2016 Hyundai Elantra GT.

A growing number of young drivers associate fun-to-drive with telematics, and electronic gadgetry is expanded on the freshened Elantra GT. But you'll also find more traditional features such as nimble handling, precise steering, and enough power to ward off boredom. Competitors in this class include the Mazda 3, the Ford Focus ST, and the Volkswagen Golf.

The GT’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine makes 173 horsepower, which qualifies as adequate among the compact hatchback hot rods, and the EPA forecasts fuel economy performance of 24 mpg in city driving, 33 on the highway. The ratings are the same whether the GT is equipped with a six-speed manual transmission (standard) or a six-speed automatic.

The suspension has been adjusted for less body roll in corners and a little more authority than the basic Elantra sedan. The GT also offers a Style package with a more aggressive suspension setup and stickier tires.
Hyundai’s swoopy Fluidic Styling has weathered well and didn’t need much updating.

Hyundai’s driver-selectable two-mode steering has Comfort, Normal, and Sport settings. Set it at Comfort for low effort around parking lots or city streets, or on Sport for an increased sense of feel on twisty back roads.

Styling updates are minimal. There's a new grille with horizontal slats, plus redesigned 17-inch aluminum alloy wheels. To be fair, Hyundai’s swoopy Fluidic Styling has weathered well and didn’t need much updating.
Standard features on the GT include heated seats, a cooled glove box, LED taillights, and leather seating.

The most interesting options are ventilated front seats (part of the Tech package), which Hyundai claims as a compact-class first; a new generation of Hyundai’s navigation system integrated with HD radio and Apple’s Siri voice recognition; and the latest version of Hyundai’s Blue Link system with remote start capability and Google-linked Destination Search function.
The 2016 Elantra GT will be on sale in March, with a base price of $19,625.

metaDescription: Are you looking for a really tough truck? The aluminum-bodied Ford may be the one for you.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Ford F-150 XLT Supercab

Base price: $38,200 (including destination charge)
This truck: $44,850 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 2.7-liter V-6, 325 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Notable standard features on this model: Power tailgate lock, trailer sway control, tow hooks
Options I can’t live without: Tailgate step ($375), rearview camera (part of XLT option package, $1,400)
You might also be considering: 2015 Chevrolet Silverado 1500 LT 4WD ($38,925), 2015 Ram 1500 SLT 4WD ($39,615), 2015 Toyota Tundra Limited 4x4 Double Cab ($41,785) (all prices include destination charge)

You can divide the vast number of new pickup truck buyers between two nameplates—Ford F-150 and Chevrolet Silverado. My mom had two Chevys; I had a Ford. And we were definitely not alone. These pickup trucks’ sales are so huge, they are the #1 and #2 bestselling vehicles in America. Not first and second among trucks, mind you, but among all vehicles. Oh, by the way, Chrysler’s Ram pickup is in third place. I had two of those, too.

For the past thirty-three years, Americans have loved Ford the best, and despite 2014 being a down year for the F-150, Ford still sold just shy of 754,000 F-150s—an astonishing 200,000 more than Chevy’s new Silverado.

Lining up the two rivals, I see a beautifully refined 2015 Silverado, almost carlike in its appointments and technologies. I see a truck that appeals to people who love and/or need trucks, one that women feel comfortable in.

Looking at the 2015 F-150, especially in the XLT 4X4 Supercab trim as shown here, I see a manly brawler chiseled from a piece of cold, hard steel. That’s kind of funny, considering the body of the new F-150 is actually made of aluminum to save weight. This was a controversial move that had Ford’s uber-loyal contractor fans questioning how tough it would still be. There seems to be some overcompensation in the design department to disabuse that notion.

The front end looks like a Mack truck looming in your rearview. The bumpers, the side mirrors, the instrument panel and dash, and even the logos look like they were carved with a hammer and chisel, not penned. Tough stuff. So tough, that it might be too tough for even you. You know who you are. You either like it or you don’t, but you can’t ignore it.
There are five different models of the F-150—XL, XLT, Lariat, King Ranch, and Platinum—with base prices ranging from $26,615 to $52,155. Oh, but you are far, far from finished pricing your F-150.

It’s no secret that you need to pack sandwiches to get you through a pickup truck’s endless options list.  It is much easier today than when I bought my first of three big trucks when I was in my twenties. (I picked a stripper F-150 on the lot and found out, when I tried to put something behind the seat, that a folding rear seatback would have been a desirable option.)

Ford’s attractive configurator begins with the base XL, priced at $26,615 (including destination charge) and moves up from there. There is a choice of five F-150 models, three different cab configurations, three different bed sizes, and four different engines. And did you want four-wheel drive with that?

The configurator leads you methodically through the vast world of options, one step at a time, with pop-up boxes reminding you of the cost of the option you just chose and requiring a yes or no before you go on. It doesn’t take long to hundred-dollar yourself into the stratosphere. Floor mats: $95. Manual folding side mirrors: $275. Center console box: $125. Rearview camera: part of the $1,400 301A Rapid Spec package.

Don’t get me started. I’m a buyer, not a shopper. You really have to be the kind of person who loves picking out the floor tiles, the countertops, the carpeting, the wall paint, and the faucets to enjoy hanging out on the Build Your F-150 page all day.

Our test truck is not as loaded as you might imagine, but it still has enough little niceties that the options added $6,650 to the final bill. (I think my first stripped-down truck, a Ford F-150 4x4, cost me just a tad over $5,000, but that was a while ago.) I could have done nicely with a rearview camera ($250), remote start ($195), the must-have rear tailgate step ($375), and the excellent 2.7-liter EcoBoost V-6 ($795). Moving up to a thirty-three-gallon fuel tank ($195) is an absolute necessity, or you’ll be filling up the tank more than you empty your bladder.
If you bought this 2015 F-150 XLT Supercab 4X4 as equipped, you would have been $195’d to death all the way to $44,850.

As for the driving experience: Without a running board and a grab handle inside on the A-pillar, I couldn’t have gotten in. Driving down the road, I opened the lid of the gargantuan console box and couldn’t get around the lid to get what I’d stowed. It’s just huge and in the way.

The radio controls surround the center screen. The non-touch control setup was confusing after spending the past several years trying to master MyFord Touch.  (Upgrade to the Lariat trim level to get that setup.) It took a while to figure out that there was no controller, just a block of push buttons: left, right, up, and down arrows, surrounding an OK button. Just far enough away to make you take your eyes off the road. The good news is that all of the buttons and knobs are big enough for big contractor fingers.

Driving the Ford F-150 reinforces the notion that you’re no weekend rodeo clown. (Actually, most rodeo clowns are tougher than most contractors.) First you feel cool just for being able to get in it. Then the ride is, shall we say, a tad manly. The 2.7 EcoBoost felt good leaving the driveway, but the suspension jounce was noticeable. The ride turned out to be pretty decent, although you have to pay attention.

The tailgate is also a bit of a struggle, now that I’ve gotten used to one-touch hydraulics in so many other vehicles. You can’t one-hand it; it’ll take both hands and a little forearm. It does have a power lock of the type first seen in Toyotas, along with a rearview camera aimed directly at the trailer hitch. Today’s rearview cameras are much more sophisticated and can give you a really helpful view. The Supercab is just big enough to really make it necessary; you’ll be parking by Braille without it.

Part of the bigness means you really need to get the optional rear tailgate step. It’s a small platform that swings out from under the tailgate to help you get up and in. It worked, but it needs to drop lower, and there needs to be something better to grip.

There’s a good chance that just coming out of a week with a GMC Canyon SUV—which was more the size and footprint of my mid-1970s F-150 and two Ram 1500s—has made me especially sensitive to how tall, how wide, and how jouncy this big feller rides. It’s not rough, no rattle or bang, but let’s just say it’s no fun to drive on the highway.

In a light snow on the Interstate, I found myself getting all four tires loose at the end of the on ramp, which possibly made the semi coming up on me as nervous as it made me. I dialed in 4 HI on the dash switch, and things straightened right out.

The Supercab’s rear passenger compartment—accessed by a half-door on either side—isn’t as comfy as a proper back seat. Kids will fit best, but you’ll want to see how difficult it will be to wrangle a child seat back there. Both doors on each seat open wide, to access the full opening.  The seatbacks fold up and lock in place, revealing a long shallow underseat storage tray. A release handle drops the seat back down. If you want a carpool vehicle, the extremely spacious back seat of the four-door F-150 Crew Cab is a better choice.

The Verdict:

Make no mistake: this is no throwback to the trucks of my youth. The engine is smooth and quiet. The brakes are four-wheel discs with ABS. The 4X4 is electric shift on the fly. There’s hill-start assist, power rack and pinion steering, trailer sway control, and both front-seat-mounted side airbags,and canopy side curtain airbags.

But the bottom line is, you really have to want a huge truck to come to grips with the Ford F-150. I love trucks, and I wanted to love this one. It’s made of aluminum, and it’s strong and lightweight. But there is a bigness about it that I didn’t expect.

When you see that giant grille (almost comical in its chiseled brutality), you are seeing exactly what I was feeling. There’s a lot to like in the Ford F-150, especially if you want your truck with a feeling of toughness that is off the macho scale.

images.caption: Interior view of 2015 Ford F-150 Supercab.
Rear seating area in 2015 Ford F-150 Supercab.

pageElements.text:
Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: Getting behind the wheel of this F-150 pickup was not smooth. I'm 5'3" tall, and not athletic, and found it was a bit of a reach to climb in. Having done so, however, I immediately felt at home, at ease, and in a good mood. Driving the F-150 on a lightly traveled stretch of highway, I appreciated the commanding view of the road. If it was a little bouncy on Michigan's bad roads, it was certainly no worse than many crossovers or SUVs. Jean thinks the F-150 is over-the-top macho, but I think it's just macho enough to give the person driving it a sense of capability. It doesn't feel show-offy to me, but it does encourage thoughts of spring projects involving big sacks of things that would go in the back. I also very much appreciate Ford's reach in changing up such a popular vehicle by making the body out of aluminum. Taking a chance, and on the product most integral to the automaker's success, is the kind of action that moves the world forward.

pageElements.text:
2015 Toyota Yaris SE

Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact hatchback
Base price: $17,645 (including destination charge)
This car: $18,724 (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 106 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual
Fuel economy: 30 mpg city/37 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Smart Stop brake assist technology
Options I can’t live without: Navigation system ($899)
Notable standard features on this model: Brake assist, rear spoiler, leather-trimmed steering wheel
You might also be considering: 2015 Ford Fiesta SE Hatchback ($16,420); 2015 Honda Fit LX ($16,470); 2015 Kia Rio LX ($17,815); 2015 Nissan Versa Note SV ($17,155) (all prices include destination charge)

Can you buy a decent new car and pay less than $20,000 for it? Yes, in fact, you can, and here’s the big news: You won’t have to steel yourself for a total hose-out special. Increasingly, you can get a small car laden with many features that used to be reserved for higher-end vehicles.

A case in point is the Toyota Yaris. Once a tiny, boring box, the Yaris in 2015 has a new, modern, and attractive appearance—that is, if you approve of the angry-mesh-grille look that is so popular these days. Which I do. Toyota pretty much had to update; the city-car category is jammed with little hatchbacks at small prices. The new Yaris has to elbow its way through Ford’s Fiesta, the Honda Fit, the Kia Rio, Chevy’s Sonic, and the Mazda 2, all worthy competitors.

The Yaris model we tested was the top-end SE five-door hatchback, equipped with a five-speed manual transmission, which comes in at $18,724. (The base model, the three-door Yaris L, is priced at $15,670.) But if you were expecting an el strippo look for an el strippo price, you would be pleasantly surprised. Remarkably sophisticated-looking for such a small car, the Yaris SE has projector-beam headlights with an LED light bar, LED daytime running lights, a black grille with piano black accents, a rear spoiler, and sixteen-inch alloy wheels (versus the standard fifteen-inch wheels). Compare the 2015 Yaris to the ones from 2014 or earlier, and you’ll appreciate Toyota’s leap of faith in overhauling this small car’s appearance.
Looks would certainly be one reason to buy a new car, instead of used, at this price point. Another would be modern conveniences on the inside.

Looks would certainly be one reason to buy a new car, instead of used, at this price point. Another would be modern conveniences on the inside. Our Yaris SE had a 6.1-inch touchscreen, navigation (an $899 option), and Bluetooth connectivity. Cruise control, a leather-trimmed steering wheel and shift lever, and power windows and locks are all there, as is remote keyless entry. Having said that, don’t look for luxury or coziness: there’s no center arm rest, the seats are narrow and stiff—although not uncomfortable, even on a 100-mile highway run—and the overall feeling is still somewhat...economical.

Missing is a rearview camera, something you’ll find on the Yaris’s arch-competitor, the Honda Fit. Thinking about the number of young, inexperienced drivers who are likely to own a Yaris, this is disappointing, but in fairness, most cars in this class don’t have one. It would be a welcome option, though.

Also missing is the kind of capacious rear storage the Honda Fit has so much of. The Yaris has 60/40 split-folding rear seats, but the amount of rear space you get when you fold them down doesn’t approach the 52.7 cubic feet the Fit can boast. Having said that, the rear seating area is surprisingly comfortable. I wouldn’t go so far as to call it “spacious,” but it’s no mere package holder; you could put kids back there, at least kids up through elementary-school age, and adults could stand it for short drives, at least.
The Yaris may not have the latest and greatest under the hood, but it’s reasonably competent, especially as an around-town errand runner.

If you think the Yaris seems like it’s much better suited for use around town than on a road trip, you’re not wrong, but a couple of hours on the highway, including a spate of rush-hour traffic, showed that it is capable enough and feels bigger than it is. You can push 70 mph comfortably, although you won’t forget you’re in an economy car. The SE model has upgraded suspension and brakes, and it shows. Wind noise was manageable, turbulence was minimal, and the 1.5-liter four-cylinder was reasonably competent. This is an older engine, teamed with a five-speed manual transmission versus the six-speed you’ll find on the Fit. Other competitors, including the Ford Fiesta and the Chevrolet Sonic, also have five-speed manuals as standard. The automatic transmission is an old-school four-speed. Today’s newest transmissions are much smoother and quieter. I would at least stay with the manual so I could get every last drop of shifting fun available. So, the Yaris may not have the latest and greatest under the hood, but it’s reasonably competent, especially as an around-town errand runner.

Subcompact shoppers are also concerned with fuel economy and safety. The Yaris bests its competitors with an impressive 30 mpg in town and 37 mpg on the highway. By comparison, the Chevrolet Sonic gets 26/35 mpg, and the Honda Fit gets 29/37 mpg. The 2015 Yaris did well in Insurance Institute for Highway Safety testing, rated Good in all but the small-overlap front crash rating. Here again, it’s outgunned by the Honda Fit, which got Acceptable on the small-overlap test and was named a Top Safety Pick for 2015.

The Verdict:

Why would you choose the Toyota Yaris? You might choose it if you’re a Toyota loyalist, or want to be one. You might like its styling better than that of its more prosaic-looking competitors. But there’s no doubt that you will have lots of other cars to check out before you make that decision.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: I invited my nineteen-year-old son, Henry, in to the passenger's seat of the Yaris and asked him his thoughts. "Why wouldn't you just get a used Honda Civic for this same money?" he asked. He has a point, and a lot of people on a budget might prefer a three-year-old car that's more conventionally sized, to get more horsepower and more space. Personally, I saw the appeal of the Yaris as soon as I had to back into a parallel parking space downtown. You just feel smart when you are zipping around in something this neat and compact. On the list of things I loved: the single front wiper, the topstitching on the seats, and the edgy front treatment, sort of a micro-Lexus look. Would I want to drive cross-country in it? Not today, but when I was still in the youth demographic? Sure.

Molly Jean: The driver's seat in the Toyota Yaris is oddly high. I am five foot seven, and my seating position was so high that I don't think I would ever need a visor to keep the sun out of my eyes. I can't imagine someone any taller even being able to sit in the car without hitting their head. That aside, I also agree with Laura's son Henry that, although $18,000 is a low price for a brand-new car, I can do without the new car smell to get a few more luxuries in a used car for the same price. Specifically, how about a telescoping steering wheel? It was fun to zip around with the manual transmission, but I assume most buyers of the Yaris will opt for the automatic. I personally take a pass on the Yaris.

title: 8 Flavors of Pi
subTitle: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).
promoTeaserSmall: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).
promoTeaser: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).
metaDescription: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).

pageElements.text: Geeks everywhere appreciate Pi Day (March 14, or 3.14) so much more than, say, New Year's Eve. The celebratory food of choice is, of course, pie. With that in mind, we made our list of favorites and found their equivalents in the automotive world. Flavorful, we think you'll agree, starting with the upper-crust Ferrari California you're admiring in the photo above.

1. Apple: Aston Martin Vanquish

The grand tourer looks great in Selene Bronze, one of the Contemporary collection of shades from the British carmaker. If you want to continue the apple theme, go with the full Spicy Red interior. The Vanquish and its 565-horsepower 6.0-liter V-12 will help keep the doctor away. The Vanquish starts at $287,820.

2. Banana Cream: 2015 Lamborghini Huracán

In shiny Giallo Midas Pearl Effect, as shown here, or in the matte Giallo Horus, you have two choices to color this car yellow, as it ought to be. The Huracán starts at $241,945.

3. Blueberry: 2015 Chevrolet Corvette Z06

The world is full of blue cars, but blueberry is blue with a bite. The Corvette qualifies in Night Race Blue Metallic, a standard color for the Z06. Pricing starts at $79,995. For a more blueberries-and-cream look, you'd go with the lighter Laguna Blue Tintcoat, a $995 option.

4. Key Lime: 2015 Dodge Challenger R/T

The best thing about muscle cars is how meta they are: their sense of humor, referring back to the Sixties with no historical portentousness, is so very American. You can find lots of cute little low-cost cars in green, but this? This is the best use of lime green out there. The Challenger R/T in Sublime Green Pearl Coat starts at $32,490, or get serious with the Hellcat version, starting at $60,990.

5. Pecan: 2014 Porsche Cayman

Cognac Metallic is the shade shown here, but comparing it with the deep, brooding color of pecan pie is not a stretch. Brown is a popular color for the German performance-car brand, with the deeper Anthracite Brown Metallic and Mahogany Metallic also on the menu. The Cayman starts at $53,595.

6. Pumpkin: 2015 Nissan 370Z Coupe....

The 2015 Nissan 370Z Coupe's seats: go ahead and spill that pumpkin spice latte. Or, actually, don't drink latte and drive this exhilarating car. It starts at $30,800.

....and 2015 Hyundai Veloster Turbo

Prefer your pumpkin on the outside? This 2015 Hyundai Veloster Turbo (below) is right with the current trend, seen everywhere at the Geneva Auto Show earlier this month, for electric-orange paint jobs. This one's called Vitamin C. (Pumpkin is better known for prodigious amounts of Vitamin A, of course.) The Veloster Turbo starts at $22,600.

7. Raspberry: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Coupe

Bright red is the Italian racing color, never more fitting than on this sinuous Alfa Romeo, which starts at $54,195. There's a choice of two shades of red: Rosso Alfa, as shown here, and Rosso Competizione, just a little riper-looking.

8. Rhubarb: 2015 Subaru WRX

The WRX and its more sporting sibling, the WRX STI, both come in this bright but not flashy shade of Lightning Red. Like rhubarb, it's comfortable in cold temperatures, and like rhubarb, it is very much appreciated among the cognoscenti and mistakenly overlooked by others. The WRX starts at $27,090 and the WRX STI at $34,290.

title: How Not to Get Hosed at the Car Wash
subTitle: 2 must-dos and 2 don't-bothers when you go to the neighborhood wash.
promoTitle: How Not to Get Hosed at the Car Wash
promoTeaserSmall: 2 must-dos and 2 don't-bothers when you go to the neighborhood wash.
promoTeaser: 2 must-dos and 2 don't-bothers when you go to the neighborhood wash.
keywords: How Not to Get Hosed at the Car Wash
metaTitle: How Not to Get Hosed at the Car Wash
metaDescription: 2 must-dos and 2 don't-bothers when you go to the neighborhood wash.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: When you drive up to your neighborhood car wash, you’re likely to be confronted by a blizzard of price points and option choices. Do you spring for them or just get the basic hose-off? Here are our recommendations for two options to go for and two to skip.

Two to Consider:

1. Undercarriage Flush or Wash

Especially after a long brutal winter where rock salt in the northern states and salt brine in the southern states are left clinging to the undercarriage, your car is in desperate need of TLC. Eric Wulf, CEO of the International Carwash Association, reminds us, “Today’s automotive finishes do a better job at preventing visible rust and corrosion for road salts and brines, but that doesn’t help protect equipment that is exposed to the elements under your car, with the braking systems perhaps being most important.”

2. Polish and Protect

Try a foam or tri-polish treatment to give your chariot an extra boost of shine while repelling water and debris from the surface between washes. Variations on these treatments can contain combinations of a cleaning agent, conditioner, or wax. Sometimes they’re specifically formulated to blast insect carcasses. When it comes to preserving a car's like-new sparkle, the quick wash options are no substitute for an old-school hand wax, once before winter and then again in the spring.

Two to Skip:

1. Wheel Cleaning

You may see Tire Shine or Wheel Wash on the car wash menu, but to give your tires the attention they deserve you are better off cleaning them yourself. Particulates of every kind, from antifreeze and oil-laden road sludge to brake dust, settle onto your wheels and can corrode the surface over time. Because rims come in various materials, it is best to visit your local automotive store to find the appropriate product to rejuvenate your particular wheel type. That’s also a good time to pick up some tire cleaner and dressing products to transform dull tire rubber back to black brilliance every few months.

2. Rain-X and Other "Rain Shield" Products

This popular windshield product is loved by some car enthusiasts for its water shedding properties but disdained by others because of its potential for filming or streaking. A quick spray-on version at the car wash doesn’t seem like a good bet, since precise application is key to its success. Driving through a Rain-X shower is a hit-or-miss operation. Find a reputable detailer to apply it properly and skip the random (and pricey) spray job.

subTitle: Connected luxury.

pageElements.text:
Type: Front- or all-wheel-drive mid-size luxury sedan
Price range: $45,725–$76,425 (includes destination)
Trim levels: A6: Premium, Premium Plus, Prestige; S6: Premium Plus, Prestige
Engine: A6: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 220 horsepower; 3.0-liter V-6, 310 horsepower; turbo-diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 240 horsepower
S6: Turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: A6: Eight-speed automatic, continuously variable automatic (CVT); S6: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: A6 2.0-liter automatic, 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway; A6 2.0-liter with CVT, 25/33 mpg; A6 3.0 automatic, 18/27 mpg; A6 3.0 turbo-diesel, 24/38 mpg; S6, 17/27 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Rated Good in all areas
Our favorite standard feature: Audi Connect Wi-Fi for up to eight devices
Notable standard features on this model: Voice-activated control for navigation, phone, and audio system
Notable options on this model: Night vision
You might also be considering: Cadillac CTS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Although its last full redesign was several years ago, the A6's decidedly German sheetmetal still looks fresh. Previous technical updates included a more rearward position for the engine. The sportier S6 is more expensive (in the $75,000 range), but that price includes a smooth and powerful V-8 and high-end technnology as well as Quattro all-wheel drive. The A6 has a luscious interior, featuring a wraparound dash and high-end materials. An available navigation system has a Google Earth feature and can be set up as a mobile hot spot for up to eight devices. The infotainment system includes a touchpad, capable of receiving input through handwriting. TA6 options include lane departure warning, blind spot warning, and Audi Pre Sense Plus, which will enact various safety precautions including autonomous braking and seatbelt tightening if a collision is imminent. A turbo-diesel rounds out the offerings.

New for 2015

A head-up display and full LED headlights are now standard on A6 Prestige models.

title: 2015 Audi A7
subTitle: A family of elegant fastbacks.
promoTeaserSmall: A family of elegant fastbacks.
promoTeaser: A family of elegant fastbacks.
metaKeywords: 2015 Audi A7; 2015 Audi S7; 2015 RS 7; Audi; sedan; German
metaDescription: A family of elegant fastbacks. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Front- or all-wheel-drive full-size luxury sedan
Price range: $66,825–$107,425 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Premium Plus, Prestige
Engines: A7: Supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 310 horsepower; A7 TDI: Turbo-diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 240 horsepower; S7: Turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower; RS7: Turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8, 560 horsepower
Transmissions: A7/A7 TDI/RS 7: Eight-speed automatic; S7: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): A7, 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway; A7 TDI, 24/38 mpg; S7, 17/27 mpg; RS 7, 16/27 mpg
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Audi Connect in-car Wi-Fi for up to eight devices
Notable standard features on this model: Audi Side Assist with Pre Sense Rear alerts the driver to objects in the A7’s blind spots and tightens the seatbelts during an impending rear collision
Notable options on this model: Rear side air bags, head-up display, Night Vision Assist
You might also be considering: Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class, Porsche Panamera

With a svelte profile and a massive rear hatch, the A7 pairs the elegance of a coupe with superior functionality and space, while providing the performance one expects in a high-end German car. Quattro all-wheel drive is standard across the lineup with no fewer than four engines to choose from. The base A7 can be equipped with either a 310-horsepower, supercharged V-6 or a turbo-diesel V-6 that produces 428 pound-feet of torque and achieves a respectable 38 mpg on the highway. Then there's the S7’s V-8 engine, boasting 420 horses and capable of reaching 155 mph. The RS 7’s 4.0-liter V-8 pushes the envelope even further with 560 horsepower and the ability to reach 60 mph in 3.7 seconds. It relies on a specially tuned twin-turbo V-8 to reach a top speed of 174 mph.

The cabin is designed for efficient comfort with elegant inlays. The Prestige package adds perforated leather and four-zone climate controls. The sweeping roofline encroaches on headroom in an otherwise roomy interior. Driver assistance technology abounds, including an optional head-up display and Night Vision Assist to detect pedestrians and wildlife on dark roads. Audi’s trademark Google Earth map technology is also available, as is Bang & Olufsen stereo.

New for 2015

A head-up display and full LED headlights are now standard on A7 Prestige models.

More about the Audi A7

Two Reasons to Love Diesels November 4, 2013

title: 2015 Audi A8
subTitle: Objects of desire.
promoTeaserSmall: Objects of desire.
promoTeaser: Objects of desire.
metaKeywords: 2015 A8; 2015 Audi S8; 2015 Audi W12; Audi; sedan; German
metaDescription: Objects of desire. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: All-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Price range: $78,295–$138.795 (includes destination)
Trim levels: A8, S8, W12
Engines: A8: Supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 333 horsepower; A8 TDI: Turbo-diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 240 horsepower; 4.0-liter turbocharged V-8, 435 horsepower
S8: Turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8, 520 horsepower
W12: Turbocharged 6.3-liter W-12, 500 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): A8: 3.0-liter, 19 mpg city/29 mpg highway; A8 TDI, 24/36 mpg; A8 4.0-liter, 18/30 mpg; A8 4.0-liter long wheelbase, 18/29 mpg; S8, 17/27 mpg; W12, 14/21 mpg
Safety ratings: Not yet tested
Our favorite standard feature: Audi’s Multi-Media Interface (MMI) with joystick and voice control
Notable standard features on this model: In-dash DVD player
Notable options on this model: A8 available in regular and long-wheelbase models
You might also be considering: BMW 7 Series, Jaguar XJ, Lexus LS

The A8, Audi’s top-of-the line sedan, grew a little more muscle in 2015. A more sculpted hood, wider tailpipes, reshaped LED headlights, and a beefed-up grille add personality on the outside while the 4.0-liter engine received an additional 15 horsepower for a total of 435 horsepower. For 2015, buyers will be able to choose between regular- and long-wheelbase models for both 3.0-liter and 4.0-liter A8s. The entire A8 line, which also includes the sporty S8 and the flagship W12, comes standard with Quattro all-wheel drive. High-quality, luxurious cabins also come standard with a wide variety of leather options, as well as aluminum and wood dash and door inlays. As one would expect, the A8 comes chock-full of technology including Audi’s MMI system with a touchpad designed to read handwritten instructions. Enjoy a bevy of driver assist options from a 360-degree view camera to automatic high/low beams that adjust to oncoming traffic, to blind spot detection, and much more.

Although it’s one of the larger vehicles in this pricey segment, the A8 achieves good highway fuel economy with the V-6 and the TDI returning 29 mpg and 36 mpg, respectively. The S8's 520-horsepower twin-turbo V-8 gets from 0 to 60 mph in 3.9 seconds. From the base 333-horsepower supercharged V-6 to the 500 horsepower W-12, the A8 is really about superior engineering and impressive speed as much as that classy interior.

New for 2015

The A8 and S8 get redesigned front and rear fascias.
