pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive luxury sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $49,225–$62,825 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Premium, Premium Plus, Prestige
Engine: Q7: 3.0-liter V-6, 280 horsepower; Q7 TDI: Turbo-diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 240 horsepower; Q7 S Line: Supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 333 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Q7, 16 mpg city/22 mpg highway; TDI, 19/28 mpg; S Line, 16/22 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: LED daytime running lights and taillights
Notable standard features on this model: Rest recommendation system warns driver when it detects fatigue
Notable options on this model: Offroad Style Plus package includes blacked-out fender flares and stainless steel skidplates on Premium Plus models
You might also be considering: BMW X5 sDrive35i, Infiniti QX80, Porsche Cayenne

As the roomiest Audi SUV, the Q7 is aimed at the luxury buyer who intends to bring along six passengers and tow the occasional boat as well. Fine engineering, luscious interiors, and performance are all present in the largely unchanged 2015 Q7. The few new options for 2015 include two exterior styling packages that use the Black optic theme also seen in other Audi products. Available on Premium Plus the Offroad Style Plus package offers Titanium wheels, black roof rails, fender flares, and bumpers. The Sport Style Plus package for Prestige models features oval exhaust outlets and gloss black wheels among its unique finishing touches. High-end bargain hunters will appreciate that the Q7’s base price starts below competitors like the BMW X5.

The front seats are abundantly roomy with a generous center storage compartment between driver and passenger. An available three-panel panoramic sunroof opens up the cabin beautifully and comes standard in the performance-minded S Line. The detailed and refined Q7 interior is the perfect habitat for infotainment features like navigation and parking, lane keeping, and trailer assist features.

New for 2015

Two new exterior styling packages are available for 2015: Offroad Style Plus and Sport Style Plus.

title: 2015 Buick Encore
subTitle: Emoticon on wheels.
promoTeaserSmall: Emoticon on wheels.
promoTeaser: Emoticon on wheels.
metaKeywords: 2015 Buick Encore; Buick; SUV; crossover; American
metaDescription: Emoticon on wheels. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger front- or all-wheel-drive crossover
Price: $24,990 (includes destination)
Trim level: Encore, Convenience, Leather, Premium
Engine: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: FWD: 25 mpg city/33 mpg highway; AWD: 25/30 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: 18-inch wheels
Notable standard features on this model: OnStar with 4G LTE and Wi-Fi hotspot, seven-inch display screen
Notable options on this model: Moonroof, premium seven-speaker audio, navigation, chrome wheels, heated steering wheel, oil pan heater for cold climates
You might also be considering: Mini Cooper Countryman, Volkswagen Tiguan

When the Buick Encore was introduced in 2013, the first question we asked was: Why? Who needs a short (168.4-inch) little crossover riding on 18-inch wheels? But the Encore, made in Korea, has acquitted itself well. In fact, it has opened the door in a new market segment for compact crossovers. You sit up high, surveying the road as any visionary would, and although the turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder engine is small, it has enough push to keep you on the edge of the traffic wave. Body motions are well controlled, so there’s no bobbing when weaving. The Encore excels at commuting, and for Snow Belt duty, the available all-wheel drive is an excellent choice. Meanwhile, you can choose to get heated seats in the Encore's quiet cabin where Buick’s recent expositions of good taste come to the fore, especially in the mix of dark and light tones that can be chosen instead of the all-ebony interior. And like all others from the brand, the Encore is now equipped with 4G LTE with a Wi-Fi hot spot. As we’ve grown more accustomed to the Encore after the initial shock, we’ve come to understand the answer to our question of why. The Encore is fun, versatile, easy to maneuver, and cute.

New for 2015

OnStar with 4G LTE and standard Wi-Fi hot spot

More about the Buick Encore

title: 2015 Aston Martin Vanquish
subTitle: Fine stitching and indulgence.
promoTeaserSmall: Fine stitching and indulgence.
promoTeaser: Fine stitching and indulgence.
metaKeywords: 2015 Aston Martin Vanquish; Aston Martin; British; Coupe; convertible
metaDescription: Fine stitching and indulgence. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-plus-two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury sport coupe or convertible
Price range: $287,820–$305,820 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Vanquish, Vanquish Volante convertible
Engine: 5.9-liter V-12, 568 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 13 mpg city/21mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Carbon fiber body
Notable standard features on this model: The huge, last-of-the-great redwoods, normally aspirated V-12 engine
Notable options on this model: Unpainted carbon fiber roof, door handles, mirror caps, and interior accents
You might also be considering: Ferrari F12 Berlinetta, Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT

Aston Martin says a million stitches go into every Vanquish. Now we know what it takes to craft such an exquisite, handmade interior. Leather, leather, everywhere! It’s an incomparable place to be. Available as a coupe or the Volante convertible, the Vanquish happens to have a body made entirely of carbon fiber. This helps to reduce weight (the coupe’s is 3833 pounds), which helps to result in excellent handling and acceleration: 0 to 60 mph in 3.6 seconds and a top speed of 201 mph. A new eight-speed automatic transmission smoothly handles the output. There are three selectable driving modes: normal, sport, and track. With all this performance capability, many cars would clobber you with harsh ride responses, but not so the Vanquish: in fact, the Volante thinks its always tip-toeing along in a parade with Miss Strawberry Festival balanced on the rear cowl. (And it’s very quiet inside when the multilayer cloth top is raised.) Aston Martin offers 100,000 ways to configure the interior, including—yikes!—lime-green stitching, and what with choosing the body colors and wheels, well, your computer could crash. There are even three different meshes for the hood vents. The chance your Vanquish isn’t unique is probably a million to one.

New for 2015

Eight-speed automatic transmission, Bosch engine management, retuned shock absorbers, different colors and trim, 10-spoke Star-design alloy wheels.

More about the Aston Martin Vanquish

Automotive Holiday Baubles November 11, 2013

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Lincoln revealed its New York Auto Show concept—a full-size luxury car—to a small group of journalists on Sunday evening in New York City. The Continental Concept drew rare applause from the typically stoic auto writers when it made its debut appearance.
The first shock was the Continental Concept’s show color, a deep blue called Rhapsody Blue Metallic, which chief designer David Woodhouse calls Lincoln’s “signature color.”

The side profile is sleek and unbroken, thanks to door handles that settle discreetly into the beltline and are opened with the touch of a finger. A beautiful, wide, and interesting unbroken band of chrome rings the Continental at the very bottom, anchoring the strong shape and holding the lovely quad exhaust at the rear. Who knew chrome could look this good?

The grille anchors a brand-new face for Lincoln, showcasing a raised Lincoln badge that’s surrounded by repeating aluminum Lincoln emblems. Slender taillamps stretch the full width of the rear. Headlamps are typically high-tech, just part of the suite of technologies and material that come together to accentuate Lincoln’s new “Quiet Luxury” tagline.

The interior is a hedonistic delight, with luscious leathers (including seats that adjust thirty ways and include detachable Venetian leather travel cases on the front-seat backs that smell like…leather!), a chrome work lap tray that rises from the rear seat center console (which also chills champagne), and a full SmartGlass® panorama sunroof that can block out 99 percent of UV rays with the touch of a button.

The super-duper audio system was designed by Harman Kardon’s Revel group under an exclusive ten-year deal with Lincoln. Harman Kardon claims there is more tech in this system than any automotive audio system they’ve ever developed.
The Continental Concept will be a must-see car at the show, a car that hints of Bentley and Maybach—no bad thing.
Under the hood is a twin-turbocharged, 3.0-liter EcoBoost V-6.

Lincoln also brings to bear its vast knowledge of driver assist technologies to the Continental Concept, including pre-collision assist with pedestrian detection and enhanced park assist that will parallel park as well as perpendicular park your car for you.

The Continental Concept will be a must-see car at the show, a car that hints of Bentley and Maybach—no bad thing. CEO Mark Fields coyly suggests it is “a strong indication of the production car” to come. Lincoln dealers have been desperately waiting for this, and it can’t come soon enough.

images.caption: Mark Fields, Ford President and CEO.

title: Openbay Expands into Diagnostics
subTitle: A new app to figure out what's wrong with your car and find you a good price on repairs.
promoTeaserSmall: A new app to figure out what's wrong with your car and find you a good price on repairs.
promoTeaser: A new app to figure out what's wrong with your car and find you a good price on repairs.
metaDescription: A new app to figure out what's wrong with your car and find you a good price on repairs.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: There are some things you can’t do with an app. But, as of today, diagnosing your car’s problems is no longer on that list. Openbay, an app that lets car owners obtain competing quotes from local auto repair shops, announced the launch of a new diagnostic feature called OpenbayConnect at the New York International Auto Show today.

Most vehicles manufactured in 1996 and after are equipped with an on-board diagnostic (OBD) system that activates an alert like your “Check Engine” light when a mechanical problem is detected. OpenbayConnect gathers the car’s data when you insert a compatible OBD II device, supplied by Openbay and plugged into your car’s OBD port.  This is the same port, often located behind the steering wheel, that mechanics use to diagnose vehicle problems.

OpenbayConnect accesses this diagnostic information in real time and notifies you via your smartphone account. If it’s a simple fix like “tighten your gas cap,” you can take care of it yourself. If there’s something more serious going on, Openbay’s app will send the data for that problem to participating mechanics for quotes, which you can then accept or ignore.

Rob Infantino, founder and CEO of Openbay, explains the service this way. “It all happens seamlessly. You’re driving down the road, we know who you are, your VIN, your error codes and environmental information. All that data converts to a solution. We know your thermostat failed. It’s a $35 part and a half hour of labor, and we have five shops that can do it on Thursday.”

We downloaded Openbay's app at the App Store and found there aren’t many service providers signed up yet in our town. However, Openbay has about 20,000 active service providers signed up to work with the app, mostly concentrated in major metropolitan areas such as Boston, Atlanta, Chicago, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C. Good news for you, if you’re an Uber-using, smartphone-addicted city dweller with a car you need to pay more attention to.

OpenbayConnect hasn't launched yet, but you can get on the invitation list here.

title: 2015 Toyota Corolla
subTitle: An affordable sedan with some great features.
promoTeaserSmall: An affordable sedan with some great features.
promoTeaser: An affordable sedan with some great features.
metaDescription: An affordable sedan with some great features. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Price range: $17,775—$23,780 (includes destination)
Trim levels: L, LE, S, LE Eco
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 132/140 horsepower
Transmissions: Four-speed automatic, six-speed manual, continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 1.8-liter manual: 28 mpg city/37 mpg highway; 1.8-liter automatic: 27/36 mpg; 1.8-liter CVT: 29/37–38 mpg; Eco CVT: 30/40–42 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: 4 Good and 1 Marginal rating; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Tilting and telescoping steering wheel; rearview camera (standardon LE)
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth connectivity
Notable options on this model: Multimedia and navigation package
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Cruze, Ford Focus, Hyundai Elantra, Mazda 3

To say there are a lot of Corollas navigating the world’s streets is an understatement: Toyota reports over 40 million sold since 1966. In many ways, it’s the perfect car for commuting. Great mileage comes standard across the Corolla lineup but the Eco trim achieves 40 or more mpg on the highway—that’s hybrid territory. The Corolla L comes with air conditioning, a steering wheel that tilts and telescopes, and Bluetooth. The LE adds a number of safety and convenience features like cruise control, a rearview camera, and the Entune multimedia system. Rear legroom is downright generous for a compact car, but don’t expect to fill those rear seats with anyone looking for a thrill ride. Although the Corolla’s ride is better than expected, handling is uninspiring. Regardless, the Corolla fulfills its mission of being an affordable and reliable car: a sensible car for sensible people.

New for 2015

Premium trim brings technology to the entry-level sedan with the Entune audio and media bundle for navigation, music, and access to Toyota apps.

title: 2015 Toyota Land Cruiser
subTitle: There's a definite Lawrence of Arabia feeling to this rugged SUV.
promoTeaserSmall: There's a definite Lawrence of Arabia feeling to this rugged SUV.
promoTeaser: There's a definite Lawrence of Arabia feeling to this rugged SUV.
metaKeywords: 2015 Toyota Land Cruiser; Toyota; Japanese; SUV; sport-utility
metaDescription: There's a definite Lawrence of Arabia feeling to this rugged SUV. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Eight-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $81,475 (includes destination)
Trim level: Land Cruiser
Engine: 5.7-liter V-8, 381 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 13 mpg city/18 mpg highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety & National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Full-time all-wheel drive
Notable standard features on this model: Hill descent control
Notable options on this model: Blizzard Pearl paint ($395) is the only option
You might also be considering: Cadillac Escalade, Land Rover Range Rover, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class

The Land Cruiser is a hard worker with full-time all-wheel drive to take you over hill and dale and back again. It’s big and bulky but, even around town, it’s amazingly agile, and the large, upright windows allow for a commanding view of the surroundings. The Land Cruiser only comes in one trim, but you won’t be disappointed: among the features are heated and ventilated front seats, an eight-inch infotainment display, a rear entertainment system, and a cooler box. A third row is also included, pushing seating capacity to eight. It can be split and folded flat to either side of the cargo area to allow for increased cargo space, although not as much as other vehicles where the third row disappears into the floor. The 5.7-liter V-8 eagerly rises to any occasion and allows the Land Cruiser to tow up to 8,500 pounds. As you might expect, fuel economy isn’t great: it gets a scant 13 mpg in the city but improves to 18 mpg on the open road. Adventurous types will like the Multi-Terrain Select system that allows the driver to choose one of several settings to match the current road or off-road conditions. For $81,475, it’s a little disappointing to see faux wood decorating the interior in this otherwise well-appointed sport-utility vehicle. A big vehicle that doesn’t cross the line into monster huge, the Land Cruiser has surprisingly nimble handling, good visibility, and Toyota reliability, making it worth serious consideration.

New for 2015

The Land Cruiser is unchanged this year.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu
subTitle: The long-running sedan gets a whole new look and a 47-mpg hybrid version. Does it catch your eye?
promoTeaserSmall: The long-running sedan gets a whole new look and a 47-mpg hybrid version. Does it catch your eye?
promoTeaser: The long-running sedan gets a whole new look and a 47-mpg hybrid version. Does it catch your eye?
metaDescription: The long-running sedan gets a whole new look and a 47-mpg hybrid version. Does it catch your eye?

pageElements.text:
Type: Front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder with stop/start technology; optional turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder; hybrid model with 1.8-liter gasoline engine, two-motor drive unit, and lithium-ion battery
Transmission: Six-speed automatic (with 1.5-liter engine); eight-speed automatic (with 2.0-liter engine)
Most interesting feature: Optional front pedestrian alert with automatic braking
Potential competitors: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Toyota Camry

Chevrolet unveiled a completely redone version of its long-lived Malibu at the New York Auto Show today, one that's bigger, yet sleeker-looking. You may feel like you've been looking at Malibus forever, and you'd be right: this is the ninth generation of the sedan, which was first introduced in 1964. This one has joined the 21st century with a 4G LTE Wi-Fi hot spot standard on all models, wireless charging on upper-level models, and a strong slate of active safety features available as options.

Like its looks? Mid-size sedans are getting prettier, which is good news for people looking to buy in this most popular automotive segment. The new Malibu is longer, lower, and more like its big brother, the Impala. The wheelbase is almost four inches longer, with one result being 1.3 inches more rear legroom. I personally observed as a freakishly tall journalist in the 6'6" range clambered into the back seat and looked comfortable. This gives the Malibu a great deal more credibility as a family car.

The Malibu comes in L, LS, LT, and new Premier levels, and there’s a Malibu Hybrid set up in the same style as the automaker’s Volt, with a two-motor drive unit, lithium-ion battery, and gasoline engine. Chevrolet promises “north of 45 mpg combined” from the hybrid model.

Fuel economy is predicted at 22/32 mpg for the 2.0-liter turbo engine and 27/37 mpg for the standard 1.5-liter. That’s on par for the mid-size segment, with the comparable Fusion at 22/33 mpg, the Accord at 26/35 mpg, and the Camry at 25/35 mpg.

Forward collision alert, rear cross-traffic alert, park assist, blind spot monitoring, front pedestrian alert, and adaptive cruise control with front automatic braking are all available options. A rearview camera is standard on all but the base model. Then there's the Teen Driver feature, a monitoring setup that lets you spy on (and set limits to) your kids' driving through the infotainment screen by using a special key fob. Attention, shoppers: This kind of safety and security equipment is a very good reason to think about getting a new car these days.
You'll be able to shop for the 2016 Malibu before the end of the year.

images.caption: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu with that distinctive split grille.

title: 2015 Toyota Venza
subTitle: Making an effort.
promoTeaserSmall: Making an effort.
promoTeaser: Making an effort.
metaDescription: Making an effort. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: SUV/crossover
Price range: $29,890–$40,765 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LE, XLE, Limited
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 181 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): I-4, FWD: 20/26; I-4, AWD: 20/26; V-6, FWD: 19/26; V-6, AWD: 18/25 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Back-up sensors
Notable standard features on this model: Hill start assist control to lessen rollback on inclines.
Notable options on this model: A tilt-and-slide panoramic sunroof
You might also be considering: Ford Edge, Honda Crosstour, Subaru Outback

Toyota’s marriage between sedan and SUV comes in an attractive well-proportioned vehicle intended to fit in at the soccer fields, the weekend cottage, or for a night at the opera. Family oriented at its core, the Venza has an ample 36.2 cubic feet of cargo space behind the second row. The large liftgate allows for easy access and the low load floor helps save your back. The base LE comes with helpful dual zone climate control, display screen, and reading lights for the spacious rear seat row. The XLE and Limited models get more standard luxury features like heated seats, a leather trimmed steering wheel, and keyless entry and start. The Limited is powered by the 3.5-liter V-6 mated to all-wheel drive, delivering the power and handling expected for $40,000. Otherwise the LE and XLE offer your choice of front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive and the XLE can be fitted with the base four-cylinder or upgraded to the V-6. For $2000, the V-6 is a bit of a no-brainer since it gets nearly the same gas millage as the four-cylinder and moves the Venza with an authority the four just can’t match. The look and feel of the Venza’s interior won’t win any awards—the ivory leather is quite nice though—but it is well organized and has modern features like a USB connection and 12-volt outlets to keep the family happy.

New for 2015

The Tow Prep Package is now standard on V-6 models. It comes with a larger radiator fan and a heavy-duty alternator to help handle loads of up to 3,500 pounds. A sonar-based backup sensor is now standard on all Venza’s.

title: 2016 Jaguar XF
subTitle: Aluminum, folded into a very handsome shape.
promoTeaserSmall: Aluminum, folded into a very handsome shape.
promoTeaser: Aluminum, folded into a very handsome shape.
metaDescription: Aluminum, folded into a very handsome shape.

pageElements.text:
Type: Rear- and all-wheel-drive sedan
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: Supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 350 horsepower (standard), supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 380 horsepower (optional)
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Most interesting feature: “Aluminum-intensive” architecture
Potential competitors: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Lexus GS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Jaguar is wisely milking the James Bond appeal of its product lineup. So it's only logical that the very first look we got of the new XF is when the automaker had a stuntman drive the new XF on a high wire in London last week. Devastating good looks are what this brand is all about, after all.

Having said that, this is not a supercar but a V-6-powered luxury sedan, and it has plenty of heavyweight competition from the likes of Audi, BMW,  Mercedes-Benz, and Lexus. One way Jaguar is facing off is to cut weight and improve interior space. This all-new XF has one very significant difference: it is made of 75 percent aluminum, saving as much as 265 pounds of weight on the all-wheel-drive version. The body is shorter and lower-slung but on a two-inch-longer wheelbase to improve rear passenger comfort.

The standard and R-Sport models come with the 350-horsepower V-6, and the XF S with the 380-horsepower V-6. An optional infotainment system is new, with a 10.2-inch touchscreen (the standard screen is eight inches). You can also get a 12.3-inch instrument cluster of the type also seen on the corporate cousin Range Rover.

Among the other options are full LED headlights, a laser head-up display, configurable dynamics (first seen on the F-Type) to let you choose your personal favorite suspension, steering, engine, and transmission settings, plus an adaptive dynamics suspension system.
The new Jag goes on sale before the end of the year.

title: 2016 Lexus RX
subTitle: The popular luxury crossover, now with added goose bumps.
promoTeaserSmall: The popular luxury crossover, now with added goose bumps.
promoTeaser: The popular luxury crossover, now with added goose bumps.
metaDescription: The popular luxury crossover, now with added goose bumps.

pageElements.text:
2016 Lexus RX350

Type: Front- and all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 300 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Most interesting feature: Safety System Plus active safety technology package
Potential competitors: Acura MDX, Audi Q5, BMW X3, Porsche Macan, Land Rover Range Rover Evoque
Here’s the fourth generation of a vehicle that Lexus execs have been calling “the world’s first luxury crossover SUV” since its introduction seventeen years ago.

The latest version of this hot seller features increased dimensions, more interior volume, fancier furnishings, quieter operation, new safety features, a more contemporary exterior, and an even bolder expression of the division’s so-called spindle grille—especially in the more performance-oriented F-Sport edition.
Pretty much all of the foregoing could describe a good many of the new vehicles on display at the New York Auto Show.
The 2016 RX claims one distinction that’s unique: the goose bump factor.
Lexus execs claim that the new RX has earned Mr. Toyoda’s goose bump blessing, which had to have made the engineers and product planners breathe easier.
Aside from that, specifics concerning the new RX were scarce.
It’s bigger, on a longer wheelbase, and with agility credentials capable of pleasing Mr. Toyoda, pleasing him even more in the F-Sport versions.

When it goes on sale it will be propelled by a 3.5-liter V-6, a familiar displacement in the Toyota/Lexus power inventory, expected to generate 300 horsepower, on regular fuel. The hybrid version will be an update on the gasoline/electric system common to other Toyota products. No word regarding fuel economy expectations.
There will be one transmission, an eight-speed automatic, and all-wheel drive will be on the option list.

There’s also a new Safety System Plus package that includes a pre-collision system, pedestrian detection, lane keeping assist, and dynamic radar cruise control capable of autonomous braking, available for “less than $650,” according to Lexus.
Lexus says the RX will be in showrooms at the end of the year.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Base price: $107,920
This car: $118,751 (prices include destination charge)
Engine: Supercharged 5.0-liter V-8, 510 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/19 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Navigation system with intuitive voice control
Option I can’t live without: Four-zone climate control ($3,200), Vision Assist package (includes blind spot monitor, reverse traffic detection, xenon headlamps, surround camera, $1,760)
Notable standard features on this model: Electronic air suspension with automatic load leveling; all-terrain dynamic stability control; front and rear park distance control; rearview camera; extended panoramic roof
Notable options on this model: Lane departure warning, perpendicular and parallel park, 360-degree park distance control (Driver Assistance package, $1,560); Tow package ($1,300); Meridian premium audio ($2,150); ebony headliner and leather-wrapped steering wheel ($350)
You might also be considering: 2015 Cadillac Escalade ($76,565), 2015 Lexus LX570 ($85,030), 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL63 AMG ($120,375) (prices include destination charges)

I am a member of a most fortunate generation of automotive journalists: we’re the ones who were on the ground floor of Land Rover’s official entry into the United States, in 1987. The venerable British company was represented by one vehicle, the Range Rover, for the first couple of years. But what a vehicle.
Somehow, a solitary PR man named William Baker spun that single iconoclastic off-roader—made by a company that holds a Royal Warrant as supplier to the Queen—into pure gold.

Baker created fantastical adventures for journalists in the most desolate, far-flung, and seemingly impassable places on Earth. His team invited us to learn how to fearlessly plunge these four-wheeled mountain goats blindly off the edges of cliffs, to dive into rivers that lapped the Range Rover’s hood, and to confidently set off on adventures of a lifetime. There wasn’t an enthusiast car magazine that didn’t publish at least one multipage, full-color Range Rover story every year.

Looking only at my own personal list of Range Rover stories, you’ll find wild accounts from the Great Divide, the rainforest of Belize, Iceland’s glaciers, remote rivers in Scotland, the Camel Trophy of Madagascar, and the desolate Little Karoo in the Western Cape of South Africa, where I was raced by a herd of ostriches. They won.
Not that the people buying Range Rovers in record numbers will be taking theirs anywhere at all like that. Just saying.
But it’s good to know that Range Rovers will go anywhere that four wheels and four-wheel drive can transport you, right?
Over the years, its suspension became more sophisticated, and its exterior design has morphed significantly from the tweedy luxury of the old days.

This 2015 Range Rover Supercharged Long Wheelbase (LWB) is no exception. It’s ready for virtually everything you have to throw at it, from a jaunt across the Gobi to an evening at La Scala. And after paying $118,751 for it, you really ought to consider giving it that kind of momentous assignment. The first Range Rover was a tall, narrow box that felt much better off the road than on it. Over the years, its suspension became more sophisticated, and its exterior design has morphed significantly from the tweedy luxury of the old days.

The change to the current, curvaceous aesthetic began when BMW acquired it for a minute in the 1990s. At that time, the engine became a reliable and powerful BMW, and the design and materials, both inside and outside, soared under the direction of quirky, chain-smoking chief designer Geoff Upex. When the equally quirky Gerry McGovern stepped in to the chief designer position at Land Rover, well, goodbye Wellies, hello Cristal.
Are we complaining? No, we are not. And neither would you, behind the wheel of the 2015 Range Rover.

The Range Rover Supercharged LWB, as its name declares, has a 5.0-liter, 510-horsepower supercharged V-8. It’s teamed with an eight-speed automatic transmission and paddle shifters. Punch the pedal to pass on a two-lane road, and the Range Rover immediately delivers the power in a manner that will make you think of rollercoasters. This 5,320-pound luxury liner offers a 0-to-60-mph time of 5.7 seconds, with a staggering top speed of 155 mph. No, I did not come close to 155 mph on any terrain.

Beyond sheer power, there is sheer capability. This Range Rover brings it with an electronic air suspension and auto load leveling, plus full-time all-wheel drive, plus an upgraded Terrain Response 2 auto-adaptive off-road driving system with individual settings for different types of terrain. Icing on the cake is the advertised maximum wading depth of 35.4 inches. Tempting!

The LWB model we drove extends the classic Range Rover profile with 7.8 more inches of wheelbase, 11.1 more cubic feet of cargo space in back, and 7.3 more inches of rear legroom, along with massive rear doors. Rear-seat occupants in the LWB model can stretch out like they are in business class on Virgin Atlantic.

The distinctive look of a Range Rover is part of what you’re paying for, and the automaker has wisely not diluted or changed it much over the years. Like the Royal Family it serves, the company has evolved without changing its essential personality. Yet the look is quite modern. In profile, the current Range Rover has a very defined waistline that is integrated into both the headlights (themselves worthy of a museum catalog) and the taillights.

Three shark-like vertical gills on the front doors are a graphic illusion—not functional, but very elegant. Completing the side profile view is a floating roof. That’s designer-speak for a roof that has the illusion of floating above the body. Range Rovers have been sporting this design feature for decades. The going-away view is understated, with stacked square taillights that complete the package.

The interior of the Range Rover is flawless. Aluminum accents, dark wood, and supple leather remind you that every nook and cranny has been refined to a fare-thee-well. The view through the steering wheel perfectly exposes every detail of the digital dash; no need to rock your head from side to side. The transmission shifter pops up from the center console, in the style of corporate sibling Jaguar, when you push the start button. It may sound gimmicky, but it quickly becomes effortless. The glove box is two separate compartments, both accessible via a large button. Our test car included the Four Zone Climate Comfort package ($3,200). That sounds awfully pricey, but it is actually jam-packed with desirable features: heated and cooling seats for all passengers, plus rear-seat power lumbar support and power blinds in back. Massaging seats, however, are reserved for the special derrières up front. They were more nudge than massage—useful to make a long drive less exhausting, but not quite on a level with the Brookstone massaging seats at the local mall.

This package also includes a cool box tucked into the center console, and a special windshield that helps keep the interior cooler. As the outside temperature was hovering around 30 degrees (a Michigan heat wave!), there was no need for it to actually work.

Standard fog lights are new for 2015. Our test vehicle also had adaptive xenon headlights with automatic high beam assist, part of the optional Vision Assist package. The combination of grille, headlights, and large horizontal finned vents adds up to an imposing face that commands attention.
Although there was no stream fording or mountain diving involved in our week with this Range Rover, it was a hands-down five-star experience.

Modern safety features are available, including blind spot monitoring, rear traffic detection, and a rearview camera. The options list also includes lane departure warning and parallel and perpendicular parking assist. Our test vehicle had the tow package ($1,300), premium audio ($2,150), and an ebony headliner and leather-wrapped steering wheel ($350).

Although there was no stream fording or mountain diving involved in our week with this Range Rover (not our $118,751), it was a hands-down five-star experience for the Jean Knows Cars staff. Especially notable—the Holy Grail in this category—is the large touchscreen that easily led you to your desired destination. We heard angels singing when we spied SET DESTINATION right on the home screen. It changes to CANCEL GUIDANCE, so you don’t need to dig three screens deep to make the car quit barking directions at you. Every button was perfectly placed, except the window controls that were awkwardly high on the doorsill. They’ve always been awkward in some way or another on Range Rovers. This is clearly not a deal breaker, nor is the 14 mpg city/19 mpg highway, because seriously, at this lofty price point, does mileage really matter?

The Verdict:

Do you want to go off road in style? Here’s your vehicle. Do you simply want to travel in royal comfort, with rear-seat passengers stretched out like so many house cats, at a completely effortless 80 mph on the freeway? Here’s your vehicle. The Range Rover has competitors as the luxury-SUV market grows, but it has no peer when it comes to Anglophile, old-school-tie, empire-exploring history. You may find yourself humming “Land of Hope and Glory,” and who can blame you?

images.caption: Front cooler box on 2015 Range Rover Supercharged LWB.
Spacious rear seating area in 2015 Range Rover Supercharged LWB.
Meridian premium audio is a $2,150 option on the 2015 Range Rover Supercharged LWB.

The Kia Forte model range includes a sedan; the Forte5, a four-door hatchback; and a coupe called the Koup. The most basic LX sedan includes a 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine making 145 horsepower and a six-speed manual transmission. A six-speed automatic is optional, and it brings the best fuel economy of 39 highway mpg. The Forte LX has some key features like satellite radio, Bluetooth, power windows, and air conditioning. To this basic, inexpensive starting point, you can add a touchscreen, 16-inch alloy wheels, and a backup camera. Moving to the EX model, you find options packages that can give the car many unexpected luxury features. We do love a heated steering wheel. Heated and ventilated seats are available, too. The Koup is sporty, with the 2.0-liter and six-speed manual as standard but a powerful turbocharged 1.6-liter and an available automatic transmission with paddle shifters. EX and SX trim levels are offered, and the EX includes a leather-wrapped steering wheel and LED positioning lamps. Available eighteen-inch alloy wheels give the Koup an aggressive stance. Many of the sedan’s more premium options are found here in both trim levels. Sharing the Koup’s powertrain selection, the Forte5 is a handsome and more upscale four-door hatchback. Meanwhile, with up to 23.2 cubic feet of cargo capacity, the 5 adds a measure of utility to the lineup without sacrificing sportiness.

New for 2015

Improved fuel economy for the sedan.

subTitle: Boldly striking forth.

pageElements.text:

Trim levels: LX, EX, SX, SX Turbo, SXL Turbo, Hybrid, Hybrid EX

Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.4-liter: 23/34; 2.0-liter: 20/31; Hybrid: 36/40; Hybrid EX: 35/39 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, head restraints & seats) and acceptable (small overlap front); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Brake assist system
Notable standard features on this model: Satellite radio, 6-speaker stereo, cooling glove box, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, cruise control, driver assistance features
Notable options on this model: Power folding mirrors, panoramic sunroof, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry

In a competitive market segment, the Kia Optima stands out because of its great design. It’s more daring, slightly larger, and somehow more premium-looking than most. We do a double-take whenever we see one. In addition to the Optima’s good looks, there’s a powertrain and trim level for everybody. The LX, EX, and SX have the direct-injection 2.4-liter four-cylinder that puts out 192 horsepower and gets 34 highway mpg. The SX and SXL Turbos have the turbocharged, direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 274 horsepower. The Hybrid and Hybrid EX combine the 2.4-liter four-cylinder with an electric drive system that incorporates a 47-kilowatt lithium-polymer battery. Each of the above cars uses a six-speed automatic. The LX is equipped with fog lamps, heated side mirrors, satellite radio, Bluetooth connectivity, a six-way power driver’s seat, and a package of electronically controlled safety and assistance features. The UVO2 eServices infotainment system is optional. The Hybrid’s standard equipment is much like that of the LX, while the Hybrid EX adds the infotainment system, rearview camera, and heated steering wheel. Climbing the trim level ladder to the SXL Turbo, we arrive at an elevated refuge of luxury of convenience, represented by a heated flat-bottom steering wheel with unique stitching, seats trimmed with Nappa leather trim, black gloss accents throughout the interior. Specified this way, it’s one of the ultimate choices available among front-drive midsize sedans.

New for 2015

UVO2 eServices infotainment system now offers Geo Fencing, Driving Score, Speed Alert, and Curfew Alert functions. Cruise control buttons are repositioned on the steering wheel, an acoustic laminated windshield is offered in all models, and white stitching is included on the SXL’s leather-wrapped steering wheel.

More about the Kia Optima

2016 Kia Optima at the New York Auto Show April 2, 2015

You might also be considering: Dodge Journey, Ford Edge, Toyota Highlander

The Sorento is Kia’s answer to the Toyota Highlander and other leading midsize crossovers, and if it were a Jeopardy question it would be the Daily Double. It’s as good looking as any entry in this segment, and it goes down the highway with real poise. It can be loaded up to a fare-thee-well with convenience and luxury features, but even the LX—the lowest trim level—comes standard with some key safety features like stability control, antilock brakes, and active front headrests. Naturally, all-wheel drive is available. The direct-injection, 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine would at first glance seem to be insufficient, but indeed it’s up to the task of propelling this 3594-pound crossover. The direct-injection 3.3-liter V-6 definitely adds muscle, though, and towing capacity rises from 1650 to 3500 pounds. The Sorento is equipped with Flex Steer, which allows the driver to select the steering effort among comfort, normal, and sport modes. Inside, there’s a seven-inch instrument panel display and an eight-inch touchscreen for infotainment. Bluetooth connectivity is standard. Seating splits and folds every which way. The Sorento is tough to overlook because it has the right combination of appearance, performance, technology, and feature content.

New for 2015

There are no changes for 2015.

More about the Kia Sorento

2016 Kia Sorento SX AWD, Should You Buy It? March 20, 2015

pageElements.text:

Price range: $16,015–$36,525 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Soul, Soul Plus, Soul Exclaim, Soul EV, Soul EV Plus
Engines: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 130 horsepower; 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower
Transmissions: 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic, or single-speed (EV)
Fuel economy (mpg): 1.6: 24/30; 2.0 automatic: 23/31; 2.0-liter, automatic with ISG: 24/31; EV: 120/92 (city/highway; mpg-e)
Safety ratings: Institute for Highway Safety: Top safety pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating

Notable options on this model: 18-inch wheels, panoramic sunroof with power-operated sunshade, LED tail lamps, pulsating speaker lights
You might also be considering: Fiat 500, Ford Fiesta, Mini Cooper,

The Kia Soul is a joy to drive, you will never lose it in a parking lot, and people will always want to ask you about it. Proving way more popular than expected after being released in 2009, the Soul brings a quirky kind of custom to the low-price arena. It was extensively revised for 2014, and the result was astonishing. The little runabout has a more solid feel and significantly improved ride and handling. Partly due to a stronger body, the vehicle is quieter. Kia spent some money to upgrade the interior, so it grew more attractive and interesting, with more comfortable seats and greater front legroom. The body’s front and rear were redone, adding drama, and the designers really smacked one out of the park when creating the Soul Exclaim’s cool new high-tech LED tail lamps. For the price, you’ll be surprised by the feature content, with an available heated and ventilated front seats and an infotainment system with excellent Android-based navigation display. The larger direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder packs enough wallop to make this light-middleweight quite entertaining on a back road. For 2015, the Soul EV joined the lineup. Its 90-kilowatt battery can deliver up to 93 miles of range, a top speed of 90 mph, and 0 to 60 mph acceleration in 11.2 seconds. Whichever Soul you choose will be a long-lasting statement of individualism—and good thing a car like this is on the market.

New for 2015

Soul EV

title: BMW Made My Daughter a Driver
subTitle: I took my teenage daughter to BMW Performance Driving School.
promoTitle: BMW Made My Daughter a Driver
promoTeaserSmall: I took my teenage daughter to BMW Performance Driving School.
promoTeaser: I took my teenage daughter to BMW Performance Driving School.
keywords: BMW Made My Daughter a Driver
metaTitle: BMW Made My Daughter a Driver - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: I took my teenage daughter to BMW Performance Driving School.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: “I’m scared, Mom. I don’t know how to do this. I want to go home!”

The weekend started with my sixteen-year-old daughter, Ava, whispering these words to me as we sat down in the classroom portion of her weekend at BMW Performance Driving School. The room was full of teenagers. To me, none of them looked older or more confident than her. But she was clearly spooked.

Days later, though, I have to remind myself that’s how the weekend started. Because when it ended, I overheard her laughing with her new friends and asking, “Did you see me toss that BMW? I nailed that double lane change at 40 mph! How’d you do?”
I overheard her laughing with her new friends and asking, "Did you see me toss that BMW? I nailed that double lane change at 40 mph!"

It's astonishing what a difference it made for my daughter's confidence to have two days on a closed track under the expert tutelage of professional drivers. But not nearly as astonishing as the skills she learned. She now understands the stopping distance of a vehicle at everything from 20 to 70 miles per hour, can recover a vehicle that’s spinning out of control without herself spinning out of control, can dodge an accident on the Interstate by “tossing” the car through an escape route into another lane and back, and knows some very important things about driving safety that many adults will never know. I think, now, I might be ready, not just willing, to let her drive.

Usually these weekend BMW performance driving schools are for teenagers only. Parents are allowed—encouraged—to take an adult driving school simultaneously. In fact, the schools are scheduled to make this possible. But parents are not allowed in the room—or in the cars—with the teenagers. The instructors insist this is necessary to keep the teens focused on driving and listening to the teachers, not worrying about what Mom or Dad think.

I was allowed in because this class was a special media-only event. “If this was a normal class,” Derek Leonard, the driving instructor who was running the show and giving the lectures, told us, “I would tell the kids that when they are done with class, their parents will ask what it was like.” To the teenagers he said, “You, being teenagers, will want to say, 'Good.' Or 'Fine' or something just as irritatingly vague. So I’m giving you something to tell them right now. Are you listening? Tell them their mirrors are wrong. Because I guarantee you that they are. Everyone’s mirrors are wrong.”

These instructors, all of whom make a living driving racing cars or teaching other people to drive them, have some pet peeves about the way we mortals drive. We drive with our hands on the wrong place on the steering wheel, we drive distracted, we look in the wrong places, we brake the wrong way. They see it every day on the roads. And they are aiming to fix the world, one teenager at a time.

Why teenagers? Not only are car accidents the number-one killer of teenagers, who are the most inexperienced drivers on the road. But teenagers haven’t had time yet to learn any bad habits. So they are easy to fix.
Next up after mirrors, which, for the record, none of these teenagers will ever get wrong now: eyes.

“Look where you want the car to go!” Derek declared, chastised, shouted, whispered, and laughed. (He said it so often, he asked us to count how many times he said it.) People look behind them when they merge lanes, they look right at the thing they don’t want to hit, they look the way the car is going instead of the way they want it to go when things go wrong. This is a habit so essential to driving that Derek was driving it home by word, demonstration, and heart-pounding, visceral in-car lessons.

First the teens broke up into buddy pairs, and each pair got into a BMW 335i. Then they warmed up on a slalom to get used to the cars, get over their jitters, and get accustomed to taking direction from the instructors via in-car walkie-talkies.

Then, first things first. If you are going to go, you have to learn to stop. So the first lesson was braking. Which also included a demonstration of looking where you want the car to go. But these driving instructors do not brake the way the rest of us do. New cars have anti-lock brakes (ABS). But many adults were taught to "pump" the brakes because, before ABS, that’s what you did unless you wanted the steering to lock up. So that’s what we often teach our kids. It’s wrong. With anti-lock brakes, you need to slam that brake as hard as you possibly can to stop the car in a panic situation.

So the teens started at 20 miles per hour and practiced slamming the brakes until they could stop that thing fast enough to make their hair fly and to challenge the seatbelts. At first they were scared. Then they got determined. Then they got good at it. When they got that right, they did the same thing at 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 miles per hour.
Locking up ABS brakes at 60 mph is thrilling. And it tells you a lot about how much time you need to stop a car going that fast. After that, I doubt very much that my daughter will ever tailgate.

Next up? The skidpad. This doughnut-shaped track is built from slick pavement and doused constantly with sprinklers to keep it wet. Ava got behind the wheel of a BMW 335i, with an instructor coaching her from the passenger's seat, and drove around the circle until the instructor either pulled the e-brake or asked her to give the car a burst of gas so the car would spin out.
She got to experience a car out of control in a situation where she wouldn’t get hurt, over and over until she could master it. Every teenager should get to do that.

She had to practice over and over until she could bring the car back under control. She got to experience a car out of control in a situation where she wouldn’t get hurt, but she also got to experience it over and over until she could master it, calmly. Every teenager should get to do that. She also learned how important it is to look where you want the car to go, if you want to master this skill.

Then she was on to the water wall, where walls of water shoot randomly out of the track and the teens have to avoid it. It’s fun. It’s a game. And then they have to do it while talking on the walkie-talkie while one of the instructors asks trivia questions. This is fun, too. And when they fail to avoid the water, run off the track, or nearly kill one of the event photographers because they were looking at him instead of where they wanted the car to go (that’s another story), they can see clearly how driving distracted can get them (or someone else) killed. A much better lesson than anything else I have seen on the perils of texting while driving. “It’s not that texting is the bogeyman,” says Derek. “It’s that you are looking at your phone, not where you want the car to go.”

Before Ava attended BMW’s teen driving school, she was a tentative driver. Her lack of confidence fed my fear of giving her the keys. And it was all moot because I own a manual-transmission car, and she believed she was incapable of learning to drive that, no matter how many times I offered to teach her.
We were only there two days. But it would have taken her years of road driving to gain this much ability and belief in her own skills.

She and I had a blast at our weekend at driving school. We both made friends and learned a lot of specific driving skills. But the confidence she gained is why every teenager needs to do this. We were only there two days. But it would have taken her years of road driving to gain this much ability and the belief in her own skills.
On the way home, she asked, “Hey, when can I learn to drive your car? A stick? That sounds like fun.” And I didn’t freak out. It would be fun. She’ll be good at it.

Want to Go?

BMW Performance Driving School costs $1,295 for the full two-day course for teens. A one-day course costs $775. Students must be at least fifteen years old, with a valid learner's permit. There are courses for adults, too. They're held in Spartanburg, South Carolina, and Thermal, California (near Palm Springs).

title: 2015 Volkswagen Eos
subTitle: On its farewell tour.

promoTeaser: On its farewell tour.

pageElements.text:
Type: Convertible
Price range: $37,010–$43,610 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Komfort, Final Edition, Executive
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 200 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 22/30 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good (moderate overlap front, side, head restraints & seats); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Retractable hardtop with integrated panoramic sunroof
Notable standard features on this model: Leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel, dual-zone automatic climate system, heated front seats, navigation
Notable options on this model: Parking assistance, rearview camera, wood-trimmed interior
You might also be considering: BMW 228i convertible, Mini Cooper convertible,

In its last year of production, the Volkswagen Eos, a luxurious small convertible, falls into place between the Mini Cooper convertible and BMW 228i Convertible. It’s well-equipped and luxurious. The powertrain is sporty, with 200 horsepower coming from the turbocharged direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder and with the dual-clutch automatic gearbox providing nearly instantaneous shifting. But it’s still a front-wheel-drive chassis, which won’t return the same dynamic responses as the BMW.

The Eos’s chief claim to fame is the hardtop (with incorporated power-operated sunroof) that retracts in 25 seconds. The roof’s five elements neatly sandwich themselves and drop as smoothly as deviled ham. Leave the top up, and the trunk offers 10.5-cubic-feet of storage. As standard equipment, a wind blocker reduces turbulence in the passenger compartment. To counteract roofless vulnerability, the Eos has automatic rollover support, with support elements shooting out of their housings in a quarter-second if a possible rollover or collision is detected. The Eos lineup starts with the Komfort, which has the power sunroof, leather-wrapped steering wheel, and heated front seats. A five-inch touchscreen with navigation are also standard. For 2015, the Final Edition knocks last year’s Sport out of the lineup. It has a more aggressive stance, a lowered, sport-tuned suspension, 18-inch wheels, and black-and-beige leather seats. The Executive indulges with unique wheels, wood interior trim, and a 10-speaker audio system. The only hardtop convertible with a power sunroof—why didn’t we think of that?

New for 2015

Final Edition model.

Positioning the 2015 Volkswagen Tiguan as the most premium and sporty compact crossover may be a good idea, but we just see it as being an expensive choice. It certainly does take the premium approach in powertrain, with a turbocharged, direct-injection 2.0-liter four cylinder engine generating 200 horsepower and giving solid thrust with 207 pound-feet of torque. The six-speed automatic transmission has a sport mode for snappy performance. The main addition this year is an improved standard infotainment system, which includes an iPod connection, rearview camera, satellite radio, and premium audio. The Car-Net connected services smartphone app allows remote sending of commands and monitors functions and vehicle location. Emergency assistance is also part of the app. The other notable change for 2015 is the new rear bumper on the Tiguan R-line. This is the sportiest, best-equipped model, and it climbs over the $40,000 barrier. The R-line has paddle shifters, 19-inch wheels, a sport suspension, leather upholstery, and a roof-mounted spoiler. Towing capability for all models is 2200 pounds.

New for 2015

Improved standard infotainment system, restyled bumper for the R-line model.

title: 2015 Rolls-Royce Wraith
subTitle: Like nothing else.
promoTeaserSmall: Like nothing else.
promoTeaser: Like nothing else.
metaDescription: Like nothing else. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury coupe
Price range: $289,100 (includes destination)
Trim level: Wraith
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 6.6-liter V-12, 624 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 13 mpg city/21 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Satellite-aided transmission
Notable standard features on this model: Voice-controlled navigation and calling, touchpad infotainment screen, 20-inch wheels
Notable options on this model: Starlite headliner, 21-inch wheels, two-tone paint, adaptive headlamps, gold-plated Spirit of Ecstasy mascot, ventilated seats, active cruise control
You might also be considering: Bentley Continental GT, Ferrari F12 Berlinetta

The 2015 Rolls-Royce Wraith is beautiful in itself, but check out the optional Starlite headliner, a $12,925 option, has 1,340 fiber optic cables that are hand woven over two days. The leather upholstery comes from cows that lived high in the Alps, away from barbed wire and insects, so the imperfections in the hides “are as few as possibly can be found,” as a Rolls-Royce spokesperson said. The Wraith’s rear-hinged coach doors are fully wood paneled inside and match each other exactly. With its elegant face, swooping roofline, available two-tone paint, and 21-inch alloy wheels, the Wraith looks like no other automobile on earth.

And with the twin-turbocharged, direct-injection 6.6-liter V-12 engine generating 624 horsepower, it’s the most potent Rolls-Royce ever, dashing from 0 to 60 mph in 4.4 seconds. Nevertheless, for all the Wraith’s excess, it is touted as a daily driver for a younger group of buyers. Six-footers fit in the back seat, and three bags of golf clubs go in the trunk. The technology is incredible. Communication between the navigation system and the eight-speed automatic transmission means the road is analyzed to determine the right gear. And the connectivity and infotainment make it ever so convenient. (A 1300-watt, eighteen-speaker sound system, anyone?) Here, simply, is a car like no other.

New for 2015

There are no changes for 2015.

title: Aston Martin Vulcan: Designer Walkaround
subTitle: Design chief Marek Reichman shows us around the torrid 800-plus-horsepower supercar.
promoTeaserSmall: Design chief Marek Reichman shows us around the torrid 800-plus-horsepower supercar.
promoTeaser: Design chief Marek Reichman shows us around the torrid 800-plus-horsepower supercar.
metaDescription: Design chief Marek Reichman shows us around the torrid 800-plus-horsepower supercar.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Director of design Marek Reichman came to Aston Martin from Lincoln in 2005. He stepped bravely into the very large shoes of superstar designer Ian Callum, who has been a towering force at Jaguar since. Reichman quickly got his sea legs, as evidenced by the Rapide S (pictured here), one of the most beautiful cars in the world. And now, Vulcan!

Even the mildest of contemporary Aston Martin cars is hot stuff, but this one figures to be flat-out torrid—the closest thing you can get to one of the company’s Le Mans 24 Hours racing cars. The competition reference is apropos, because this limited-edition hot rod is intended strictly for track use; there's no street-legal version.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/02NWuVYJ8YY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Aston Martin Vulcan Limited edition means just that; Aston Martin plans to build just twenty-four Vulcans and sell them at a reported $2.3 million each. Does that sound steep? Consider that the price includes tuition from the Aston Martin racing operation, as well as company-sponsored track days at famous racing venues. Then, of course, there’s the car: carbon fiber chassis, carbon fiber skin, magnesium torque tube surrounding a carbon fiber driveshaft, huge carbon-ceramic brakes from Brembo. The suspension package includes racing-style in-board shock absorbers, adjustable cockpit, and adjustable anti-roll bars.
And of course there’s ample power—more than 800 horsepower, according to Aston Martin, delivering thrust to the rear wheels via a six-speed racing transmission.
Exterior finish? Interior decor? Well, what are your preferences? As is appropriate at this price point, Aston’s trim department will make sure your Vulcan is exactly as you like it

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/alfYvrYofAw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Lincoln design director David Woodhouse has been working toward his current role of crafting Lincoln’s future for most of his fifteen years with the Ford Motor Company.  He jumped ship from General Motors U,K. in 1999 to become chief designer of Ford’s once prestigious Premier Automotive Group, which comprised Jaguar, Land Rover, Aston Martin, and Volvo.

When asked why Ford did not see fit to include Lincoln as part of the group, PAG’s imperious group president, Wolfgang Reitzle, sniffed, "Because then we would have to call it the Almost Premier Auto Group." He was not wrong.

After chief designer stints in Ford’s California advanced design studio and at its Ingeni strategic concepts group, Woodhouse  was ready for the monumental task of putting Lincoln back on the map.  With only a few months of  directing strategy under his 
belt, Woodhouse took over as Lincoln’s director of design at the end of 2013.

He showed us the 2016 MKX Concept at the 2014 North American International Auto Show a month after he assumed the role of director of design, but the Continental Concept is his first true breakout design for the beleaguered brand.

title: 2015 Ford F-150
subTitle: Revolutionary changes to a bestseller.
promoTeaserSmall: Revolutionary changes to a bestseller.
promoTeaser: Revolutionary changes to a bestseller.
metaKeywords: 2015 Ford F-150; Ford; pickup; truck; American
metaDescription: 2015 Ford F-150: Revolutionary changes to a bestseller. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Rear- or all-wheel-drive full-size pickup
Price range: $26,995–$52,545 (includes destination)
Trim levels: XL, XLT, Lariat, King Ranch, Platinum
Engines: 3.5-liter V-6, 282 horsepower; turbocharged 2.7-liter V-6, 325 horsepower; turbocharged 3.5-liter V-6, 365 horsepower; 5.0-liter V-8, 385 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 3.5-liter, RWD: 18 mpg city/25 mpg highway; 3.5-liter, AWD: 17/23 mpg; 2.7-liter, RWD: 19/26 mpg; 2.7-liter, AWD: 18/23 mpg; 3.5-liter turbo, RWD: 17/24 mpg; 3.5-liter turbo, AWD, 17/23 mpg; 5.0-liter, RWD: 15/22 mpg; 5.0-liter, AWD: 15/21 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Storage inside the rear-seats
Notable standard features on this model: Tow/haul mode for managing big loads
Notable options on this model: Configurable storage in the bed via the BoxLink system
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Silverado, GMC Sierra, Ram 1500

The ubiquitous F-150 underwent a radical transformation for 2015 that challenges the traditional notions of truck manufacturing. The body and bed are constructed of aluminum, making new F-150 models up to 700 pounds lighter than their predecessors. The frame is the same high-strength steel, but the new lighter sheetmetal is intended to better resist dents as well as help improve fuel economy, acceleration, hauling capacity, and stopping distances. With three cab choices, three bed lengths, four available engines, as well as five trim levels with increasing interior elegance and tech features, the line’s configurability is seemingly limitless and can take the F-150 from bare-bones work truck to powerful luxury hauler. Utility essentials like tow/haul mode, a cargo lamp, and roll stability and trailer sway control are standard on all F-150 models. The optional BoxLink system adds metal brackets and cleats allowing a variety of accessories—ramps, storage bins, bed dividers—to be secured in the cargo bed. Although the F-150’s styling is not as revolutionary as the much-touted aluminum construction, its stout front end, wide stance, and orderly interior suit its purpose nicely.

New for 2015

Aluminum alloy materials lighten the F-150 considerably.

2015 Ford F-150: Should You Buy It?

Price range: $29,995–$38,595 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SE, SEL, Limited

Fuel economy : 3.5-liter: 18 mpg city/25 mpg highway; 3.5-liter, AWD: 17/23 mpg; 3.5-liter turbo, AWD: 16/23 mpg

Ford calls it a utility vehicle but the enigmatic Ford Flex has wagon written all over it. The long, low rectangle shape with a hint of old 1960s woody styling looks like nothing else on the road. With seating for seven and a decent 20 cubic feet of storage, to say this is a family-centric vehicle is an understatement. An optional second-row cooler compartment, back seat climate control, and electronic ports to create a Wi-Fi hot spot for passengers are all geared toward the tech-hungry and their kids. Parents will appreciate the fold-flat second- and third-row seats (powered third-row seats are optional) that extend the cargo capacity to 83 cubic feet. Large windows give the Flex’s cabin an airy feel, and the optional three-panel Vista Roof open’s it up even more. A plethora of video, navigation, and connectivity options are available if you add the Sync infotainment with MyFord Touch system that can be accessed by voice, steering wheel controls, or a tap on the eight-inch touchscreen. A backup sensor system that alerts you to obstructions behind the car is standard, but other safety options like inflatable seatbelts or blind spot warning are on higher trim levels only. All Flex models have a six-speed automatic transmission mated to either a normally aspirated or twin-turbocharged V-6 engine. The Flex Limited comes with the latter and all-wheel drive.

New for 2015

The two-tone roof can be dressed up in either Tuxedo Black Metallic and white or Deep Impact Blue Metallic and white.

title: 2015 Ford Transit Connect
subTitle: Small-business focused.
promoTeaserSmall: Small-business focused.
promoTeaser: Small-business focused.
metaKeywords: 2015 Ford Transit Connect; Ford; wagon; van; work van; American
metaDescription: 2015 Ford Transit Connect: Small-business focused. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Front-wheel-drive wagon or van
Price range: $23,325–$30,180 (includes destination)
Trim levels: XL, XLT, Titanium
Engines: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 169 horsepower; turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 178 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.5-liter, van: 21/29; 1.6-liter, van/wagon: 22/30; 2.5-liter, LWB wagon: 20/28; (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars (wagon)
Our favorite standard feature: Dual sliding side doors
Notable standard features on this model: Overhead storage shelf, 180-degree-opening rear doors
Notable options on this model: Fixed glass roof
You might also be considering: Mercedes-Benz Sprinter, Nissan NV200, Ram ProMaster City

The Transit Connect was well received when it first came on the scene in 2009. The small van, built on the Focus platform, offers versatility and good fuel economy, and that has helped make it a favorite with businesses and entrepreneurs. Like a minivan, it has sliding doors on both sides, but has the option of hinged rear doors instead of the standard liftgate. Both body styles, are available in two wheelbase lengths, but while the van can only carry two people, the wagon can shuttle five or seven, in short- and long-wheelbase versions, respectively. With the rear seats folded, the short wheelbase can swallow 77 cubic feet of cargo, while the long wheelbase can transport over 100 cubic feet of stuff weighing up to 1,270 pounds. The van’s payload maxes out at 1,600 pounds and, with the appropriate fittings, can tow up to 2,000 pounds.

While the van is all business, the wagon can be trimmed in leather. Available comfort and convenience options include heated side mirrors, front and rear parking sensors, and Ford’s Sync infotainment system. Owners may also like the programmable MyKey, which allows speed and audio limits to be set for specific drivers. The van can be customized with numerous aftermarket products like bins, shelves, and partitions to create an individually tailored cargo space. There are two four-cylinder engines to choose from: a normally aspirated 2.5-liter and a turbocharged 1.6-liter; the former can be converted to use compressed or liquefied natural gas. A starting price in the low $20,000s makes the Transit Connect affordable for the smallest business.

New for 2015

The short-wheelbase wagon with the liftgate gets a rear cargo cover to disguise valuables in the back and Magnetic Metallic exterior paint.

Trim levels: Stingray: 1LT, 2LT, 3LT; Z06: 1LZ, 2LZ, 3LZ
Engines: 6.2-liter V-8, 455/460 horsepower; supercharged 6.2-liter V-8, 650 horsepower
Transmissions: Seven-speed manual, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 6.2-liter, manual: 17 mpg city/29 mpg highway; 6.2-liter, automatic: 16/29 mpg; 6.2-liter supercharged, manual: 15/22 mpg; 6.2-liter supercharged, automatic: 13/23 mpg
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Power-folding convertible top
Notable standard features on this model: Color head-up display (2LT and higher)
Notable options on this model: Corvette Museum Delivery that includes a Corvette Museum logo plaque personalized with your name
You might also be considering: Audi R8, Jaguar F-Type, Porsche 911, SRT Viper GTS

Did you say fast? The Corvette Stingray or Z06 are not made for the slow lane. Not with that aluminum spaceframe, carbon fiber hood, removable carbon fiber roof panel, and 6.2-liter supercharged V-8 engine. This car is built for the racetrack. And you will be required to drive it very, very fast, not if you turn on that 650 horsepower and 650 pound-feet of torque, And if you want to look like you went fast when you arrive, consider the open-top coupe or the convertible—those are sure to mess up your hair. The open-top coupe has an ultra-light removable carbon fiber panel that fits neatly under the hatch. The Stingray convertible’s electronic top can be lowered remotely using the key fob, even if the desire to feel the wind in your hair happens when you are driving 30 mph.

Did the really important people miss your entrance? No worries. Replay your drive for anyone who missed it with the available industry-exclusive Performance Data Recorder. Like a black box for your ride, it records high-definition video of your shenanigans with telemetry overlays. The use of carbon fiber in the body makes this car light. But it is designed to stay on the road, with aerodynamics that help keep it grounded. The available 4G LTE with Wi-Fi will also keep you on the road by helping you stay connected wherever you are. Even if your phone doesn’t get a signal, this car very well might as its powerful antenna is built into its frame.

New for 2015

An optional eight-speed transmission, choice of new colors and design packages, and available Performance Data Recorder and 4G LTE

More about the Chevrolet Corvette

2015 Chevrolet Corvette Z06 February 3, 2014
