You may be hauling scrap metal through a rocky field but inside the Sliverado will be calm and quiet. The interior has been tuned for silence—engineered with sound-absorbing materials and available active noise cancellation on LTZ models. The seats are comfy, the tailgate is engineered to be easy to open and close. And there are a host of details such as the rear-bumper step and available LED lighting in the bed to add to the comfort level.

The Silverado can haul up to 12,000 pounds and can be powered by a robust V-8 with 420 horsepower and 460 pound-feet of torque. This working truck assumes you’ll be working, too. So there is plenty of room for all your gear, and not just in the 6’6” truck bed. The center console is big enough to stash your laptop, safe and out of sight. There are cubbies and storage areas tucked into the doors for your Thermos, umbrella, and other items. Flip open the rear seats, and you’ll find another compartment to keep your valuables out of sight.

New this year is the High Country trim level, which brings some serious creature comforts and luxury to your work day: leather trim, heated and ventilated front bucket seats with twelve-way power adjustment, a Bose audio system, 20-inch wheels, and optional built-in 4G LTE with Wi-Fi to keep your passenger—and you when you park on the job site—connected, informed, and entertained.

New in 2015

High Country trim level, new eight-speed automatic transmission, optional spray-on bedliner, new exterior colors, the Midnight Edition, and available 4G LTE with Wi-Fi.

Small like a compact car. Tall like an SUV. The Trax is a cute addition to the urban jungle. Chevy-style dual-port grille, swept-back headlamps, and optional chrome trim also make it a cute date car. Available all-wheel drive makes it sure-footed, and its compact footprint makes it easy to maneuver into tight parking spots and weave through traffic in town. It can seat five—as long as the rear-seat passengers don’t mind rubbing shoulders—and carry more than 18 cubic feet of cargo simultaneously. With the rear seat folded, that number goes up to 48 cubic feet. The Trax also has eight different seating/cargo carrying configurations and more than a dozen interior storage compartments.

The interior is hyper-focused on maximizing space while keeping the exterior small enough to negotiate city traffic and parking. The front passenger seats folds out of the way so you can carry a surfboard or an eight-foot ladder, and there are sixteen storage compartments and 48.4 cubic feet of cargo space with seats folded.
Plus? It’s just darn cute.

New for 2015

The Trax is an all-new vehicle for 2015.

title: 7 Ways to Put Joy into Car Shopping
subTitle: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.
promoTitle: 7 Ways to Put Joy into Car Shopping
promoTeaserSmall: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.
promoTeaser: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.
keywords: 7 Ways to Put Joy into Car Shopping
metaTitle: 7 Ways to Put Joy into Car Shopping
metaDescription: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.

pageElements.text: How does shopping for a new car fit into your life? Is it right up there at the desirability level of a trip to the spa, or way down low next to a root canal?

Let me tell you how I feel about new-car shopping: You should be thrilled. You’re about to buy a brand-new car! You should take your time to revel in every moment and make the whole experience be about you. The lucky dealer owes it to you to listen carefully to you, to give you answers that make sense, and to build your enthusiasm, not sidetrack it or knock it down.
To get there, you need to put yourself into the right mindset. Then you’ll be able to put all the elements in place that will make the experience work for you.

1. Believe that this is all about you.

It’s your money. It’s going to be your car. Too many people let car shopping feel like a dreaded chore. Don’t. Going on a tropical vacation, or buying a fabulous piece of jewelry, the hottest new putter, or a collector’s edition book….those things are fun. Buying a car should be all of that, multiplied by about 100. You are spending enough money to give you the absolute right to actually enjoy choosing and closing the deal on your car.

2. Know what you want before you walk in.

You can greatly reduce the stress of car buying by walking into the dealership already armed with information you need. Every brand you could possibly be interested in has an online presence these days. Go to the manufacturers’ websites and play with the excellent online car configurator tools. Specifically, try to understand what packages are available on the model you’re interested in, and what different trim levels your vehicle of choice can come equipped with. Print that information, and put it on a clipboard. Once you’ve narrowed down the different cars you like, comparison shop on dealer websites. The more you have explored and decided on your own needs and wants, the more you’ll be able to relax and enjoy the shopping experience.

3. Know how much you have to spend. Really.

It’s a good time to check your credit score and get pre-qualified by your bank or credit union. Find out about their loan rates and deals. In short, don’t show up at the dealership until you are clear on the financial aspects and have a clear idea about your spending limit. It makes no sense to be distracted by cars on the lot that are priced beyond your means. Knowing your financial status sends a message to your salesperson that you’re serious about buying.

One last thing: Don’t be surprised if the dealer can get you a better rate on your loan.

4. Expect respect from your salesperson.

Start the relationship on a high note. Make an appointment and start to establish a connection before you just wander in. You may also get an idea of your compatibility before you ever walk through the door. Assume that the salesperson is a professional and is there to help you find your dream car and facilitate your ownership. It’s not fair to start the process with a chip on your shoulder or an assumption that the salesperson is out to cheat you—not fair to the salesperson, but also not fair to yourself.

5. Make your first trip to the dealership a fact-finding mission.

This is a good time to get your bearings without the pressure of decision-making. This is also a great time for that first appointment, to decide if you click with the salesperson. Bring your clipboard and a list of any questions you might have. Tell them upfront that you won’t be testing, just shopping. Say it again if you have to

6. Don’t let anyone set the timetable for you.

Don’t be in a hurry at any stage of the process. When you’re ready for your test drive, bring along all the props and baggage of your daily life—dog crates, child seats, briefcases, or whatever else you know you’ll load into the car the minute you own it—and make sure it fits. Take all the time you need—all the time you want—to truly test drive the car. Let absolutely nobody pressure you into making a decision before you’re ready.

7. Be prepared to keep trying, or walk away, if the salesperson doesn’t give you the experience you want.

This is the most important element. You are not required to work with the first salesperson you encounter. You don’t have to buy any one car from any one dealership. There are lots of fish in the sea dying to jump on your hook. Your best weapons are being ready and willing to spend the amount of money you have decided you can spend, along with being ready and willing to walk away if the deal isn’t going to happen. You don’t need to be rude. You don’t have to get mad. You just need to be your own best advocate.

Notable options on this model: Engine block heater, power second- and third-row windows
You might also be considering: Honda Odyssey, Kia Sedona, Toyota Sienna

The Dodge Grand Caravan may be the bestselling minivan with the most accolades, but these days its chief competitive advantages are available Super Stow ’n Go seating and a low price. It does lead the minivan class with 283 horsepower, but that is likely a secondary attribute for most buyers in this market niche. So that leaves value. For example, consider the Grand Caravan AVP (American Value Package). It’s a bargain with standard seventeen-inch wheels, air conditioning, and power locks, windows, and mirrors. It also has keyless entry and a multifunction steering wheel. It can be equipped with available second-row Stow ’n Go seats and the Handsfree group ($690) that includes a USB port, Bluetooth with audio connectivity, satellite radio, and voice command. That’s a screamin’ deal for a vehicle that offers so much basic utility and performs competently. On the other hand, the Grand Caravan can be given the home theater treatment with Blu-ray and DVD entertainment that includes two nine-inch screens, a remote, and the required HDMI connection and USB ports. As for the Caravan R/T, well, competing minivans hardly attempt to be sporty, but this bad boy goes for it with a monochromatic paint scheme, polished aluminum and gloss black wheels, and retuned suspension and steering. Inside are leather seats with red accent stitching and a ten-speaker audio system.

New for 2015

Daytime running lights are now standard.

You might also be considering: Audi A8/L, Maserati Quattroporte, Mercedes-Maybach S600, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

There are a lot of fast cars on the market, but the 2016 Bentley Flying Spur is for the buyer who wants a luxury sedan that is fully capable of driving at speeds up to 200 mph but doesn’t want a dedicated track car. Available in either a four- or five-seat configuration, the Flying Spur is more than adequately powered by either a 626-horsepower 6.0-liter twin-turbo W-12 engine or a slightly more modest 500-hp 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8. The recently added V-8 isn’t necessarily for the environmentally conscious—because no one buys a V-8 to save on trips to the gas pump. Rather, it’s tuned to be sportier thanks in part to the weight savings that come from using a lighter engine, and it presents different driving dynamics. But still, the W-12 emits that low, unmistakable engine sound that only $200,000 can buy. The interior of the Flying Spur is heady, with luxurious materials at every turn and touch, including polished or matte metals on the door, supple leather seats, and wool floor mats. And although the sedan features some of the latest safety and connectivity options, such as parking sensors and Wi-Fi, no one buys a Bentley for its cutting-edge technology, unless, of course, they’re talking about the massaging front seats.

New for 2015

The V-8 gets more power, more customization options.

You might also be considering: BMW 3 Series, Mercedes-Benz C-Class

The ATS is Cadillac’s answer to the outdated notion that American manufacturers can’t build a compact performance car. The 2015 ATS coupe offers buyers three engine options: the standard 2.5-liter, 202-hp four-cylinder; the midlevel 2.0-liter turbo; and the potent 320-horsepower 3.6-liter. The ATS-V model will be available later this year with either a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission with 464 horsepower, something for track enthusiasts. But if you can’t wait until then—or don’t need 464 hp to go to the grocery store—performance-minded buyers will still be pleased with the ATS’s quick reflexes and a sporty interior that lends a cockpit-like feel to the driver’s seat. Attention to detail and craftsmanship extend throughout the cabin, including the hand-cut and -sewn door panels, steering wheel, and dashboard. Connectivity and technology are becoming synonymous with luxury, and Cadillac is leading the pack with standard OnStar 4G LTE availability and its Cue infotainment system. Crash avoidance systems and head-up display complete the technology picture.

New for 2015

The 2.0-liter turbo gets more torque, keyless, passive vehicle entry, wireless phone charger, two new exterior color options and OnStar with 4G LTE and built-in Wi-Fi hot spot (3GB/three-month trial).

More about the Cadillac ATS

Trading luxury for fuel economy is a big sacrifice for many buyers. For those people, one choice is the Cadillac ELR. Based on the award-winning Chevrolet Volt's platform, the ELR is a technological feat packaged in gorgeous exterior design, offering environment-conscious buyers a way to drive electric without the range anxiety. A fully charged ELR can travel up to 37 miles using only the electricity stored in its 16.5-kwH electric battery, but after its range-extending engine kicks in, the ELR achieves approximately 33 mpg and can travel 340 miles on a tank of gas. Setting it apart from the Volt is a sport-tuned chassis, the same one used by the CTS. The vehicle’s driving modes help make the vehicle handle a bit more like its Cadillac siblings. But you don’t buy the ELR because you like to accelerate off the line—you buy the ELR because you like alternative propulsion technology. On the downside, the ELR seats only four, which is one less than some of its competitors.

New for 2016

Revised electric drive system for more power and torque; OnStar with 4G LTE and standard built-in Wi-Fi hot spot.

More about the Cadillac ELR

Automotive Holiday Baubles November 11, 2013

When you need a big SUV but hanker for something lavish, that compromise could likely land you in the Acadia. With comfortable seating for up to eight and luxurious details like a soft instrument-panel wrap, touch-activated climate controls, and ambient lighting accents, the interior is attractive and welcoming. It’s capable of hauling the entire brood without looking like a minivan. Halogen headlamps with LED daytime running lamps, available halogen fog lamps, and an impressive wraparound rear-window glass make it look more tough-guy luxury ride than soccer mom taxicab. Of course, it can do both, sometimes in the same family.

Pretty details aside, it will get the job done. The third row is a 60/40 bench that folds flat if you need it to with additional underfloor storage when the seat is in use. There is also a significant amount of storage behind the third row—more than other vehicles in this class—if you often carry lots of people and their gear. And there is plenty of onboard technology to keep you rolling, including an available head-up display that feeds data into your field of vision as you drive.

New for 2015

Heated, leather-wrapped steering wheel, 20-inch wheel design, three new exterior colors: Crimson Red Tintcoat, Dark Sapphire Blue Metallic and Midnight Amethyst Metallic.

More about the GMC Acadia

title: 5 Rules to Pack the Car Right
subTitle: Be ready for anything without cluttering up the inside of your vehicle.
promoTitle: 5 Rules to Pack the Car Right
promoTeaserSmall: Be ready for anything without cluttering up the inside of your vehicle.
promoTeaser: Be ready for anything without cluttering up the inside of your vehicle.
keywords: 5 Rules to Pack the Car Right
metaTitle: 5 Essential Rules to Pack the Car Right - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Be ready for anything without cluttering up the inside of your vehicle.

pageElements.text: One of the very best things about a car is how you can get inside and drive anywhere there’s a road. Road trips with your family or your friends can be some of the best moments in the car.  A well-packed vehicle can make the difference between a joyous, memorable experience and a cramped, unpleasant trip to purgatory and back.
Let’s not go there! Here are five things you must do before you drive off on your adventure. (We assume you’ve already made sure your car is road ready.)

1. Make a checklist. Use ours—or have fun creating one of your own. If it’s a family trip, put it up on the refrigerator and let everybody in the family contribute items to the list. Then, before you actually load the car, narrow it down as much as you can. Then narrow it down again.

2. Practice the art of micro- and macro-packing. How much you can pack depends entirely on how much room is in the vehicle. The key is to limit the number and size of bags per person. If you’re taking a short trip of two or three days, each person gets one medium-size suitcase or duffel bag. No exceptions. As the trip gets longer, you can add communal packing. Emergency clothes and equipment for inclement weather can go into a communal clear plastic storage crate, and for families, a community laundry bag can be helpful.

If you have a duffel bag, it’s a lot easier if you segment your clothes into Ziploc bags—one bag for toiletries, one for underwear rolled tightly, one for shirts, etc.  Bags are your road-trip friends.

3. Bring emergency supplies—and have a narrow definition of “emergency.” Number one is emergency supplies for the car. Have one duffel bag that is just big enough for jumper cables, flares, an emergency triangle, a couple of rags, and a pair of gloves. Make sure your jack is in working order and stowed where it belongs. Medicine comes second. Everyone should have their prescription medications and a copy of their prescriptions. There should be a first-aid kit that’s easy to access. Paper towels and wet wipes are essential. However, you don’t need dozens of over-the-counter medications or three kinds of hair conditioner. For all of that, there are drugstores.

4. Prioritize comfort. Give each person a car bag for his or her comfort items, so things like sleep masks, earplugs, books, and stuffed animals aren’t rolling around loose in the car. Police your vehicle once a day and keep it tidy inside for a comfortable road trip. That includes having a trash bag on board and emptying it every time you stop for gas.

Bring a cooler of healthy snacks and drinks to make sure everybody has what they need, and nobody gets impatient while you seek a good place to stop for lunch. If you have a caffeine addict—or are one—get that coffee before you drive off in the morning. Little kids should be issued a stuffed animal or other small toy friend.

5. Make smart entertainment and electronics choices. A combination of idealism and realism works well on a long road trip. Audiobooks are a lot of fun as long as everybody can agree on one. The nearly lost art of playing games in the car—spot something that starts with the letter Q—can be a great bonding experience. But at some point, people will want to plug in to iPods or watch a video, and you should be prepared with the cords and DVDs that you’re going to need when that happens. Having said that, why not make a playlist of music and/or audiobooks and plan a stretch of time each day when everybody listens to something together? A little togetherness, as long as it has an expiration date, can make the difference between enduring a road trip and really loving the experience.

You might also be considering: Chevrolet Colorado, Toyota Tacoma, Nissan Frontier

Though it is stylish, resourceful, comfy, classy, loaded with available safety features, and capable of handling the tight turns and gas-sipping efficiency demands of an urban environment, the all-new Canyon is still a mid-size pickup, capable of a hard-day’s work. Its design details, triple-sealed doors for interior quiet, comfortable interior, on-board technology—including 4G LTE with Wi-Fi hotspot, cruise control, available heated front seats (standard on SLT), and available lane-departure warning and forward-collision alert—might lead you to believe this is a mock pickup. But it also offers the segment’s highest-available trailering rating—7,000 pounds with the available V-6 engine and heavy-duty towing package—and the segment’s highest horsepower. And with the All-Terrain package it is downright beefcake worthy with its chrome accented, body-color grille and 17-inch painted aluminum wheels. This lovely compromise between work and play is available in four-door extended- or crew-cab model. Traditional truck features such as four-wheel drive and a highly flexible bed with GMC’s GearOn™ system are available. Who says compromise can’t be sweet?

New for 2015

The Canyon is an all-new model for 2015.

You might also be considering: Ford Explorer, Nissan Pathfinder, Toyota Highlander

The Honda Pilot hasn’t changed much in years, but it’s still a very practical SUV for families, with seating for eight, very respectable gas mileage, and a high-functioning interior. If your family tends to hit the slopes or lives a bit off the grid, you might even appreciate some of the real SUV features of this car – though we understand that you might want it simply because it doesn’t look like a minivan. The 8 inches of ground clearance and available 4-wheel drive, will take that steep driveway, sail over city potholes, and handle the rough road to your favorite fishing spot just fine. And it can tow 4,500 pounds (in the 4WD version) if boats or big bikes are your thing. Lots of seat configurations in the back make it easy to accommodate gear, pets, kids, and friends, or all of those at once if that’s how you roll. Honda has announced it is bringing out an all-new version of the Pilot for 2016, so deals no doubt likely abound on this older design.

New for 2015

New SE trim gets unique wheels, a power tilt-and-slide sunroof, and a rear DVD entertainment system.

More about the Honda Pilot

The Lexus ES may be the "entry luxury" entry from the Toyota luxury division, but it still offers the premium Lexus experience buyers are looking for, with fantastic details, textures and comfort designed to spoil: wood inlays, bamboo-trimmed steering wheel, leather wrapped bits, hand-stitched leather. The back seat is designed to be used by discerning adults who enjoy full-on comfort, with 40 inches of legroom in the back. Twelve-way heated and ventilated power front seats are optional.

The uplevel Crafted Line model takes the whole hand-crafted beauty thing even more seriously. And the ES300h is one mighty fine hybrid (and only one of five hybrid models from Lexus, showing the automaker's commitment to the genre). Fuel economy for the ES300h reaches 40 mpg in the city and 39 mpg on the highway. Even the gasoline-powered ES350 gets 31 mpg on the highway from its 268-horsepower V-6.

title: 2015 Chrysler 300 Limited AWD
subTitle: Classic sophistication with testosterone. Should you buy it? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Classic sophistication with testosterone. Should you buy it? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Classic sophistication with testosterone. Should you buy it? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: Classic sophistication with testosterone. Should you buy it? Here's what we think.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive full-size sedan
Base price: $34,890 (including destination charge)
This car: $37,580 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 292 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/27 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Analog clock on dash
Notable standard features on this model: Uconnect infotainment with 8.5-inch touchscreen, leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated front seats, leather seating, rotary shifter, chrome-trimmed LED taillamps, dual rear exhaust
Notable options on this model: LED foglamps, rearview camera, remote start (part of Driver Convenience package, $1,695); Navigation, HD and SiriusXM radio (part of Uconnect Navigation package, $995)
You might also be considering: 2015 Toyota Avalon, 2015 Chevrolet Impala, 2015 Hyundai Genesis, 2015 Kia Cadenza, 2015 Nissan Maxima (all prices include destination charges)

Postmodern art and minimalist design are all well and good. Comic-book colors and bulbous designs have their place. But there are still people out there who maintain a classic, old-school aesthetic, the kind of people who read Traditional Home and appreciate simple lines and elegance. The Chrysler 300 Limited is for those people. This full-size sedan’s appearance is the very definition of a formal design: upright, gracious, yet indulgent. Like me.
It’s something you don’t see enough of these days, an American rear-wheel-drive full-size sedan. (They’re just more fun to drive, in a Smokey and the Bandit kind of way.)

This is Chrysler’s flagship, slotting in above the new-for-2015 Chrysler 200. It’s something you don’t see enough of these days, an American rear-wheel-drive full-size sedan. (They’re just more fun to drive, in a Smokey and the Bandit kind of way.)

Yes, this car’s overall design is about ten years old, but it’s still head-turning. Chrysler has updated it for 2015 with a larger grille—still nowhere near as extreme as say, a Lexus—and a few other upgrades. But if you like your cars classic and sophisticated, this car will appeal to you as much today as it probably did in 2005.

There’s a range of 300 models to choose from: the 300 and 300 Limited, the luxurious 300C, and the top-end 300C Platinum. Then there’s the 300S, which I walked around with chief designer Ralph Gilles at the Los Angeles Auto Show last fall. “No other car has its profile,” he said, and he’s absolutely right.

The model we tested was the 300 Limited AWD, which as its name suggests had all-wheel drive. It comes with a 292-horsepower 3.6-liter V-6 and an eight-speed automatic transmission, and it was smooth, quiet, comfortable, yet missing very little in the testosterone department.

As for the 300S, it is powered by a 5.7-liter Hemi V-8 making 363 horsepower, and its eight-speed transmission has paddle shifters and a Sport mode. A deck-lid spoiler and blacked-out trim add an extra dab of macho appeal.
It feels almost impudent of me to say I would make a beeline for the Hemi, especially since the V-6-powered model has plenty of power to please just about everybody.

LED lighting is new for 2015, and so is a rotary dial transmission selector. I adjusted quickly to the dial, since it feels different enough from other controls. Shifting into Reverse shouldn’t feel exactly the same as tuning the radio or adjusting the A/C.
The elegance of the interior, all the way down to an analog clock on the dash, was complemented by a huge 8.4-inch touchscreen with Chrysler’s excellent, easy-to-use Uconnect infotainment system.
It comes with a 292-hp 3.6-liter V-6 and an eight-speed automatic transmission. It was smooth, quiet, comfortable, yet missing very little in the testosterone department.
A rearview camera is standard, and the Safetytec package ($1,695) adds blind spot and cross-path detection and a front and rear park assist system.

Other admirable exterior touches include the very cool shark-fin antenna atop the roof and the gleaming nineteen-inch polished aluminum wheels. It’s one of seven new wheel designs for 2015 that range from seventeen to twenty inches in diameter.

The 300 we tested had a classy black-and-linen interior with shiny black olive ash burled wood trim and charcoal metallic accents. Chrysler waxed lyrical with talk of “peaceful Zen” and using Sausalito, California, as the muse for this interior. It’s nice, but it’s a little less Zen and more Ralph Lauren if you ask me.

You can get the 300S with a black-and-blue Nappa leather interior with piano black and matte carbon accents. That one’s supposed to be Detroit inspired, which makes sense: a lot less Zen and a lot more badass. The 300C Platinum, the top-end luxury model, is available with an Indigo/Linen two-tone interior, high-end Italian Poltrona Frau leather trim, and hand-sanded natural-pore wood in a matte mocha finish. It’s a new day for Chrysler interiors.

The Verdict:

If you’re looking for a good old-fashioned big American sedan, but you want 2015 amenities, safety equipment, and fuel economy, the Chrysler 300 merits a serious look. It’s attractive enough that you’ll want to look twice at it anyway.

title: Real World Test: GM's 4G LTE
subTitle: The Cadillac Escalade, like most 2015 GM models, is a rolling Wi-Fi hot spot. Let's try it.
promoTeaserSmall: The Cadillac Escalade, like most 2015 GM models, is a rolling Wi-Fi hot spot. Let's try it.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: General Motors is going all in for 4G LTE Wi-Fi. The technology is now on board nearly all of its vehicles, from the basic Chevrolet Sonic to the 2015 Cadillac Escalade shown here, which was the subject of my real-world test of the technology. Yes, this is a great leap forward for technology in cars, and yet I am conflicted about it. This would surprise anyone who knows me, even myself. Quick lesson: 4G is the fourth-generation data technology for cell service, and the LTE is a version of 4G (the initials stand for Long Term Evolution). It is ten times faster than the previous generation, and the OnStar hardware is 100 times faster than the previous version. This OnStar version of LTE allows for seven devices to stream simultaneously. Sounds like an excellent step forward for mankind, but perhaps a step backward for family road trips.
Yes, 4G LTE wireless is a great leap forward for technology in cars, and yet I am conflicted about it. This would surprise anyone who knows me, even myself.

The 2015 Cadillac Escalade 4WD Platinum (price as tested, $94,565) is downright huge. It swallowed up my family and all of our devices to give the 4G LTE a test of the connectivity that this beluga offered. My daughter quickly went to her Wi-Fi setting on her phone, plugged in the password, and was off to stream movies and catch up on her YouTube viewing. My eighty-one-year-old mother was a little slower, but with a little help from her friends she was soon reading her email on her tablet. My husband connected my phone, and we were off. The connection was flawless, but I know if we did get into rural America it would fare no better than my phone service. We did have some disgruntled passengers when my husband turned off the car at the drive-in restaurant. So, if you are thinking you will sit around a fire near your vehicle while hitting the Wi-Fi, know that the ignition has to be on or in accessory mode.
If you are thinking you will sit around a fire near your vehicle while hitting the Wi-Fi, know that the car's ignition has to be on or in accessory mode.

If I am honest with myself I am an addict. Yep, I am addicted to my lovely iPhone 6 Plus. I am especially fond of the access to the Internet to immediately bring me information to support my side of an argument. I consider my phone an integral part of my ability to be a good employee, mother, wife, daughter, and all-around citizen of Earth. My phone bill is expensive, and in recent months I have had a tendency toward exceeding my data limit. But I don't think in-car Wi-Fi is the panacea for my data consumption problem.

That's because it can get expensive. General Motors offers free service for three months. Then you have to start paying the man. Packages range from $5 a month for 200 MB to $50 for 5 GB of data. Unlike the Wi-Fi in your home you pay for the data you use. So it makes me ponder: Why not just add data to my phone plan instead? The answer is that you might want to use devices, including laptops, that do not have a phone plan and are only Wi-Fi equipped. If you do, the in-car 4G LTE could be a game changer. Depending on your phone, the 4G may also boost your connection, so that is a consideration as well.

I wonder if the introduction of 4G LTE into vehicles is a step too far. My daughter grew up with on-board entertainment systems in our cars. When we drove a different vehicle, we toted along a portable DVD player. She would watch a movie or two and then spend the rest of the road trip unplugged. Then along came the smartphone; now she has contact with much cooler people than her middle-aged parents while traveling through rural America. She eats up our 10G phone data plan like Pac-Man, so we often have to forbid YouTube and streaming while anywhere without a Wi-Fi connection. I must remind her that "data" includes everything except texting and actual phone calls.

For me, paying up to $50 a month for Wi-Fi in the car is not something I'd be willing to do. For lots of people, the kind who want to surf the Internet and stream movies on their laptops in the car, it probably is. That kind of convenience can make very long drives, as well as zipping around town, more enjoyable for your passengers. With the cost of this Escalade hovering north of $90,000, it is obviously not a hardship for its owners to add a little extra to their monthly transportation budgets. Big downside, though: It may make the driver very lonely.

More to Read:

Do You Need Wireless Internet in the Car? March 19, 2015

title: Pro/Con: Leather or Cloth?
subTitle: Molly likes her cars swathed in leather. Laura prefers the feel of fabric. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaserSmall: Molly likes her cars swathed in leather. Laura prefers the feel of fabric. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Molly likes her cars swathed in leather. Laura prefers the feel of fabric. Whose side are you on?
metaDescription: Molly likes her cars swathed in leather. Laura prefers the feel of fabric. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Molly Jean: Leather

When it comes to car interiors, I fall firmly in the leather camp. You will need to put your S&M jokes aside for the remainder of this article. There are three reasons I prefer hide under my hiney—aesthetics, cleanliness, and resale. It doesn’t even have to be real leather. There are plenty of excellent faux leather options, and I would be pleased with any of them.

Leather just looks richer. You cannot convince me that there is any fabric option that is as pleasing to the eye as leather. The leather in high-end cars is so supple and beautifully tanned that it is worth the drive to a Bentley dealer near you to at least smell and feel the seats. I am drawn to contrasting stitching, piping, and how about the diagonal stitching in the Mercedes-AMG G-Wagen. I am especially enamored with the faux suedes like Alcantara. But enough waxing on about the high-end models. The more thrifty vehicles also sport some lovely leather.
Leather just looks richer. You cannot convince me that there is any fabric option that is as pleasing to the eye as leather.

Cleanliness is essential in any vehicle. Leather is simple to wipe clean and sanitize with leather cleaners and mild detergents. Even the most difficult stains can be tackled. The suede-like seat fabric options are not quite as durable, but possibly worth the risk if you are weak for Alcantara like me. Cloth, however, starts sucking up debris on day one, and good luck trying to remove anything sticky or stainworthy. Did I mention they also absorb odors? Even if you do get the stain out, my sensitive sniffer will still know that something is amiss. And if you are a secret smoker, you'd best opt for leather if you want to chauffeur around your mother-in-law.
Cloth, however, starts sucking up debris on day one, and good luck trying to remove anything sticky or stainworthy.

If I purchase a used car, I would rather not sit my posterior on cloth seats that have possibly lived a life worthy of a Hunter S. Thompson novel. No, thank you. When I search for a car, I check the filter for leather seats only. Obviously there are leather seats that have not received much tender loving care. But don’t be too quick to pass. There are amazing leather care products that can turn around some pretty battered seats into supple vintage thrones.

Cloth fans, including Laura (below), rally around temperature complaints—too cold in the winter and too hot in the summer. Since I am partial to seat heaters on any seat, that shuts half that argument down, and cooled seats are becoming increasingly available to counter the hot seats as well. If you are not lucky enough to have heated or cooled seats and would like to wear your micro-mini, I might suggest just sitting on a blanket for the first part of your trip. Chances are once you are ten minutes into your trip, your tender buttocks will be fine.

Laura Sky Brown: Cloth

We are lucky here at Jean Knows Cars that we get to drive a lot of very nicely appointed vehicles. The vast majority of test cars come with leather interiors, and I appreciate them for what they are.
But for my own personal vehicle, I insist on cloth seats.

I honestly just like cloth so much better: the way it looks, feels, and won't burn or freeze your butt. My preference isn't because I'm an old hippie with a vegetarian aesthetic. (Although I am.) It's because I think cloth seats are more comfortable, more homey, and I like the way they are always a neutral temperature, even on a hot or a cold day. I like the interesting fabric designs and two-tone color schemes you can get, especially on cheaper and more youth-oriented cars like the Fiat 500.
I like the interesting fabric designs and two-tone color schemes you can get in cloth, especially on cheaper and more youth-oriented cars.

There's the whole environmental/ethical thing, too. I'm not obsessive about it, but I do think about how many beasts had to give up the ghost when I stare into the dark, shiny heart of a three-row SUV all kitted out in leather. It's not such a happy feeling. I like recycled materials in a car for the same reason. For example, the 2015 Ford Escape uses scrap cotton, recycled plastic bottles, and repurposed fiberglass in its insulation and carpeting. I love that kind of thing. There's a part of leather seating, not to overstate the case, that's just excess and vanity.

Cloth is nearly always the more affordable choice. Besides the look and the feel of cloth, I like how it is standard equipment on most cars. Want leather instead? It's a major way to jack up your new vehicle's sticker price. For example, the 2015 Mini Cooper Hardtop comes with non-leather seats as standard. Making them real leather adds $750 to $2,250, depending on which leather interior you choose. Standard leather seats tend to be up in the top trim levels of a model, which is another way of paying more for a new car. When I'm the one buying, I like to stay down in the low to midrange trim levels, and that's where the cloth is.

I'm not a fanatic; I know that leather and suede or Alcantara can be delightful. I appreciate a well-made perforated-leather seat as much as anyone. But having been a kid in the era of stiff vinyl seats, I am often reminded of vinyl when I see some leather seats. If you imagine stained beige plush when you think about fabric seats, you should look at the MB-Tex seats that Mercedes-Benz uses in the C-Class and E-Class lineups. Surprise: It is vinyl, not leather, yet I like it better than the most buttery, excessive set of leather seats you can find anywhere. I think it will look better ten years down the road, too.

title: 2015 Nissan NV
subTitle: Looks don’t kill.
promoTeaserSmall: Looks don’t kill.
promoTeaser: Looks don’t kill.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan NV; Nissan; cargo van; van; wagon; Japanese
metaDescription: Looks don’t kill. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 12-passenger, rear-wheel-drive full-size passenger and cargo van
Price range: Passenger: $33,805–$39,005, Cargo: $27,235–$33,685 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Passenger HD S, Passenger HD SV, Passenger HD SL, 1500 Cargo, 2500 HD Cargo, 3500 HD Cargo
Engines: 4.0-liter V-6, 261 horsepower; 5.6-liter V-8, 317 horsepower
Transmission: 5-speed automatic
Fuel economy: N/A
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Four-row seating for 12
Notable standard features on this model: Dual-zone climate control, durable upholstery, heated tow mirrors, 17-inch wheels
Notable options on this model: Fog lamps, leather-appointed seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, 8-way power driver’s seat, heated front seats
You might also be considering: Ford Transit, Ram ProMaster, Mercedes-Benz Sprinter

Nissan says “rugged and professional” design. You might say, “The van with the large forehead.” The Nissan NV is distinctive and purposeful, a fully modern entry in the full-size van category. It is available in Passenger and Cargo models, each of which is well conceived. They come with either V-6 or V-8 power and a 5-speed automatic transmission. The Passenger van has a 41.7-inch side opening and seats up to 12 occupants in four rows. The three rows to the aft have split benches, and the individual sections can be removed and repositioned. Nissan claims 324 different configurations. Each seating position has its own headrest and an integrated seatbelt, so there’s no “seatbelt jungle” that anyone who’s climbed onto an airport or hotel shuttle is familiar with. Rear passenger comfort is ensured, thanks to dual rotating overhead A/C vents and available reading lamps in each row. Heat vents are built into the floor.

After taking advantage of the cheaper-by-the-dozen offer at the drive-in, everyone will be happy to find that cupholders slide out from beneath the seat cushion. Up front, there are dual-zone climate controls and available heated seats. The infotainment system now incorporates a text-to-voice feature. Productivity is enhanced by the same central “mobile office” center console unit familiar from the Titan pickup. The van’s available rearview camera seems like an essential feature. Standing even taller beside the Passenger version, the NV Cargo is available in 1500, HD 2500, and HD 3500 grades and, like its sibling, S, SV, and SL trim. High-roof variants are available. The Cargo takes advantage of the same wide-opening rear doors, available third-row 12-volt outlet and cargo-area 120-volt outlet to run devices, tools, or accessories. The Passenger van tows up to 8,700 pounds, and the Cargo van up to 9,500 pounds. A 5-year, 100,00-mile warranty is extended to both versions.

New for 2015

Updated infotainment with 5.8-inch display, voice recognition for audio and navigation, hands free calling and texting. Arctic Blue Metallic brings the number of available colors to six.

title: 2015 Hyundai Genesis New Cars
subTitle: Three cars, one label.

promoTeaser: Three cars, one label.

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sedan or coupe
Price range: $27,645–$35,495 (coupe); $38,950–$52,450 (sedan) (includes destination)
Trim levels: Coupe: 3.8, 3.8 R-Spec, 3.8 Ultimate; Sedan: 3.8, 5.0
Engine: Coupe/Sedan: 3.8-liter V-6, 311/348 horsepower; Sedan: 5.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed manual, 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy: V-6 sedan: 18 mpg city/29 mpg highway; V-6, AWD sedan: 16/25 mpg; V-8 sedan: 15/23 mpg; Coupe: 16/25 mpg; Coupe, R-Spec: 16/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick (coupe not rated); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars (sedan)
Our favorite standard feature: Paddle shifters
Notable standard features on this model: Pushbutton start, 18-inch wheels, automatic headlamps, Proximity Key entry, automatic climate control, Bluetooth connectivity, satellite radio, iPod and USB ports
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, panoramic roof, power trunk lid, 17-speaker audio system
You might also be considering: Cadillac CTS, Lexus GS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

The Hyundai Genesis is three cars in one: a slinky, sporty, affordable rear-wheel-drive coupe; a near-luxury sedan with available V-8 power; or, in either body shape, a capable all-wheel-drive climate conqueror. The standard engine is a potent, direct-injection 3.8-liter V-6 that produces 348 horsepower. In the agile Genesis Coupe, a 6-speed manual transmission is standard; the Ultimate’s available 8-speed automatic has a performance-oriented rev-matching feature for smooth downshifts. All-wheel drive is an option with the V-6 in either body style. But in the sedan, our experience leads to a preference for the smooth, powerful V-8 in the sedan. In size and level of specification, the Genesis falls just short of the top-of-the-line Hyundai Equus. It’s not quite cavernous inside, like the Equus, but it’s roomier than most of its direct competitors. The interior is gorgeous with available matte wood trim, aluminum accents, and leather upholstery that will continually delight. The Sedan 5.0 has standard heated and cooled front seats. (Heated rear seats are only available in the Sedan 3.8 with all-wheel drive, which also can be ordered with a heated steering wheel.) And of course, there are audio speakers and safety features galore. The Genesis is a very special car, a good value, but just a bit less prestigious than its competitors.

New for 2015

The Genesis sedan is all new this year. The V-6/manual transmission configuration is now standard on the Coupe, the four-cylinder engine has been dropped. The Coupe also gets automatic climate control, LED daytime running lamps, and Proximity Key as standard equipment.

More about the Hyundai Genesis

2015 Hyundai Genesis in Jean's Driveway May 29, 2014
Should You Buy It? 2015 Hyundai Genesis May 16, 2014

Price range: $22,545–$28,825 (includes destination)
Trim levels: GLS, SE, Limited
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower; 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.0-liter, FWD: 23 mpg city/29 mpg highway; 2.0-liter, AWD: 21/25 mpg; 2.4-liter, FWD: 21/28 mpg; 2.4-liter, AWD: 20/25 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in four categories, Poor in small overlap front test; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity
Notable standard features on this model: Seventeen-inch alloy wheels, rear spoiler with integrated LED brake lights, tilting and telescoping multifunction steering wheel, air conditioning, power windows with driver’s auto-down, six-way adjustable driver’s seat, front and rear 12-volt outlets
Notable options on this model: 18-inch alloy wheels, LED taillamps, shark fin antenna, Proximity Key entry with push-button start, dual-zone climate control, seven-inch touchscreen, leather upholstery, leather-wrapped steering wheel
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Kia Sportage, Toyota RAV4

The current generation Hyundai Tucson is reaching the end of the line. This spring, the 2016 Tucson was revealed at the New York Auto Show. So for those who don’t need all the latest features and design, it could mean good savings as dealerships try to clear out the 2015 inventory. Although it’s dated, the Tucson still has a competitive level of specification and feature content. The GLS comes with an efficient 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine and 6-speed automatic transmission. Front-wheel drive is standard, all-wheel drive, optional. Six air bags, active front head restraints, electronic stability control, hill-start assist, and downhill braking control are standard. The Popular Equipment package adds a 4.3-inch infotainment touchscreen, power driver’s seat, and leatherette seat trim. There’s also a tech package with a seven-inch screen and navigation, panoramic roof, and premium audio. The Tucson SE and Limited are equipped with the more powerful and slightly thirstier direct-injection 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine. The Limited’s standard equipment list includes eighteen-inch alloy wheels, LED tail lamps, and a chrome grille and chrome door handles. Having eased into the cabin thanks to Proximity Key entry, we find a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, leather upholstery, and dual-zone climate automatic control. Automatic collision notification and assistance through Blue Link is another plus.

New for 2015

No new features.

More to Read

New York Auto Show: Introduction of the 2016 Hyundai Tucson

Trim levels: Premiere, Select, Reserve

Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: EcoBoost FWD: 22 mpg city/33 mpg highway; EcoBoost AWD: 22/31 mpg; V6 FWD: 18/27 mpg; V6 AWD: 18/26 mpg; MKZ Hybrid: 41/39 mpg

The MKZ is a classic mid-size sedan, known for wrapping lovely design around technology that is focused on the human behind the wheel. For example, the push-button transmission opens up the center console by moving the shifting mechanism to five buttons on the dash. The hybrid version, unusually, is priced the same as the gas-engine version, and it has all the same features.

This is a lot of car for the money: quiet, with a smooth driving dynamic made possible by Lincoln’s drive control technology, which seamlessly monitoring rod conditions and managing the car’s shocks and other systems. A huge, retractable glass room opens the interior up to the skies as you enjoy your ride.

New for 2015

Available connectivity to the MyLincoln Mobile™ app, made possible through an available 3G embedded modem. New exterior colors: Luxe, Magnetic, Bronze, Guard.

title: 2015 Subaru BRZ Series.Blue
subTitle: The tiny sportster in my driveway: for those whose love for driving is deep but whose pockets aren’t.

promoTeaser: The tiny sportster in my driveway: for those whose love for driving is deep but whose pockets aren’t.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Subaru BRZ Series.Blue Edition

Type: Four-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sport coupe
Base price (BRZ): $28,490 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $30,285
Engine: 2.0-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 200 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/30 mpg highway
You might also be considering: 2015 Honda Civic Si Coupe ($23,710); 2015 Hyundai Genesis Coupe ($27,645); 2015 Scion FR-S ($25,670)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ULfoXvLYC1w" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Fun-O-Meter: 9.0

If you want a lightweight, rear-wheel-drive sports car in your life—and don’t have $50,000 to spend—here’s a very intriguing alternative. Subaru’s BRZ, the near twin of the Scion FR-S from Toyota’s youth division, is priced starting well under $30,000, and you can have a whole lot of sliding-the-rear-around fun for that money.

The BRZ was introduced in 2003, and it represented a new era in small, light, rear­-wheel-drive performance for Subaru and for Scion. Subaru jointly developed the BRZ with Toyota, which is why the BRZ is an anomaly in the Subaru lineup. It is rear­-wheel drive—not Subaru’s highly touted all-­wheel drive—the first rear-wheel-drive car for Subaru since the days of the Subaru 360 city car of the 1950s and 1960s.

The name BRZ stands for boxer engine, rear-wheel drive, and zenith.  The 2.0-liter engine was so nicknamed because its four horizontally opposed cylinders in action look a bit like a prize fighter throwing punches. Zenith seems to relate to the fact that the engineers working on the BRZ had in mind a sporty production car with the lowest possible center of gravity.

Horsepower from the flat four is a modest 200, so it’s no barn burner. Instead, you have the thinking person’s sports car: rear-wheel drive, low center of gravity, super low weight (2,758 pounds), near-perfect 50/50 weight balance between front and rear, and a lovely six-speed manual transmission to play with while you’re sporting around. All of this engineering thoughtfulness gives the engine a chance to feel powerful enough while delivering EPA fuel economy of 22 mpg city/30 mpg highway. The BRZ should be looked at in the same way as the popular Mazda MX-5 Miata: the idea that you can get a good time without terminal velocity that will make your nose bleed is one we should embrace.

The BRZ’s light, rigid structure feels superb, and the steering is nicely weighted. It’s surprisingly easy to use as a daily driver, and it handles beautifully, although it’s best for a maximum of two occupants, since the rear seat is cramped and the trunk is small. Hahahaha! Did I say “cramped”? The rear seat isn’t cramped, it’s virtually unusable for anything but hauling a couple of grocery bags. Or two hat boxes. Or maybe two child seats. I didn’t try that out, but I’d hate to be the parent trying to cram myself back there to get the things installed.

“You’re missing the point!” said Subaru public relations executive Michael McHale. “It’s a Subaru. You have to put a dog in the back.” Oh, of course. He also addressed rumors that a convertible version of the BRZ is headed for production. “There’s just no place to put the top,” he said. Now the front seat? Very lovely, especially in our special-edition tester, the BRZ Series.Blue edition. (Yes, it gets that extra period.) The one you see here went on sale last July in limited quantities. Only 1,000 BRZ Series.Blue cars will be sold in the continental U.S.

There are many interesting cosmetic details on the Series.Blue. Most apparent is the brilliant WR Blue Pearl paint, well known to Subaru’s rabid World Rally Championship fan base. Just to confuse the issue, 500 of the limited edition are that color. The other 500 are Satin White Pearl, but they’re still called Series.Blue. They just happen to be painted white. How about that for bizarre?

The BRZ Series.Blue has STI front, side, and side/rear underspoilers, seventeen-inch STI black­-finish alloy wheels, leather­ and ­Alcantara trimmed interior with blue highlights and stitching, red­-painted brake calipers, carbon­ fiber patterned trim, and an undercover insulator. The premium is $2,545, but the window sticker of our test car indicated a $1,795 reduction, bringing this one of 1,000 Edition.Blue series BRZs to just a tick over $30,000, destination included.

As befits its $28,490 base price, the standard BRZ is a little light on options. There’s no adjustable suspension, for example. For 2015, all BRZs get larger stainless tailpipe tips, a simulated carbon fiber center dash panel, and a roof­-mounted, body-color shark ­fin antenna. The rest is carryover from its 2013 complete redesign.
The only factory option for the BRZ Limited is a six­-speed automatic transmission. That version starts at $29,590.

Standard safety equipment on the BRZ includes six airbags, vehicle stability control, traction control, and whiplash protection front seats. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety named the 2015 BRZ an IIHS 2015 Top Safety Pick.

The bottom line is this: The BRZ is underrated. It’s beautifully engineered to deliver superb fuel economy and a lot of driving fun for someone who wants to be entertained, not terrified by the experience. News from the Great White North (a.k.a. Canada, where news of the 2016 model is out) is that the 2016 model will be unchanged. We can assume the same for the United States. This offers a primo opportunity to strike a keen bargain for a 2015 BRZ right after the 2016s hit showrooms. Sharpen your calculators now.

Subaru has been on a roll, setting records for six consecutive years and growing from 180,000 sales in the U.S. in 2008 to an expected 550,000 sales for 2015. This makes Subaru the eighth-biggest car company in the U.S., outselling Mazda and Volkswagen, among others. Obviously the vehicle driving most of these sales is the far more practical Outback crossover, not the BRZ, but don’t forget this is also the company that makes the WRX. It warms my heart that a company with a reputation for practical off-road vehicles also makes room in its portfolio for something as fun, impractical, and frivolously fabulous as the BRZ.

2015 Subaru BRZ has simulated carbon fiber trim.
Driver's seat of the 2015 Subaru BRZ Series.Blue.

title: 6 Cars a Family of Six Would Love
subTitle: Whether you want a third row every day or just occasionally, here's a winning variety of choices.
promoTitle: 6 Cars a Family of Six Would Love
promoTeaserSmall: Whether you want a third row every day or just occasionally, here's a winning variety of choices.
promoTeaser: Whether you want a third row every day or just occasionally, here's a winning variety of choices.
keywords: 6 Cars a Family of Six Would Love
metaTitle: 6 Cars a Family of Six Would Love - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Whether you want a third row every day or just occasionally, here's a winning variety of choices.

pageElements.text: The bench seat is only a memory, but the need to carry six people in a vehicle is still alive and well—at least for some people. Even if you don’t have a family of six, there are plenty of times you want to carry several friends, or other people's kids, or some combination of the two. Or perhaps you just want to give two squabbling children a little extra real estate to call their own in the back of your car.

With that in mind, here is our carefully selected list of six cars, crossovers, and SUVs that you could comfortably pack six people into—in some cases, more.  We’ve chosen the model of each one that we feel would be the most appreciated by a busy family, for its standard features list, price, or packaging. We’ve listed them from smallest to largest passenger numbers. All prices include destination charges.

1. 2015 Ford F-150 XLT 4x4 SuperCrew

Price: $42,800
Type: All-wheel-drive pickup truck
Holds up to: Six
Cargo volume: 6.5-foot truck bed
Engine: 5.0-liter V-8, 385 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic

What’s good for families: Every bit the pickup truck, the newly reborn, mostly aluminum F-150 is lighter, more fuel-efficient—and, yes, with the SuperCrew model, has four doors and ample space for six people. Just fold down the center console in front, and it’s bench-seat days all over again. It’s all good, because you have a pickup truck and a family car.

2. 2015 Kia Sedona EX

Price: $33,195
Type: Front-wheel-drive minivan
Holds up to: Seven
Cargo volume: 33.9 cubic feet (seats in place), 142.0 cubic feet (second- and third-row seats folded)
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 276 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic

What’s good for families: If you want the open, airy living-room-on-wheels feeling of a minivan—as families with kids in car seats often do—this is an affordable one. It was restyled last year to look more crossover-like and less like a traditionally boxy mom-mobile. A rearview camera and backup warning are standard; rear cross-traffic alert and blind spot monitoring are options. The EX is the middle trim level, but you can get the base model, the L, starting under $27,000.

3. 2015 Mazda CX-9 Touring AWD

Price: $34,950
Type: All-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Holds up to: Seven
Cargo volume: 17.2 cubic feet (seats in place), 100.7 cubic feet (second- and third-row seats folded)
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 273 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic

What’s good for families: The CX-9 is Mazda’s biggest SUV. The Touring model is one step up from the base Sport. We think it’s worth the extra $2,500 added cost because it has a rearview camera and blind-spot monitoring. There are many crossover/SUVs on the market, but this one has two advantages: especially good looks and spirited driving dynamics. If you want something that works as hard as a minivan and doesn’t look or drive at all like one, consider the CX-9.

4. 2016 Volvo XC90 T6 AWD

Price: $49,895
Type: All-wheel-drive crossover/wagon
Holds up to: Seven
Cargo volume: 15.4 cubic feet (seats in place), 85.7 cubic feet (second- and third-row seats folded)
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 276 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic

What’s good for families: For those who want a more carlike silhouette and still want to carry seven, the Volvo is the latest and greatest choice out there. The all-new XC90 goes on sale shortly, offering all the most current active safety features and little luxuries like a crystal shift knob, plus three rows of comfortable, attractive seating. All that and an impressive amount of cargo space when one or more seats are folded down.

5. 2015 Toyota Sienna XLE AWD

Price: $38,580
Type: All-wheel-drive minivan
Holds up to: Eight
Cargo volume: 39.1 cubic feet (seats in place), 150.0 cubic feet (second row removed and third-row seats folded)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 266 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic

What’s good for families: The Sienna is noteworthy because you can get an all-wheel-drive version in addition to the standard front-wheel-drive model, and you can also get two rows of bench seating to accommodate eight (or captain’s chairs in row two for a seven-seater). For those who want to be impressive when they growl, “Don’t make me come back there,” Toyota offers a Driver Easy Speak system, which involves a microphone that lets the front-seat occupants amplify their voices when admonishing those in the back. A rearview camera is standard; blind spot monitoring is available.

6. 2015 GMC Yukon XL SLE

Price: $54,635
Type: All-wheel-drive extended-length sport-utility vehicle
Holds up to: Nine
Cargo volume: 38.9 cubic feet (seats in place), 121.1 cubic feet (second- and third-row seats folded)
Engine: 5.3-liter V-8, 355 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic

What’s good for families: This is what you want if you are really, truly looking for a big carry-all, do-it-all vehicle. All new for 2015, the Yukon XL and its regular-wheelbase Yukon sibling are high, wide, and handsome sport-utility vehicles. Even the base model SLE has a rearview camera, front and rear park assist, Bose premium audio, and OnStar with 4G LTE on-board wireless that makes your Yukon a rolling hot spot.
