Kid stuff in the 2015 Toyota Sienna XLE.
2016 Volvo XC90 with optional Excellence interior.
Spacious Excellence Lounge console interior in 2016 Volvo XC90.

title: 2015 BMW 4 Series
subTitle: A driver’s coupe.
promoTeaserSmall: A driver’s coupe.
promoTeaser: A driver’s coupe.
metaKeywords: 2015 BMW 4-series; BMW; coupe; convertible; hatchback; M4; German
metaDescription: A driver’s coupe. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive coupe, convertible, or hatchback
Price range: $41,550–$65,150 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 428i, 435i, M4
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter 4-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter 6- cylinder, 300 horsepower
Transmissions: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 428i manual: 22 mpg city/34 mpg highway; 428i automatic: 23/34–35 mpg; 428i xDrive: 21–22/32–33 mpg; 435i manual: 20/30 mpg; 435i automatic: 20–22/30–32 mpg; 435i xDrive manual: 20/28 mpg; 435i xDrive automatic: 20/30–31 mpg; M4 manual: 17/26 mpg; M4 automatic: 17/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Run-flat tires
Notable standard features on this model: Adaptive cruise control, automatic stop/start, leather-trimmed steering wheel, hands-free Bluetooth and USB audio connection
Notable options on this model: Hands-free trunk opener, heated steering wheel, heated front seats, retractable headlight washers, blind-spot monitor, keyless entry, app-integration, navigation with touchpad, parking assistant
You might also be considering: Audi A5, Cadillac ATS, Lexus IS, Mercedes-Benz C-class

BMW has given the performance coupe its own model and series, betting that serious drivers who aren’t concerned with rear-seat egress want a more aggressively styled car. To that end, the 4-series fits the bill. Its sportiness is emphasized with an elongated, athletic exterior and a more rigid chassis than the 3-series. Mucking up the formula a bit is the recently introduced 4-Series Gran Coupe, which gets four doors but retains the fastback styling of the coupe. Although the 4-series and 3-series models share the same turbocharged 2.0-liter in-line-four and turbocharged 3.0-liter in-line-six engines, the 4-series wheelbase is bit longer, its body wider, and roof lower than its compact sedan sibling, which results in a more dynamic driving machine that feels firmly connected to the road. Rounding out the different driving characteristics is the standard speed-sensitive steering— variable-assist sport steering and adaptive suspension are available as part of the optional dynamic handling package. Optional technology is available on every aspect of the 4-series, from the Comfort Access that opens the trunk with a small foot movement under the center of the rear bumper, to the pedestrian detection, speed limit sign detection, collision avoidance, head-up display, and Google search-based points-of-interest for the navigation system. Rear seats in the Gran Coupe hatchback have a 40/20/40 split help make the most of cargo capacity.

New for 2015

Revised package features, new leather and material options, Comfort Access now includes the hands-free trunk closing function, and the Gran Coupe and M4 models are all new.

More about the BMW 4 Series

What I Drove Last Weekend: BMW 4 Series February 18, 2015

title: 2015 BMW X1
subTitle: Downsize without compromise.
promoTeaserSmall: Downsize without compromise.
promoTeaser: Downsize without compromise.
metaKeywords: 2015 BMW X1; BMW; sport-utility; crossover; SUV; German
metaDescription: Downsize without compromise. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $31,850–$39,750 (includes destination)
Trim levels: sDrive28i, xDrive28i, xDrive35i
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter 4-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter 6-cylinder, 300 horsepower
Transmissions: 6- or 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy: sDrive28i: 24 mpg city/34 mpg highway; xDrive28i: 22/32 mpg; xDrive35i: 18/27 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small overlap front: Moderate; Moderate overlap front, Side, Roof strength, Head restraints and seats: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Adaptive cruise control
Notable standard features on this model: Hands-free Bluetooth and USB audio connection, LED taillights, 8-way manual front seats
Notable options on this model: Heated front seats and steering wheel, adaptive headlights, rearview camera, navigation
You might also be considering: Audi Q3, Lexus NX, Volkswagen Tiguan

It may seem counter-intuitive to build an even smaller crossover than the already compact X3, but the BMW X1 is finding its niche in the market. Sized more like a beefy hatchback than a crossover, it’s tempting empty nesters to downsize their vehicles without giving up the commanding view to which they’ve become accustomed, and it’s offering young families and city dwellers decent cargo capacity without suburban proportions. The X1’s equipment is straightforward but generous, with a 2.0-liter 4-cylinder engine that produces 240 horsepower mated to an 8-speed automatic transmission, and it’s available with either standard rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. The interior retains that clean, Bavarian styling synonymous with the BMW brand, and its driving dynamics reflects the sportiness of its new, self-described “sport activity vehicle” classification. With a maximum of 34.9 cubic inches of legroom, the rear seats aren’t as cramped as you might expect in a compact crossover, and keep in mind that the 25 cubic feet of cargo capacity behind the second row, which more than doubles to 56 with the seats folded flat, had to come from somewhere.

New for 2015

Minor upholstery changes.

More about the BMW X1

BMW X1 xDrive 28i March 27, 2014

title: 2015 BMW i8
subTitle: Going green never looked so good.
promoTeaserSmall: Going green never looked so good.
promoTeaser: Going green never looked so good.
metaKeywords: 2015 BMW i8; BMW; hybrid; coupe; German
metaDescription: Going green never looked so good. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 2+2-passenger, all-wheel-drive hybrid coupe
Price range: $137,450 (includes destination)
Trim levels: i8
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter three-cylinder/electric hybrid, 357 net horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic/2-speed automatic (engine/electric motor)
Fuel economy: 28 mpg combined; electric only: 76 mpg-e combined
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Scissors doors
Notable standard features on this model: LED head- and taillamps, six-way heated power-adjustable front seats, iDrive infotainment system, navigation, 8.8-inch color touchscreen display, color head-up display, adaptive cruise control
Notable options on this model: Laser headlights (not legal in the U.S. market), 20-inch wheels, Louis Vuitton luggage set
You might also be considering: Porsche 918 Spyder, Audi R8

In some ways, the BMW i8 is two cars in one. Its futuristic styling suggests a whiplash-inducing luxury performance coupe that bolts off the line, hugging the road as it careens around the track. And with a 0-to-60-mph sprint completed in only 4.2 seconds, that would be a correct assumption. But it’s still a plug-in hybrid, which means that at the push of a button, it can operate on electric-only mode and responsibly motor around town emitting nary a tailpipe emission. With the gasoline engine disengaged, the i8 offers a pure EV range of approximately 22 miles and a top speed of 75 mph, but when making full use of its electric motors and its three-cylinder, 1.5-liter gasoline engine, the coupe produces an output of 357 horsepower and maxes out at an electronically controlled top speed of 155 mph while still getting an average combined fuel economy of 76 mpg. If you’ve drained the lithium-ion battery, you can expect an estimated 29 mpg when using only the gasoline engine. There are four different trim packages—the limited-edition Pure Impulse World is the most expensive at $10,800—each with its own interior trim options. As you might expect in a $140,000 vehicle, the standard features list is comprehensive. In fact, the only available options are turbine-style 20-inch alloy wheels and a swanky Louis Vuitton luggage set.

New for 2015

Comfort Access is now standard.

More about the BMW i8

Louis Vuittons in Carbon Fiber February 27, 2014

title: What Are Young Drivers Most Afraid Of?
subTitle: Surprising Ford survey shows driver-assist technology is a really good idea for Millennials.
promoTitle: What Are Young Drivers Most Afraid Of?
promoTeaserSmall: Surprising Ford survey shows driver-assist technology is a really good idea for Millennials.
promoTeaser: Surprising Ford survey shows driver-assist technology is a really good idea for Millennials.
keywords: What Are Young Drivers Most Afraid Of?
metaTitle: What Are Young Drivers Most Afraid Of?
metaDescription: Surprising Ford survey shows driver-assist technology is a really good idea for Millennials.

pageElements.text: Think about this while you're merging onto the freeway: the only thing that terrifies Millennials more than public speaking is seeing you driving next to them. Yes, you read that correctly; Millennials fear other drivers more than ghosts, snakes and even death.

As part of its Further with Ford technology initiative, Ford polled 1,000 members of Generation Z (ages sixteen to twenty-two) and Generation Y (ages twenty-three to thirty-four) this spring. The aim: to find out more about our fears, attitudes towards driving, and outlook on new technology in the car. Millennials’ anxiety towards driving—whether it’s parking, monitoring blind spots, or sharing the road with other drivers—may mean that majority of younger people (like me) will find it easy to get comfortable with driver-assist technologies.

As a nineteen-year-old, I immediately thought there's no way my generation worries this much about driving, but then I remembered I have not parallel parked since my driver’s test three years ago. To remedy my conflicting feelings, I did what any responsible and inquisitive young journalist would do: I asked my friends.

Nothing sends cold sweat down Allison Pfeiffer’s back quite like the on-ramp sign of a highway. At nineteen years old, Allison (pictured at top) has only driven on the highway once. “I have recurring nightmares about merging onto I-75,” Allison said. When I asked her to elaborate, she explained that driving straight into moving traffic unnerves her, and the idea of semi-trucks and larger vehicles cruising at 60 miles per hour in her general vicinity is just too much. Last week she used her GPS to find her way to a friend’s house, but when it suggested she take a highway, she pulled over and called her mom.
“Driving is scarier than spiders or snakes for me because if I get in an accident, it would be my fault,” Allison said.

“Driving is scarier than spiders or snakes for me because if I get in an accident, it would be my fault,” Allison said. All of the other friends I spoke to expressed similar sentiments, and I have to say I think Allison hit the nail on the head. According to Ford, 74 percent of Millennials fear death, 69 percent fear spiders, and 75 percent fear public speaking. In light of Allison’s remark, though, this data makes a bit more sense. If a ghost comes to haunt me or a spider bites me, I become a victim, not a guilty party. However, in the event of an accident, I face whatever physical damage occurs and a big steaming pile of responsibility.

So if fear of responsibility is fueling Millennials’ aversion to anxious-making driving situations, it stands to reason that parking would definitely create Level Ten nervousness. According to Ford, 57 percent worry about finding a parking spot, and 70 percent are concerned about getting into a tight space. To some degree, we all know the ritual that accompanies pulling into a tricky spot: gripping the wheel with white knuckles, inching along, silently praying you don’t hear the sound of side mirror on metal. My friend Katie drives a large SUV, so getting situated safely between those white lines is a major concern for her. “I’ll often park farther away from a restaurant or store if it means avoiding tight spots… or other cars in general,” Katie said.

This is where technology comes in. Ford just announced its decision to migrate the company’s driver-assist technologies across its product lineup over the next five years, which bodes well for the 52 percent of Millennials that would be as comfortable or more comfortable in a self-driving car than driving themselves. This technology would help with parallel parking and detection of objects in blind spots, among other functions.

My friend Gabe certainly doesn’t have a problem with tech in the car. He explained that driving is probably the most unsafe thing we do every day, so he would buy into any type of advances to make it easier and safer. In addition to appeasing these concerns, though, Gabe has even bigger dreams for automobile technology. “I want an Amazon Dash button in my car that knows my Chipotle order, and when I press it they make it at Chipotle, and my robot car drives me there,” Gabe said. He relishes the idea of sitting in the back seat, Driving Miss Daisy style, which makes sense given Gabe’s driving record. He described it as “not good.” In the past two years he has been involved in three accidents, two of which were with stationary objects.
After talking with me, Allison walked to her car. She left me with the following expression of her latest worry: “Let’s just hope I don’t hit a tree on the way home.” Well Allison, you’re not alone.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz B-Class
subTitle: Luxury goes green.
promoTeaserSmall: Luxury goes green.
promoTeaser: Luxury goes green.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz B-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; hatchback; electric; German
metaDescription: Luxury goes green. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive electric hatchback
Price range: $42,375 (includes destination)
Trim level: B-Class
Motor: Asynchronous 177 horsepower; lithium-ion battery, 28 kWh
Transmission: One-speed
Fuel economy: 85 MPGe city/83 MPGe highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Keyless entry
Notable standard features on this model: Push-button start, 7.0-inch LCD with control dial, LED head- and taillamps, split-folding rear seat
Notable options on this model: Parking assist, rearview camera, blind spot warning
You might also be considering: BMW i3

Mercedes-Benz has introduced its all-electric B-Class to the U.S. market as a small expansion of its alternative-propulsion product portfolio. For the moment, the electric hatchback is only available in eleven states, although fifty-state availability is expected. The B-Class seats five, offers a decent 21 cubic feet of cargo capacity behind the rear seats, and retains some of its European design features such as fold-down trays for the rear passenger. The B-Class offers some of Mercedes’ more advanced safety features, including Collision Prevention Assist Plus, which automatically applies the brakes if it detects the vehicle is not braking hard enough to avoid an impending collision. You will still pay extra for features that you might expect standard on a vehicle this pricey and technologically advanced, such as heated seats and a rearview camera.

But as with most electric cars, the majority of the attention tends to be paid to what’s under the hood rather than interior amenities. The electric B-Class is equipped with an electric motor that offers an equivalent 177 horsepower and an impressive 251 pound-feet of torque and moves it from 0 to 60 mph in 7.9 seconds. Mercedes estimates that the real-world driving range of the B-Class is nearly 100 miles, but the EPA estimate is a little lower at 87 miles. Charging times from empty are two hours for a 60-mile driving range and 3.5 hours for a full charge. There isn’t a quick charge option. This means you need to plan your road trips accordingly. However, Mercedes has equipped the electric B-Class with an “extended range” option that makes the battery’s full 36-kWh capacity available, and increases the estimated driving range by 25 to 30 percent. But keep in mind, the fine print states that overuse of this option can increase battery degradation.

New for 2015

The B-Class Electric Drive is all-new for 2015.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz G-Class
subTitle: The intrepid classic soldiers on, inimitable and unforgettable.
promoTeaserSmall: The intrepid classic soldiers on, inimitable and unforgettable.
promoTeaser: The intrepid classic soldiers on, inimitable and unforgettable.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz G-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; SUV; sport-utility; German
metaDescription: The intrepid classic soldiers on, inimitable and unforgettable.

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, all-wheel-drive SUV
Price range: $116,325—$138,075 (includes destination)
Trim levels: G550, G63 AMG
Engines: 5.5-liter V-8, 382 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 5.5-liter V-8, 536 horsepower
Transmission: 7-speed automatic
Fuel economy: G550: 12 mpg city/15 mpg highway; G63 AMG: 12/14 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Heated front and rear seats
Notable standard features on this model: Comand infotainment with seven-inch display, power tilt/sliding roof with one-touch open, park assist, blind spot assist, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Paint and trim options
You might also be considering: Land Rover Range Rover, Toyota Land Cruiser

The G-Class stands out in the crowded SUV field due to its iconic design that harks back to a time when “explorer” was an acceptable job title. The 2015 G is well equipped with either a 382-horsepower, 5.5-liter V-8 engine in the GL550 or the twin-turbo version that bumps up the output to 536 horsepower in the G63. Both are paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission. With standard all-wheel drive, three sequentially lockable differentials, and eight inches of wheel travel, the G-Class boasts some serious off-road capabilities. One may be forgiven for saying the G-Class is over-engineered, since it’s more likely to be traversing the Whole Foods parking lot rather than the plains of the Serengeti. On that end, drivers will be pleased that it’s standard equipped with adaptive cruise control, blind-spot assist, a rearview camera, and parking assist sensors to help you squeeze into those tricky compact parking spaces.

New for 2015

There are no major changes to the G-Class for 2015.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter
subTitle: Commercial vehicle with versatility and appeal.
promoTeaserSmall: Commercial vehicle with versatility and appeal.
promoTeaser: Commercial vehicle with versatility and appeal.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; van; cargo van; passenger van; diesel; German
metaDescription: Commercial vehicle with versatility and appeal.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two- to 16-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive passenger or cargo van
Price range: $36,990–$47,175 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 2500 Cargo, 2500 Passenger, 2500 Crew, 3500 Cargo, 3500 Passenger, 3500 Chassis Cab
Engines: Turbo-diesel 2.1-liter four-cylinder, 161 horsepower; turbo-diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 188 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: N/A
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Crosswind assist
Notable standard features on this model: Load-adaptive stability control, collision prevention, 5.8-inch color LCD display, Bluetooth
Notable options on this model: Regular or long wheelbase, standard or high roof, parking assist, lane-keeping assist, blind-spot assist, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Ford Transit, GMC Savana, Nissan NV, Ram ProMaster

The market for a sixteen-seat commercial van is largely, well, commercial, but the choices have never been more appealing if you’re looking for a people mover. The 2015 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter is available as either a passenger (three row), crew (two row with cargo), or cargo van configuration, and offered with a 144- or 170-inch wheelbase. Buyers can choose from two turbo-diesel engines: the standard 161-horsepower, 2.1-liter 4-cylinder or a 188-horsepower, 3.0-liter V-6. Both are linked to a seven-speed automatic transmission. Although not technically an off-roader, it does have an available 4x4 drivetrain on both cargo and passenger versions equipped with the V-6, which makes it more capable in inclement weather. And because of its tall and top-heavy vehicle—especially if you choose the high roof option—buyers will appreciate the standard crosswind assist for additional stability. Optional safety features abound, including blind-spot assist, lane-keeping assist, and high beam assist. While a 5.8-inch color display and Bluetooth connectivity are standard, a rearview camera is optional. The interior has been nicely upgraded, but most of the outfitting in a Sprinter is bespoke and performed by what Mercedes calls a Preferred Upfitter, which means the sky—and your wallet—is the limit when it comes to customizing this van.

New for 2015

Crosswind Assist has been added as a standard feature and all-wheel drive can now be optioned with the V-6 engine.

title: Pro/Con: To Bumpersticker or Not?
subTitle: Do you make your car a rolling message board? Laura says go for it; Molly won't commit. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaserSmall: Is your car a rolling message board? Laura says go for it; Molly is sticker-free. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Is your car a rolling message board? Laura says go for it; Molly is sticker-free. Whose side are you on?
metaDescription: Is your car a rolling message board? Laura says go for it; Molly is sticker-free. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura: Views Expressed by This Vehicle Are Mine

Your car is a speech bubble. What are you going to make it say? Whether you're displaying political messages or stick-figure families (which I kind of like, no matter how much they're joked about), they can be the only thing that stands between your dull, inexpressive car and a rolling conversation between you and all the people you encounter in traffic. I say, don't leave your speech bubble empty.
Your car is a speech bubble. What are you going to make it say?

Some of the most memorable moments of my misspent youth involve bumperstickers. The first political campaign I remember was 1968, when booths were found on the street corners of my town handing out Humphrey, Nixon, and Wallace bumperstickers and most people had one or another on their cars in that contentious year. The first demonstration I participated in was environmental, and someone pressed a No Nukes sticker into my hand even though I didn't yet own a car. "Put it on your bicycle," the well-meaning hippie suggested. I looked forward to the opportunity to have a car like a lot of those I admired on the streets, with a back end totally covered with stickers.

And yet, when I got my first new car, I was curiously hesitant to sully its paint with any stickers. I tried a peace sign magnet; somebody stole it off the back. Then I realized, that's why God gave us Goo-Gone. And I started peeling and sticking in earnest.

I've gotten over my fear of sticking something semi-permanent onto my car. For one thing, there's always the window. I have three kids in college, and each of their schools gets pride of place on the back of my car. Political campaigns will see me putting at least a few regional or national stickers onto the back window.
And I love to see a Toyota Prius at a stoplight in front of me that is completely covered with messages and slogans. Even a rusty pickup with NRA stickers makes me happy: the First Amendment at work.

Molly: My Car's Rear End Has Taken a Vow of Purity

I love bumper stickers, but only if I am looking out my windshield and it is on someone else’s car. I truly enjoy reading them. I believe that bumper sticker people are passionate people. They proclaim what is important to them and proudly wear it on their tail. I am confident that many pro sticker people fill their Facebook feeds with messages that reveal their peeves and pleas. I assume their yards have signs that proclaim their favorite politicians and support or displeasure with local or national issues. These are people who wear their hearts on their sleeves.
There is enough tension on the highways already, so I will leave my political opinions for cocktail discussion among rational adults.

I personally do not want to discuss politics with most anyone, and certainly not with anyone who has Fox News as their default station. I respect that they have a right to believe anything they want; I just don’t want to debate it. I also don’t want to advertise how I stand on most political issues. I am not embarrassed of my opinion; I am just not comfortable putting my choice right on my bumper. I would worry that if I proudly put a “Hillary for America” sticker on my bumper and parked in certain parts of America that my car might be vandalized, or worse, cause my fellow drivers to judge me. There is enough tension on the highways so I will leave my political opinions for cocktail discussion among rational adults.  I know that when I see certain stickers that are intended to get a rise out of other drivers I can’t wait to pass them so I can get a good look at the driver.

My daughter begged us to get a set of stick figures for the back of our van. We finally broke down and got a magnetic peace sign instead. It was promptly stolen. I love stickers, just not on cars, and don’t even get me started on the cars I see where the kids willy-nilly stick stickers all over the back windows. Our salvation for my daughter’s sticker love was her footlocker for camp. The stickers look great there, and it has become a sort of scrapbook of her life. And truth be told, if I drove a beater I would be more likely to plaster it with stickers to give it some character.

But my strongest reason for not wanting bumper stickers on my car is purely aesthetic. As a designer, I find very few stickers that are well enough designed that I would want to look at them through the duration of my car ownership. Bad typography, color choice, and layout are rampant in the sticker world. Designers spent countless hours painstakingly creating my lovely Chrysler Town & Country van; who am I to deface it? But to the stickerophiles in the world I give you the breakfast club arm pump. I will remain pure, and when I finally get to own the Mercedes of my dreams, it will too remain a sticker virgin.

title: 6 Coolest Car Experiences in Europe
subTitle: My favorites! Don’t let another year go by without crossing some of these off your bucket list.
promoTeaserSmall: My favorites! Don’t let another year go by without crossing some of these off your bucket list.
promoTeaser: My favorites! Don’t let another year go by without crossing some of these off your bucket list.
metaTitle: 6 Coolest Car Experiences in Europe - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: My favorites! Don’t let another year go by without crossing some of these off your bucket list.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Autumn is a great time to plan a spring or summer trip to Europe, and while you’re planning, make room for one or more of these auto-related adventures. I’ve tried most of them, and I’m here to tell you, you should do likewise. They’re graded from easiest to most challenging.

1. Buy a car from a European carmaker, have a vacation, and then ship it home.

Among potentials: Audi, Volvo, Porsche, BMW, and Mercedes-Benz. You order the car a few months in advance, pick it up at the factory—and get a tour and other perks—drive around Europe, then drop it off at a prearranged dropoff point. Shipping to the U.S. takes a few months; costs and terms vary by automaker. Check individual European delivery programs to be sure what’s included and what’s extra.

2. Visit the massive Schlumpf auto collection in Mulhouse, France.

Located near the Swiss border, the collection was secretly amassed by reclusive brothers who owned a textile factory. It was revealed during fiery protests by underpaid workers living almost like slaves in company housing. It is now called the National Automobile Museum Collection Schlumpf. The secretive Schlumpfs unsuccessfully attempted to find and buy every Bugatti ever made. They managed to procure a rare Bugatti Royale—the Type 41 Coupé Napoléon Royale. Only six Bugatti Royales were produced. This one almost made my brain turn to cottage cheese when I saw it up close.

3. Become a member of the Royal North Cape Club in Nordkapp, Norway.

(I became Royal North Cape Club member #1837 on May 6, 1985.) To get your diploma, drive 1,300 miles from Oslo to Nordkapp, the northernmost point in Europe. Bring companions, a satellite phone, chains, and $18.39 in cold, hard Norwegian kroner (150 of those, to be precise). Wait until early summer. You’ll experience the midnight sun from mid-May until the end of July, which is a lot like the midafternoon sun in Michigan, but with dancing Sami, the reindeer people previously known as Lapps. How do I know this? I danced most of the night sun into the day sun with them.

4. Trace the route of the great Monte Carlo Rally.

Go in winter for extra points. Go slowly. Or maybe just follow the official re-creation, the Rallye Monte-Carlo Historique, from a safe distance! The 2016 event runs from January 27 to February 3.

5. Buy a ticket to drive on the Nürburgring.

The legendary Nürburgring circuit is actually a national road open to the public, except on days when car and tire manufacturers have booked it for product testing. One of the most challenging road courses in the world, the “Green Hell” is the ne plus ultra test of cars trying to claim the ever-changing Fastest Car in the World crown. From April to October, you can hire a performance driver in a 560-horsepower BMW M5 “taxicab” to take you around the seventy-three-corner, 12.9-mile Nordschleife for about $250. Bring a strong stomach.

6. Drive from Liège, Belgium, to Rome and back to Liège as fast as you can.

Then try to figure out how British racing legend Sir Stirling Moss’s sister, Pat Moss, won that particular rally back in 1960 in her Austin-Healey 3000. In 1989, I asked my heroine Pat to race in the Pirelli Classic Marathon with me from London to Cortina D’Ampezzo, Italy, in a vintage Healey 3000, and she said, “That bloody car didn’t kill me back then, old girl, and I’m not going to give it another chance!” Stirling and I ended up doing the Pirelli Classic Marathon in a 1965 MGB, ending third overall and first in class.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class
subTitle: The sun sets on this luxury crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: The sun sets on this luxury crossover.
promoTeaser: The sun sets on this luxury crossover.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLK-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; crossover; sport-utility; SUV; wagon; diesel; German
metaDescription: The sun sets on this luxury crossover. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $38,825–$40,325
Trim levels: GLK250 BlueTec, GLK350
Engines: Twin-turbocharged diesel 2.1-liter 4-cylinder, 200 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 302 horsepower
Fuel economy: GLK250 BlueTec: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway; GLK350: 19/25 mpg; GLK350 4MATIC: 18/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: 8-way power adjustable front seats
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth, tilt and telescoping steering column, steering-wheel mounted shift-paddles, all-wheel drive (BlueTec model), 19-inch wheels
Notable options on this model: 115-volt outlet in cargo area, power liftgate, active blind-spot, lane keeping, and parking assist
You might also be considering: Acura RDX, BMW X3, Infiniti EX

It’s the end of the line for the 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class. Next year the compact SUV will be reborn as the GLC-Class, so if you’re partial to the squared-off, wagon-esque design of the GLK, hurry to the dealership before they’re all spoken for. Engine variants for this model include a 3.5-liter V-6 with 302 horsepower and a twin-turbo 2.1-liter four-cylinder diesel with 200 horsepower and 369 pound-feet of torque. Both engines are paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission, and while you can get the GLK350 with rear- or all-wheel drive, the diesel version is only available with the latter. At 18 mpg in the city and 24 mpg on the highway, fuel economy is decent but not exceptional in the GLK350 4MATIC, although dropping AWD will improve the numbers by 1 mpg in both the city and highway ratings. To get a significant bump, you’ll have to opt for the diesel, if you can still find it.

Legroom is a bit snug for rear passengers with only 35.1 inches to spread out and, despite its boxy hindquarters, the GLK-Class's cargo capacity is only 16.5 cubic feet with the rear seats up; that number jumps to 54.7 with the second row folded flat. Like most Mercedes-Benz vehicles, the GLK's interior is elegant, but most of the bells and whistles that many drivers have come to expect in new vehicles are optional features, such as navigation, a rearview camera, and a power liftgate. That usually isn’t much of a drawback for luxury buyers willing to shell out the extra thousands for the German crossover’s premium packages, but as with most end-of-cycle cars, they’ll probably have to take what they can get from what’s left on the lot.

New for 2015

No major changes.

title: The Best and Worst Cities for Drivers
subTitle: Of 100 cities and towns, where do you suffer the most or least? The breakdown.
promoTitle: The Best and Worst Cities for Drivers
promoTeaserSmall: Of 100 cities and towns, where do you suffer the most or least? The breakdown.
promoTeaser: Of 100 cities and towns, where do you suffer the most or least? The breakdown.
keywords: The Best and Worst Cities for Drivers
metaTitle: The Best and Worst Cities for Drivers
metaDescription: Of 100 cities and towns, where do you suffer the most or least? The breakdown.

pageElements.text: Oh, sweet summer: a time for sunshine, barbecues, beach days, and higher gas prices. With longer trips to the cottage on the horizon and gas prices tending to peak during these warmer months, now would be an opportune time to know the best and worst cities to be a driver. Leading personal finance website WalletHub has compiled a list, comparing the 100 most populated cities in the United States across areas like average gas prices, average annual traffic delays, and average parking rates.

This map shows the best cities for driving as smaller dots; as the circles get bigger, so does the amount of hassle involved with driving in that city.

Source: WalletHub

What do the highest-rated cities have in common? Two words struck me when I saw WalletHub’s top ten best cities to be a driver: small town. Well, all of the cities on the list have populations of at least 100,000, so they are not small in the one school and a general store kind of way. However, when put in a pool with the country’s biggest cities, Greensboro, North Carolina, in the number-four position, does feel a bit small.

The top three cities are Lubbock and Corpus Christi, Texas, and Lincoln, Nebraska. All have populations that hover around 300,000 and median incomes per household that are slightly below the national average. A generally okay standard of living plus fewer people equals lower rates of car theft and accident likelihood, WalletHub says. Another (perhaps questionable) small-city stereotype? Southern. Nine out of ten cities at the top of WalletHub’s list are found in the southern half of the country. The warmer and sometimes drier climate definitely contributes to these cities’ better road conditions, fewer traffic delays, and overall happier drivers.

What about the ones at the bottom? It comes as no surprise that the U.S.’s largest cities make the list of ten worst cities to be a driver. New York City is home to 8.5 million people. With that many individuals trying to get to the office, coffee shop, or school, there is bound to be exponentially more traffic, poorer road conditions, and less parking availability. Big cities face another issue: greater rates of car theft. With urban areas come a wider economic spectrum. Detroit has the third highest rate of car theft, in addition to a population of 680,000 in which one out of every three residents lives below the poverty line. Washington, D.C., Philadelphia, and San Francisco hold the three spots behind New York City, but don’t worry; you don’t have to give up on your Sex and the City dreams just because driving to work will take you three times longer. Most of the worst cities to be a driver are also the best cities to be a public transportation user, so moving there might just mean trading in your keys for a subway pass or a regular taxicab habit.

This list will probably not determine your next home town, and if it does I applaud your commitment to enjoyable driving. If you crave smooth roads and a low-traffic rush hour, though, take a look at these figures and maybe pack your bags.

The Best Cities for Drivers

1. Lubbock, Texas
2. Corpus Christi, Texas
3. Lincoln, Nebraska
4. Greensboro, North Carolina
5. Tucson, Arizona
6. Reno, Nevada
7. Durham, North Carolina
8. Colorado Springs, Colorado
9. Winston-Salem, North Carolina
10. Raleigh, North Carolina

The Worst Cities for Drivers

10. Los Angeles
9. Baltimore
8. Chicago
7. Boston
6. Newark
5. Detroit
4. San Francisco
3. Philadelphia
2. Washington, D.C.
1 (worst). New York City
Washington, D.C., has six times more average annual hours of traffic delays than Bakersfield, California.

Lowest likelihood of an accident: Boise, Idaho.
Five highest average gas prices: five California cities, San Francisco, San Diego, Chula Vista, Los Angeles, and Long Beach.
In Irvine, California, you are twenty-seven times less likely to have your car stolen compared with Detroit.
Fewest car washes per capita: Boston.
Parking rates in Chicago are fourteen times higher than in Wichita, Kansas.

title: Android Auto: What You Need to Know
subTitle: The smartphone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.
promoTitle: Android Auto: What You Need to Know
promoTeaserSmall: The smartphone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.
promoTeaser: The smartphone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.
keywords: Android Auto: What You Need to Know
metaTitle: Android Auto: What You Need to Know - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The smartphone experience for your car, soon to be widely available. What makes it so good.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: It’s a bad moment. You shopped for a car. You read reviews. You showed up with a checklist of must-have features. You tried the seats, tested the cupholders, drove it with a salesperson in the back seat. But now that you’ve got it home, you discover you totally hate the in-car telematics system.  The navigation is maddening, the on-screen apps are unfamiliar and scant, and who knows what is going on with the rest of it. And you realize that you are stuck with it. For years. You paid for it. Like most of us, you’ll use it as a radio and turn to your much more familiar phone for all the other things you have come to expect from touchscreens.

And that is why Google launched Android Auto in 2014. Car companies make cars. And, for the most part, they do that well. Google, on the other hand, has spent decades, fortunes, and countless human hours creating Google search, its voice interface Google Now, and the Android mobile operating system. All are designed to give you access to the information you want right now, easily and quickly. It was a herculean task that changed the world. And today, Google is very good at voice search, mapping, and answering whatever question pops into your head—even if that question is, “Where is the nearest gas station?” That’s why, with rare exceptions, people quickly give up on the in-car telematics and pick up their phones instead. Google spoiled us.
Android Auto is Google’s effort to bring everything you love about your Android phone into your vehicle.

Android Auto is Google’s effort to bring everything you love about your Android phone into your vehicle. If a car supports it, you simply plug in your phone and load the app, and it will take over the dash and use your phone’s data plan to do everything from streaming music to mapping your destination to answering questions you ask Google Now by voice.

I have been trying to hold out against buying a new car until I could get one with a telematics system that ran it. But finding a car that offers Android Auto has been difficult until now. Fortunately that is changing quickly.

The 2105 Hyundai Sonata was the first vehicle to use Android Auto. Chevrolet already offers Apple CarPlay on many models; starting with the 2016 model year, its popular Everyman vehicle, the Chevrolet Cruze, and fourteen other Chevrolets will also support Android Auto. Acura, Audi, Dodge, Chrysler, Ford, Honda, Infiniti, Nissan, Subaru, Volkswagen, Volvo, and several other car manufacturers have announced the intention to include the technology in future cars. It’s far from widely available yet. But it’s getting there. You can find the complete and updated list at the Android Auto site.

Android Auto is a simplified and limited version of the Android you know and love. It’s optimized to be easy to use when you are driving, meaning that it can be understood at a quick glance. The mapping is the same Google Maps you are used to, redesigned for the way you use it in the car. Google Now is available at a touch. You can tap a button to ask Google Now any question you might have and, since it’s been practicing for quite a while on a lot of phones, the answers you get are often startlingly good. The mapping, too, is Google Maps good.
The apps available in the car are much more limited than the vast marketplace of apps in the Google Play store. (But still way more than most car manufacturers support.)

The apps available in the car, though, are much more limited than the vast marketplace of apps you’ll find in the Google Play store. (But still way more than most car manufacturers support.) At the moment there are about twenty, and it’s an odd assortment: Skype, Google Play Music, Hangouts, Kik, WhatsApp, Spotify, iHeartRadio, some texting apps, and a few others.

But all of this is a moving target. Google is a tech company, nimble and fast-changing, and it is famous for testing and perfecting products in the marketplace. Whatever is true at this early stage of Android Auto is likely not to be true in a year or two. More apps will become available, and brilliant nerds will find awesome ways to use it. But that’s okay. Your phone—if it’s a reasonably recent Android phone that meets Google’s specs for using Android Auto—will update the in-car app as it changes.

I don’t know where Android Auto will go. But this much I know: If you’re an Android fan and you can wait for a car with Android Auto in it, do that. In fact, you will want a car that supports both Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. You might get a new phone, right? Because you will want to own that car for a few years. And that moment of hating the in-car telematics is solved much more simply if you can just plug your phone in and be instantly living in the present—whatever that present looks like.

title: 2015 Volvo V60
subTitle: The wagon returns.
promoTeaserSmall: The wagon returns.
promoTeaser: The wagon returns.
metaDescription: The wagon returns. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive wagon
Price range: $36,675–$49,475 (includes destination)
Trim levels: T5 Drive-E, T5 AWD, T5 AWD Cross Country, T6 AWD R-Design
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 2.5-liter inline five-cylinder, 250 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter inline six-cylinder, 325 horsepower
Transmissions: 6- or 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.0-liter: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway; 2.0-liter Cross Country: 24/31 mpg; 2.5-liter AWD: 20/29 mpg; 2.5-liter AWD Cross Country: 20/28 mpg; 3.0-liter: 19/28 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick+; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: City Safety collision avoidance
Notable standard features on this model: LED running lights, heated mirrors, keyless ignition and entry, dual-zone automatic climate control, 40/20/40-split flat-folding rear seats, 8-way adjustable power front seats, Bluetooth, adjustable steering wheel
Notable options on this model: On Call (similar to GM’s OnStar), front and rear parking sensors, rearview camera, navigation, voice controls, sunroof, blind spot monitoring
You might also be considering: Audi Allroad, BMW 3 Series, Subaru Outback

Station wagons are part and parcel of the lives of middle-aged Americans who went on vacations in the family wagon long before the advent of the minivan. As minivans grew in popularity, wagons began to disappear from the U.S. car scene—much to the consternation of U.S. wagon aficionados. So the announcement that Volvo would be bringing a wagon back to the U.S. market was greeted with great anticipation.

The Volvo V60 has lived up to—and exceeded—expectations. Essentially a wagon version of the S60 sedan, the V60 has many of the same powertrains and features as its sibling. Like the S60, the V60 is available with front- or all-wheel drive, with a four-, five-, or six-cylinder engine, and with a six- or eight-speed automatic transmission. Standard equipment includes heated mirrors, dual-zone climate control, 40/20/40-split rear seats, Bluetooth, and a sunroof.

What the wagon version offers that the sedan lacks is 43.8 cubic feet of cargo capacity and a Cross Country version. Yes, that’s right, Volvo has brought back the Cross Country name with a go-anywhere version of the V60. The Cross Country is differentiated from the V60 by a honeycomb grille, skid plates, side scuff plates, black fender extensions, and ground clearance that has been raised by 2.6 inches, to 7.9 inches total. The Cross Country is powered by the 250-horsepower five-cylinder and, naturally, comes with all-wheel drive.

The V60 is fun to drive, with well-balanced handling and strong acceleration, no matter which engine you choose. On top of that, the four-cylinder gets 29 mpg in combined city/highway driving, which makes it both fun and practical.

New for 2015

The Volvo V60 made its debut for the 2015 model year.

You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Passat

The Mazda 6 has received rave reviews since its launch for being a spacious, quality, efficient, and pretty sedan, and that all holds true for 2016. With added options that make it a bit more posh, the Mazda 6 appeals to buyers across the socioeconomic spectrum. A seven-inch touchscreen and Sport mode buttons now come standard on all three trim levels, and Parchment leather has replaced Almond leather in the Grand Touring. The optional Technology package include heated seats and navigation. You have one engine option—a 2.5-liter four-cylinder—but two choices of transmission: six-speed manual and six-speed automatic. The Mazda 6 received five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and is a Top Safety Pick Plus, the top rating of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. With 98 cubic feet of passenger volume and 15 cubic feet of cargo space, the Mazda 6 is no minivan, but it is roomy enough.

New for 2016: Electronic parking brake
Upgraded center console, dash, and armrest design

Notable options on this model: Power moonroof with tilt, Lane Watch, push-button start, floor mats, HDMI port (all optional on EX and EX-L); leather-trimmed seats and steering wheel, heated front seats (optional on EX-L only); navigation system with voice recognition, HD digital traffic (optional on EX-L only)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Sonic, Ford Fiesta, Hyundai Accent, Kia Rio, Toyota Yaris

You'd be forgiven if you have dismissed the Honda Fit as yet another really cramped city car. It is so much more than that: almost shockingly spacious for a subcompact hatchback, the Honda Fit offers a degree of flexibility for daily use that just might spoil you for larger, less fuel-efficient cars. With seats in place, the Fit offers 16.6 cubic feet of cargo space, which is more than you'll see in competitors such as the Chevrolet Sonic or Ford Fiesta hatchback (both at 14.9) and the Kia Rio five-door (12.3). Fold down the seats—which go flat thanks to the instant-folding Magic Seat feature—and the yield is 52.7 cubic feet, again more than the competition. Fuel economy skirts around the all-important 40-mpg level on the highway, depending on whether you choose the more efficient continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT) or the six-speed manual. The base LX and midlevel EX models have the six-speed manual as standard, while the top EX-L model comes only with the CVT. Paddle shifters are an option to liven up your CVT experience on the EX; they're standard on the EX-L. Other creature comforts if you opt for the EX-L are leather-trimmed seats and steering wheel, heated front seats, and, for an added $1,000, a navigation system with voice recognition and HD digital traffic, making the best use of the seven-inch touchscreen. (That screen is also found on the EX, but the LX gets a five-inch touchscreen.) Both EX and EX-L models have options including a power moonroof with a tilt feature, push-button start, and Honda's Lane Watch, which shows live video from a camera on your passenger's-side mirror when you turn your right turn signal on (EX, EX-L). That's what you call exceeding expectations; not only will you get used to this feature, you won't remember how you got along without it. You won't forget the diminutive size of the car you're driving if you choose the Fit, but you won't feel like you've cheaped out; in fact, you'll feel like you're driving a modern, well-appointed, up-to-date vehicle, a good feeling anytime and especially at this price point.

New for 2016:

The Fit's third generation was all new for 2015 and continues unchanged this year.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan or coupe
Price range: Sedan: $22,925-$35,400; coupe: $24,595-$34,945 (includes destination charge)
Trim levels: Sedan: LX, Sport, Ex, EX-L, EX-L V-6, Touring; coupe: LX-S, EX-L, EX-L V-6, EX-L Navi with Honda Sensing, EX-L Navi V-6 with Honda Sensing, Touring V-6
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower (189 horsepower in Sport model); 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual, continuously variable automatic (four-cylinder models); six-speed automatic (V-6 models)
Fuel economy: LX, Sport, EX with manual: 23 mpg city/34 mpg highway; LX and EX with CVT: 27/37 mp g; Sport with CVT: 26/35 mpg; EX-L V-6, andTouring 21/34 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Multi-angle rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model:Nineteen-inch alloy wheels, LED daytime running and fog lights, dual exhaust, side sills, body-color rear deck-lid spoiler, aluminum-clad foot pedals, leather wrapped steering wheel, ten-way power adjustable driver’s seat, 160-watt four-speaker audio
Notable options on this model: Honda Sensing package (approximately $1,000; includes forward collision warning, collision mitigation braking, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, adaptive cruise control); remote engine start; park assist; rain sensing wipers; heated rear seats
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Hyundai Sonata, Kia Optima, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Passat

You see so many of these in your daily life, don't you? After all, the Honda Accord has been around for almost forty years and has been manufactured in the U.S. since 1982. More than 10 million have been built in North America, in fact, so many that the Honda dealers could put up a McDonald's-style "Millions Served" sign if they wanted. But does ubiquity lead to contempt? Not in our book. The Accord has won a place in so many driveways precisely because it's so well executed. Buyers flock to it knowing they can count on it to be well built and reliable as well as comfortable and drivable. If there's a little less excitement than with a lot of other cars you could choose, well, it's a mid-size, front-wheel-drive sedan, not a sports car. 2016 brings changes to the ninth-generation Accord that was introduced for 2013. Think of it as ninth generation 2.0, while we wait for the all-new tenth generation in a couple of years.

Read our full review here.

New for 2016: New front-end design; larger wheels and tires; Apple CarPlay and Android Auto; Honda Sensing active safety package standard on Touring and available as an option across all models (approximately $1,000); Touring model added to coupe lineup
